39370536.review:
I've played this game for the first time in 2017. So I'm not influenced by any nostalgia. And it's now my favorite point'n click. You can switch any time between the three heroes, in their own path, to help them travel back in time. You can tell the guy had fun writing this delirious game. It's humoristic from start to end, through all enigmas, all dialogues, all situations. Strangely, there's kind of logic in all these puzzles, but it's still make you laugh when you find the solution.
It's hard, very hard, not predictable but I've never got annoyed and always felt the answer was close. You can find all of them by cleverness, without help of coincidence.
In this genre, it's clearly a masterpiece, a must-have game without any discussion about it.

Depuis le temps que j'en entendais parler, il fallait bien que je me lance un jour. Et franchement, aucun regret.

Les animations sont magnifiques, les dialogues (et donc l'humour) juste géniaux, et la difficulté juste comme il faut. Bravo LucasArt : déjà que je considérais Monkey Island et Grim Fandango comme des chefs d'oeuvre, tu n'as décidément pas fini de me surprendre (oui, j'ai découvert le jeu un peu tard) !

Je dois quand même avouer avoir bien tourné pour pouvoir avancer un petit peu, et certaines énigmes sont vraiment capillotractées (il faut aussi dire que j'ai mis trois ans à comprendre la véritable utilité des toilettes, j'en dis pas plus).

Bref, j'ai adoré et je recommande à 100%. Mention spéciale pour le hamster.

39294050.review:
This is another example of a classic point and click game done well. As a spin off from Maniac Mansion, I was skeptical when I first played this game years ago that it would try to be a fun game, but ultimately would fall flat. I was pleasantly surprised. Set in the same world as the original Maniac Mansion, the game thrusts three characters into chaos as one goes into the past, one into the future, and one stays in the present. All three of them must work through puzzles and finding items to get everyone back into the same time. Chopping down trees, spitting out dentures, and getting electrocuted by a kite are all adventures to be had, and in a hilarious way. The items needed to be used together or to complete puzzles are used in logical ways. There are few combinations that may seem frustrating, but they are few and far between. There are no random combinations that do not make sense. The game does not have a hint system and there are a few puzzles that will take a lengthy amount of time to figure out. Or you can check a guide. 

There are wonderful characters, such as the American founding fathers, who constantly fight with each other, the purple and green tentacles, Dr. Fred, and the main three characters you will play, Bernard, Hoagie, and Laverne. The story and events that happen are consistently funny and never forced.

The graphics work perfectly for a zany, laugh out loud, silly story. The music is equally great as well as the solid voice acting. This is still an outstanding game from the 90's that will have you laughing and wish there were more games like it.

9.5/10

39186951.review:
Day of the Tentacle,..wer kennt diesen Klassiker aus dem Hause Lucas Arts nicht? Naja gut, jeder der nicht das Glück hatte in den 80ern oder 90ern großgeworden zu sein und somit eines der besten Advnture-Spiele spielen konnte, die jemals erschienen sind. Zusammen mit Monkey Island, Sam und Max Hit the Road oder Full Throttle gehört dieses Spiel eindeutig an die Spitze der Adventurespiele. Diese Version ist eine Remastered-Version mit schön aufgebesserten Originaltexturen sodass das Spiel in heutiger Optik erscheint.

Der Spieler übernimmt in diesen Adventure die Kontrolle über drei Protagonisten die unterschiedlicher nicht sein können. Zum einen haben wir Bernard, einen augenscheinlichen Nerd, dann Laverne die durchgeknallte Blonde im Bunde und Hoagie, einen Rowdie wie er im Buche steht. Diese drei leben zusammen in einer WG, bis eines Tages ein Hamster vor der Tür steht mit einem Brief für Bernard. So fängt das Abenteuer an,...welches im Verlaufe der Geschichte dazu führt, dass man Automaten knackt, absolut gegen den Tierschutz verstößt, den Vereinigten Staaten eine neue Flagge schenkt, unsagbare Dinge mit einer Mumie anstellt und mal eben 2 Millionen im Teleshopping verpratzt und viele viele andere Dinge abstellt die abseits jeglichen gesunden Menschenverstandes liegt. Und warum? Um die Menschheit zu retten!

Ich habe das Spiel damals in der Originalversion schon geliebt und bin sehr zufreiden mit dieser Remastered-Version. Einziger Nachteil ist, dass das Spiel in mehreren Zwischensequenzen einen Bug hat und ohne die Überspringen-Funktion das Spiel nicht weitergeht, wodurch es unmöglich wird die letzten beiden Achievements zu erlangen. Wenn man nicht unbedingt die Achievements haben muss ist dieses Spiel auf jeden Fall empfehlenswert und natürlich für alle Fans der Adventure-Szene die diesen Klassiker zuvor noch nie gespielt haben.

11/10 lo compraría dos veces más.

38702799.review:
The Day of the Tentacle Remastered is a cute little game and quite humorous.  I remembered when it originally came out and heard it was a fun adventure game, but I never got it or other great games like The Seceret of Monkey Island, etc because I've never really been into adventure style games.  However, when I saw the Rematered edition on Steam and for a decent sale price, I decided to pick it up and at least try to experience it.

It's good.  

The main recurring complaint I've seen about the remstered edition is that the voice acting was bad and that it should have been updated or something.  I think this is kind of B.S. because I think people have gotten a little spoiled and used to modern games where game companies pay high priced actors to come in and do voices.  Day of the Tentacle came out in a different era of games production.  In early games most voice acting was done in-house by developers and such.  With that in mind, I actually enjoyed the voice acting.   I am actually glad they didn't re-do Laverne's lines with a new voice because once I got use to her, she was the most interesting.  I felt Laverne was very funny and fit with the personalilty in how she physically moves throughout the game.  Hogie was also quite funny as well.  Some of the jokes are a little dated, but overall still quite good.  The tentacles were all enjoyable too.

The story had a neat little premise and overall I am glad finally I picked up Day of the Tentacle Remastered. 

Thanks for the fun.

I really recommend it. Great remake of an awesome old fashion game. I really hope that they remake Maniac Mansion.

For old fashion gamers it is a game worth to buy. You can choose to enjoy the new graphics, play with the game or even play the old Maniac Mansion. It is a very nostalgic and fun experience. For people who is less familiar with this kind of games it can be either an amazing experience or a frustrating one. I know that old fashion 'adventure games' have a very specific logic (try every conversation, touch everything and try to combine every object) and I understand that before enjoying this kind of games you need to understand it. But if you accept this 'game logic' it really becomes an enjoyable game.

38213547.review:
A time traveling point and click adventure where you control three different people in three different times trying to prevent an uprising by the Purple Tentacle. The puzzles are well designed and the humor is great, especially if you’ve played a lot of adventure games in the past, as there are a lot of call backs. 

On the other hand, it isn’t very long. That said, it is worth picking up.

One last note, you can transport items through time by dragging them from one inventory and dropping them on the other two characters. This is much faster than the using items on the Chronotron and the only way to get Master Plumber in a reasonable amount of time.

I loved the cartoon style.  The pace was a bit slow compared to an actual cartoon.  But it was ruined by the unintuitive leaps of logic the game requires you to make to solve the puzzles.  Basically, you might have to try one of the 20 objects in your inventory with any of 100 random things in the environment.  How am I supposed to know to combine a squirrel with a battery?  They may have been focused on selling access to their hint phone line line back in the day.
If you do play it, do yourself a favor and have this walkthrough playing off to the side to refer to in case you get stuck...which will happen every 5 minutes.
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=eW283uY3sLI
(Remember, YouTube shortcuts are > to speed up and right arrow to skip forward 5 seconds.)

Grandpa: Hey Kids!
Kids: Hey Grandpa!
Grandpa: Do you wann know what games we played back in the 1990's?
Kids: Yay. (obvious lie)
Grandpa: We called them Point and Click Adventures. It was called Point and Click Adventures because we had to point at a certain spot on the screen and click it and it was very adventurous to find the exact pixel because we had no internet to google its location...
Kids: Whats a Pixel Grandpa?
Grandpa: Back in my days pixels where everywhere.
Kids: Even in Shooters?
Grandpa: Exspecially in Shooters!
Kids: What did those pixels do?
Grandpa: They annoyed us whenever they could. But then 3DFX Grafic accelerrators where invented and hexed us with thier voodoo (ultrapun).
Grandpa:... ...
Grandpa: Now that I think about it, that was about the same time when Point and Click Adventures suddenly dissapeared. I guess so cause it became to hard to point at the exact pixel and click it.

37777445.review:
To me this is the best point and click adventure of all time. I played it numerous times before and now while playing remastered version I must say it haven't lost any of the old charm.

Story, characters and puzzles are all funny and even silly. Some puzzles could seem difficult and illogical but figuring those out becomes very rewarding and funny experience because they have some silly logic that at the end just makes sense! Rare games are able to accomplish that.

Day of the Tentacle was one of the games that drawn me to the game industry. I was never fortunate enough to work on a real point and click adventure, but it's still an inspiration for characters, puzzles, dialogues... but also is an example of a great product which has equal quality of all game elements throughout the whole game. 37719895.review:
Ein Klassiker aus meiner Jugend bekommt eine Neuauflage? Klar, dass ich dieses Spiel haben musste. Und ich wurde nicht enttäuscht, denn das Spiel wurde 1:1 übernommen und lediglich optisch und akustisch ansprechend modernisiert. 
Für alle, die es nicht kennen: Day of the Tentacle ist ein Point&Click Adventure aus den 90ern, als dieses Genre Hochkonjunktur hatte und Lucasarts die Meisterschaft darin errungen hatte. Es ist der Nachfolger zu Maniac Mansion und kommt im überdrehten Comic-Look daher. 
Die Story ist dabei herrlich blödsinnig: ein lila Tentakel - "Purpur" genannt - trinkt einen Schluck verseuchtes Wasser und mutiert zu einem Super-Tentakel mit Armen, das die Welt beherrschen will.
Dr. Fred, der das Desaster ausgelöst hat, schickt die Freunde Bernard, Hoagie und Laverne mit je einer zur Zeitmaschine umgebauten Toilette in die Vergangenheit, um das Problem rückgängig zu machen. Dummerweise explodiert der Diamant, mit dem die Maschine betrieben wird und Hoagie landet in der Kolonialzeit, Bernard bleibt in der Gegenwart und Laverne landet in einer fernen, von Tentakeln beherrschten Zukunft. 
Das Ziel ist es nun, die Freunde wieder zusammenzubringen: Bernard muss einen neuen Diamanten besorgen, Hoagie braucht eine Stromquelle und Laverne hat in der Zukunft ganz eigene Probleme. 
Der Clou: man spielt alle drei Charaktere (bzw. zunächst nur Hoagie und Bernard) und kann gefundene Gegenstände durch die Toiletten in die jeweils andere Zeit spülen. Hoagies Aktionen in der Vergangenheit wirken sich dabei direkt auf die anderen Zeitlinien aus, wodurch dort bestimmte Probleme umgangen werden können. 
Die Rätsel sind allesamt logisch und durch die Dialoge mit den unzähligen Figuren bekommt man teils recht eindeutige Hinweise zur Lösung. Da aber von Beginn an die meisten Areale begehbar sind, ist es gar nicht so einfach, die ganzen Möglichkeiten im Blick zu behalten. Schnell hat man einen wichtigen Ort vergessen oder einen offensichtlichen Gegenstand übersehen. Hinzu kommt noch das Tauschen der Gegenstände über die Zeiten hinweg. Somit gehört DotT trotz aller Logik definitiv zu den anspruchsvolleren Titeln. 
Der Humor ist aber einzigartig, die Figuren herrlich schräg und die Ideen wunderbar originell. Nur ein paar Stichworte für Kenner: Linkshänder-Hammer, Ozo der Clown, die Mumie, George Washington, die Steuerfahnder, entkoffeinierter Kaffee, tiefgekühlter Hamster...
Zur Technik: die Grafik ist nun hochaufgelöst und das Bild wurde auf Breitbild angepasst, indem die Menüleiste und das Inevntar am unteren Bildrand weggefallen bzw. ausgeblendet wurde. Zusätzlich wurden ein paar subtile Effekte, wie Unschräfe, Schatten und andere Details eingefügt.
Die Soundeffekte wurden an einigen Stellen aufgepeppt, entsprechen aber sonst weitgehend dem Original. Die deutsche Sprachausgabe wurde 1:1 übernommen, klingt dabei nicht so professionell, wie es in modernen Grafik-Adventures heutzutage üblich ist (z.B. in Edna bricht aus), aber die Frage ist, ob das hätte sein müssen, denn für den Kenner muss es der O-Ton sein, schließlich kommt dadurch ein Stück der alte Charme zustande.
Das Interface ist nun kontextbasiert und bietet über ein Kreismenü die gängigsten Funktionen an. Unzählige Steam Errungenschaften runden das ganze schließlich ab. 
Fazit: nach fast 25 Jahren hat es mir wahnsinnig Spaß gemacht, dieses Spiel erneut zu zocken und trotz diverser Vorkenntnisse dauerte es gut fünf Stunden bis zum Abspann, da eben nicht mehr alles geläufig war. Für Anfänger sicher eine harte Nuss, aber immer fair und lösbar. Die einzige Strafe, die man bekommt, wenn man nicht optimal spielt, ist das Laufen von Umwegen.
Daumen hoch und ich hoffe, dass dieses Remake Schule macht und auch die anderen Klassiker, wie Indiana Jones 4 oder The Dig eine Remastered Version erhalten. Ich würde jedenfalls sofort zuschlagen...

37494145.review:
Day of the Tentacle habe ich vor vielen Jahren; das müsste etwa 1995 gewesen sein, mit und bei meinen Freunden in der Nachbarschaft als 12 jähriger Jüngling zum ersten mal spielen dürfen. Bereits den Vorgänger Maniac Mansion habe ich gespielt,  allerdings nicht annähernd so intensiv und bewusst wahrgenommen, wie seinen Nachfolger.
Für mich ist DOTT daher der absolute Inbegriff des Point and Click Genres. 
Damals wie Heute bin ich vor allem von der witzigen, verrückt-verdrehten und raffinierten Storyline sowie den liebevollen handgezeichneten Grafiken begeistert. 
Die Kombination aus abswechslungsreicher Story, schönen Grafiken, witzigen Dialogen und einem herausforderndem Schwierigkeitsgrad machen es zu einem ganz besonderen Spiel.
Was aktuelle Point and Click Games angeht, bin ich nicht mehr up to Date, allerdings würde ich dennoch pauschal behaupten, dass sich die DOTT-Remastered Edition heutzutage nicht zu verstecken braucht.
Die Grafik kann auf den OldSql Look umgestellt werden, was alle Nostalgiker, die es damals schon gezockt haben, analog zum Spiel auf eine Zeitreise der ganz besonderen Art schicken dürfte.
Die neuen Grafiken sind allerdings sehr gut gelungen, kaum verändert und treffen den Charme der damiligen Zeit perfekt.
Zum Inhalt selbst möchte ich garkeine großartigen Worte verlieren.  
Man muss sich einfach selbst auf diese Zeitreise begeben! 

Ganz klare Kaufempfehlung für Jung und Alt. Für Rückkehrer und Neueinsteiger!

37200476.review:
"Mutierte Tentakel wollen die Weltherrschaft übernehmen und durch eine Zeitreise soll dies verhindert werden. Allerdings schägt der Versuch fehl und so landen zwei der drei Hauptprotagonisten 200 Jahre Vergangenheit bzw. 200 Jahre in der Zukunft. Somit sind sie darauf angewiesen sich durch Austausch diverser Untensilien, die sie durch ihre Zeitreise-Toiletten in die verschieden Epochen schicken können bzw. durch Beeinflussung ihres Umfeldes und Ausnutzen der vierten Dimension gegenseitig zu helfen und die mutierten Tentakel aufzuhalten!"

Day of the Tentacle Remastered schafft es nicht nur, das Original mit seinem Charme und Witz unverfälscht aber dezent aufpoliert in das 21. Jahrhundert zu befördern, sondern vielmehr auch jenen, die das Spiel im Original nicht gespielt haben, den Eindruck eines modernen und lustigen Adventures zu vermitteln. Mit seiner überarbeiteten comicartigen Optik und dem zeitlosen Humor, weiß das Spiel voll zu überzeugen. Gerade zum Angebotspreis sollte sich kein Point & Click - Fan diese Perle entgehen lassen. Ein erster Spieldurchgang dauert geschätzt ca. 4 - 6 Stunden, aber wer das Spiel bereits kennt, wird eher 2 - 3 Stunden für einen Spieldurchgang benötigen. Allerdings können sich Errungenschaften-Sammler ohne Komplettlösung auf einige Stunden mehr einstellen. Das Spiel ist äußerst linear, aber ein gewisser Wiederspielwert ist den Errungenschaften, der tollen Optik und dem interessanten, wenn auch nicht allzu realistischen Zeitreise-Setting zu verdanken.

37177795.review:
Day of the Tentacle Special Edition is a classic point and click adventure game originally created by Tim Schaefer for Lucas Arts. It is an enhanced version of the original game that sees completely redrawn graphics that replace the originals.

Pros:
The game has a cartoon art style as well as animation that is meticulously detailed without taking shortcuts like reusing frames when a unique one would work better. The game also plays like a cartoon as well, with the same silliness and gags that you would expect from a classic episode of Loony Tunes.
The major unique gameplay mechanic in DOTT is time travel, which lends much more depth to puzzles. Instead of dealing with one linear feeling storyline, there are 3 different time periods that interact with each other making for more unique gameplay and allows you to attempt many different puzzles in parallel which can interact with each other through the passing of time.
DOTT's puzzles are a bit more out there than your typical adventure game flair, but while they'll leave you scratching your head, when you solve them, you wont just feel accomplished, but it will also be hilarious.

Completely new re-drawn graphics:
In order to update the game for modern hardware, the graphics have been entirely re-drawn from scratch for HD displays. This makes for a much improved experience in the graphical department that sees a classic improved for modern use. Luckily the new graphics still exude the excellence of the original, meaning there is no loss of quality or feeling of the game.

Cons:
There is no in-game hint system to help them when they run into the few unintuitive puzzles, meaning the player will either have to tough it out, or consult an online guide. Both of which can be immersion breaking and disrupts the flow of enjoyment of the game.


Most of the puzzles in the game make sense, with item combinations that one can usually think about coming to a useful conclusion. But some of the puzzles take this a step too far and are not as logical in their conclusions, this can be frustrating for the player and may turn some people off of the game.

37106958.review:
[h1]Back to the day of adventure gaming[/h1]

[b]If you are an old gamer:[/b] This remake will take you back to the days of SCUMM. The days of two floppys and no hd computers where you used one floppy for DOS and one floppy for Maniac Mansion or Monkey Island.

[b]If you are a young gamer:[/b] You will experience a good old classic adventure game on a modern system and you will have a lot of fun.

[b]What does this game have to offer:[/b]

[list]
  [*] Entertaining story
  [*] Good humor (nothing your kids can't see, rated Teen for a few references but compared to today's TV this is super safe)
  [*] Great animations, cartoonish style. It was awesome back in the day!
  [*] The ability to switch between modern graphics and classic pixel graphics
  [*] Good voice acting & sounds
  [*] Classic point & click adventure
[/list]

If you are a fan of adventure games or want to see what all the hype was about back in the 90's then get Day of the Tentacle!

36636621.review: Oh goodness. What a fantastic game. I played Maniac Mansion a long time ago on the NES. It was a brutally difficult but fun adventure game, I remember replaying it over and over again trying to find out what I missed. Adventure games back then had such odd solutions for puzzles that often you couldn't think it through and instead you had to try every single possible combination on everything. Day of the Tentacle, the sequel to Maniac Mansion, is no different. It is difficult but thoroughly entertaining. The game has aged well when playing even the old version. The new HD version offered with the remastered version doesn't just boast smoother and sharper graphics, but also an improved soundtrack and developer commentary. It has a wonderfully ridiculous story, interesting characters and top notch voice overs. It is quite difficult so before giving up on certain parts within the game I recommend looking up solutions online because some of them are so obscure you probably wouldn't be able to figure them out on your own. If you are a fan of adventure games or maybe used to be and are considering giving them a try again, Day of the Tentacle is a must buy.

36611914.review:
Bernard rossz hírt kap: az első részben megismert fura csáplények egyike tudatára ébredt, és meg akarja hódítani a világot. Felkerekedik hát 2 társával, hogy megakadályozza a szörny tudatára ébredését, azáltal, hogy visszamennek a múltba. Az időgép azonban véletlen elromlik, és a három lakótárs három időzónába kerül.

Körülbelül 7x toltam ki a játékot az idők során, most először HD-ban. Ez egy olyan kis gyémánt a játéktörténelemből, amihez talán alap angoltudás, egyetemes történelem, logika, és humorérzék szükségeltetik. Emiatt tehát ajánlom is meg nem is. A játék igyekszik vizuálisan kisegíteni a játékost, még akkor is ha nem nagyon ért dolgokat. Legyen ez a kifejező arc, vagy a jól elkülöníthető sziluettek sorozata. Mindig válaszolhatunk marhaságot, de soha nincs visszacsinálhatatlan végeredmény. Előről kezdhető a beszélgetés. Miután a beszélgetés és kipuhatolózás a játék fő eleme, ezért ez fontos is nyílván.

Node mit tud a hd, és érdemes e nekimenni a soundfontos scummvm emulátor után:
- A rövid válasz az, hogy nem feltétlenül. Immáron meg van minden rajzolva kézzel, amin sokan joggal kételkedtek. hiszen egészen hasonlít a fent említett emulátor 3xos hq textúra filteres megoldásához. Valószínűsítem, hogy közrejátszatott, de nagyon sok esetben jól kihasználja a játék a szélevásznú képet, és látszik, hogy az eredeti hosszú rajzokat vették alapul.
- A hangok és a zene valamilyen szinten rendhagyó, amit sajnálok. Az intróban levő kugli hang már akkor sem illett a játékba, és most sem illik. Egyes hangok teljesen marhasággá lettek kicserélve. Maga a zene tűrhető, de hallottam már sokkal jobb soundfontot is, és a lucas által készített Monkey Island remakeben helyet kapott zeneátváltás itt pl nem került alkalmazásra. így amikor új szobába kerülsz átvezetés nélkül hirtelen új zenét kapsz.
- A dialógusok ki lettek tisztítva, és normális minőségben halljuk a beszédeket. Nagy plusz!
- A hd kapott még egy új felületet, ami viszont piszkosul jó lett, Igényes, célratörő, és nem foglalja el a fél képet mint a régi UI. Immáron láthatóak az interaktív elemek a képen, nem kell minden pixelt végigkattintani a képen.

Végeredményben jó lett a hd remake. 8/10 rágható műanyag egér.

http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=1204988809

36469164.review:
Cette version de "Day Of The Tentacle" (DOTT) est un remaster du jeu sorti originalement sur PC en 1993 qui lui-même est la suite du jeu "Maniac Mansion" sorti en 1988 (!). On y retrouve le personnage de Bernard qui, accompagné par deux amis Hoogie et Laverne, devra sauver l'humanité de l'emprise des tentacules, le tout dans un monde aux graphismes cartoonesques. 
L'humour et les anachronismes sont omniprésents dans cette aventure qui se déroule simultanément dans trois périodes temporelles : le présent, le passé colonial et un futur dystopique. On y rencontrera au passage toutes sortes de personnages : des archétypes excentriques, des tentacules anthropomorphiques et même des personnages historiques effrontés.
Le gameplay et les graphismes (lissés) ont été modifiés de manière à davantage coller aux standards actuels mais il est toujours possible de passer en mode "original" et de jouer au jeu comme il y a 25 ans. 
La difficulté est sans doute moins relevée que dans son prédécesseur mais on passe tout de même un très bon moment. Comptez environ 5h pour terminer le jeu en ligne droite mais largement plus si vous vous attardez sur tous les dialogues et les références cachées ici ou là (mon temps de jeu est bien inférieur car j'avais déjà terminé le jeu sur iOS).
Quelques petits bugs sont parfois présents (notamment des décalages entre les sous-titres et le son/les animations) mais ces rares inconvénients ne doivent pas vous empêcher de foncer sur ce grand classique du jeu vidéo.

36343250.review: A point-n-click puzzle classic. 36312981.review:
When you think about classic adventure games, you simply can't forget this title. I can still remember the first time I've played, where you still had to use that code card to avoid piracy. Well, not only that. Since back in the day there wasn't internet available, whenever you'd get stuck in a certain part of the game, you had two options: Find a magazine with some hints, or find a friend that could help you out. 

Ok, things changed, now everything is so much easier and it was really refreshing to play that game again. I was really surprised to find out that I remembered how to solve almost every puzzle in the game (only got stuck in a couple of parts). The story is cool, the characters are really funny, the music and sound effects are great too. The graphics are still pretty much the same, and I don't think that it's a bad thing at all. 

Yeah, since the original game is so old, there's no better way to describe it than with memories and nostalgia. Either way, I still think that new players who are into the adventure genre can have a lot of fun while playing it.

36228547.review:
A very cute adventure game. I never played the original, so I was coming into this with no expectations or nostalgia. I would say that it stands up well to modern adventure game design, and the few rough spots it has are more than made up for by the very unusual characters and amusing dialog.

Rough spots: The animations and dialog can be a bit tediously slow. I don't know if this is an intentional nod to the source material, but I found it a little annoying to wait for tentacles to jump across the screen just so that dialog could continue.

Some of the solutions were pretty out there. But they were at least able to make fun of themselves for it ("You Call That A Hint" achievement). But some of the solutions involved more "try everything in my inventory on every possible target" attempts than I would normally like.

Cool spots: As stated, the characters are very interesting and amusing. But it also uses a very clever "three-state" configuration for most puzzles in the game, where you have to interact with the puzzle from the perspective of each of your three characters in order to solve it. Those were quite fun to play. Also, their game-within-the-game was surprisingly well done.

36197829.review:
[b]My rating:[/b] 9/10
Based on: one full playthrough

[b]Full disclosure:[/b] I played and enjoyed the MS-DOS original around the turn of the century on my first home PC along with its predecessor embedded inside, Maniac Mansion, which I previously played on my Commodore 64 a decade or so back.

[b]Pros:[/b]

(+) nutty storyline involving 3 playable characters (clever but awkward nerd Bernard, lazy but wise-cracking roadie fatso Hoagie and loopy but sassy Laverne) stranded in 3 distinct time periods (the present, the colonial past and the dystopian future) trying to stop a purple tentacle monster hell bent on world domination
(+) a varied cast of supporting characters including quirky archetypes, cheeky historical figures and anthropomorphic tentacles
(+) unique time travel, inventory sharing and character switching mechanics involving high-end, state-of-the-art porta-potties
(+) freedom to explore the interconnected time periods (worlds)
(+) the wickedly irreverent and hilarious writing by the supreme LucasArts trio of Dave Grossman, Tim Schafer and Gary Winnick, ranging from potty jokes and clever easter eggs to high-brow references, delivered through the remastered, deliberately cartoonish voice acting
(+) wacky, often slapstick humour and animations reminiscent of classic cartoons with the original hand-drawn art style by the masters Peter Chan and Larry Ahern redone completely, but respectfully and beautifully in high resolution and with full widescreen support
(+) the properly goofy SFX and music are a blast from the past, but hold up splendidly, especially remastered
(+) the classic point-and-click controls improved by substituting the original unintuitive SCUMM command syntax with a streamlined radial selection menu
(+) logically sound puzzles with only a few verging on the absurd, their solving aided a bit by some easily missable hints hidden in cutscenes, conversations and throw-away lines
(+) you can switch back and forth between the original and the remaster at the press of a button
(+) the first Maniac Mansion is still playable in-game, a feature unheard-of in 1993, but imitated many times since
(+) newly introduced Steam achievements make for thorough exploration and manic experimentation
(+) vast concept art gallery and extensive developers’ commentary by Schafer, Grossman, Chan and Ahern, along with the composers Peter McConnell and Clint Bajakian
(+) perfectly playable with a mouse and keyboard, but analogue controllers are also supported
(+) expanded language options: English, French, Italian, German and Spanish interface and subtitles options, but only English and German audio
(+) another fine and masterful remaster from Double Fine overall worth paying through the suction cup for (all puns intended)

[b]Cons:[/b]

(−) developers’ commentary sometimes plays on top of the on-screen dialogue, which makes it confusing to hear
(−) infrequent, but annoying stops in character dialogue delivery while waiting for the subtitles to catch up
(−) some background dithering and low-framerate animations are more noticeable on a modern widescreen monitor
(−) occasional textual mistakes in developers' commentary subtitles (not enough proof-reading?)
(−) the first Manic Mansion playable in-game has not been remastered, only updated with a new menu, including a save/load/resume feature
(−) minimal hand holding (some easily missable hints can be gleaned from cutscenes or conversations, but there’s no journal nor check-lists to remind you)
(−) some of the more complex and multi-step puzzles may throw you for a (time) loop
(−) not nearly enough tentacles for hentai enthusiasts ;-)

36128420.review: Point and click adventure games used to be the kings of the PC Gaming mountain, and this game shows exactly why. Don't expect any white-knuckle action or tense moments--this game is for those who love lateral thinking and quirky story telling.  If you've never experienced it, now is the time. It's the best paced Lucas Arts adventure game and its puzzles never get so obtuse as to need a guide. And it's funny.

36127207.review:
Another LucasArts classic point-and-click adventure, and a good one, to say the least! If you are a fan of LucasArts games, you need no reviews for this one, but if you find this game on a sale or Steam recommends it to you, here are a few things worth noting before you try it and rate it negatively.

1. Humorous point-and-click adventures from LucasArts are known for their quite silly logic in terms of combining items and using them on the environment. Often you have to think very out of the box to progress further. Or just force your way by trying each and every item in the inventory on eveything until it works. This gets a lot easier the more you play such games, but be warned.

2. LucasArts adventures often have quite a lot of puns to real world events and phenomenae, and also many hidden references to their previous products, like Monkey Island series or Grim Fandango. So many in-game jokes might not be funny for you at all.

3. The general way LucasArts point-and-click adventures are built is that at the beginning of the game you have a task that seems to be quite easy to complete, but the whole game consists of an enormous amount of silly obstacles preventing you from completing that task. Say, at the beginning of the game you might just need to cut a rope, but you won't be able to find or craft anything that is able to cut the rope until the very end of the game. Which makes most of the fun, of course.

Hope this helps you to judge this great game honestly, and I really enjoy you would have as much fun while completing it as I did.

I played the original. I had a rush of nostalgia. Then I pressed F1, which - in real time - switches from the modern look to the original 4:3 640x480 look with countable pixels. My memory of the game's original look should have never come back. 

The point and click adventure is one of the best of its genre. That means three things:
- It looks great with its humor fitting toonish visuals.
- It has a funny and very strange story, that is compelling to follow through. It has timetravel and mutations!
- Most importantly, it has rather logical puzzles or well implemented hints through "meanwhile"-cutscenes or commentaries on different things with few exceptions. That means depending on your awareness you probably don't need a walkthrough.

Play it, it is rightfully a classic! 

Follow my curator at http://store.steampowered.com/curator/28337205-Fair-Minded-Witness/?appid=680310

PS: George Washington and Harold the Pet have the same face. Noticed?

36007630.review:
Ein gutes Spiel aber warum trotzdem einen Daumen nach unten?

Ich besitze das Originalspiel, welches unter SCUMM auch heute noch einwandfrei funktioniert, wenn ich also 15€ in ein Remake investiere muss es sich folglich auch lohnen, leider hat es sich für mich nicht gelohnt ;(
1. Die Story des Spiels ist identisch mit dem Original, alle Konservationen sind identisch, also rechtfertigt die Story alleine nicht den Kauf des Remakes.
2. Die Grafik wurde klar verbessert, sieht zwar ab und zu so aus als wurde einfach der 4xBR-Filter angewendet aber dennoch eine Bereicherung für das Spiel.
3. Musik und Soundeffekte wurdem angeblich verbessert aber neue Sounds und Musikstücke wurden nicht implementiert. Eine große Änderung erfuhr die Tonspur: Hier haben ein paar Laien sehr unprofessionell ihre Stimmen den einzelnen Protagonisten geliehen, dabei haben durchaus auch einzelne Sprecher mehrere Charaktere synchronisiert. Alle Stimmen kommen irgendwie unmotiviert und lustlos rüber.

Für mich sieht das Spiel so aus, als hätten es ein paar Hobbyprogrammierer in ihrere Freizeit erstellt. Daran ist natürlich nichts verwerfliches und ich ziehe meinen Hut für dieses Engagement aber ein Preis jenseits der 5€ halte ich für dieses Spiel, deren Programmierer den größten Teil, also die Stroy, einfach kopiert haben, für überteuert.

36006729.review:
If you like Point and Click adventure games then this is a great one to play, even if you haven't played a Point and Click before then this is a great game to start with.

 • The cartoony visuals are great, if you prefer playing it in the original pixaly visuals then that's an option as well.
 • The characters are lovable, they certainly won't bore you with their oblivious minds and goofy antics.
 • The story isn't too long, but it isn't too short either. If you know exactly what you gotta do then you can beat this game in less than an hour.
 • You can get every achievement in a single run, considering if you know what you gotta do.
 • There were some times playing this game where I got stumped and had to use a guide, the game is simple but it does have it's moments where you're like "Ah! There we go!"

It's one of the more lasting Point and Clicks out there, but if you played it once there isn't really a reason to go back other than cleaning up some achievements or nostalgia.
7/10 -  Good game for your first Point and Click that isn't TellTale.

I was really impressed by Day of the Tentacle. Typically I usually find point and click adventure games to have obtuse puzzles   which halt progress, and I was able to complete this game on my own without any outside help. 

There are a ton of puzzles in this game but they seem smaller, more modualr. There was never a point where I couldnt do   something else if I couldnt figure out what I was doing wrong. Alo there are a ton of items so if you get stuck you can try new combinations or talk to non player charecters for possible hints through conversation. 

Which isnt to say there arent frusterating parts. The game still uses cartoon logic and some things might not make sense right away. But through taking breaks and trying new things I was able to finish the game and that contrubited to my enjoyment of it. 

Also the game Maniac Mansion is available inside Day of the Tentacle as an Easter Egg. I played that game a long time ago on NES and while it hasnt aged as well it is a really nice touch for a trip down memory lane. I recommend this game if you are a fan of the genre or as a jumping on point if you havent played a point and click adventure game before.

35794760.review: A fun game with humor from another time. Knocked out the game over a weekend with a little help from a walkthrough when frustration started in, but mostly the puzzles and story kept me happy throughout.

35645198.review:
1. I do not share the halcyon memories of playing these old adventure games w/ many in my peer group. I played them, yes. I had fun for sure but they do not exactly reach the highest heights of refined gameplay. Once I got done microwaving the hamster or telling the text parser to go fuck itself, I always just got frustrated at the trial and error halfway through and either cheated or quit.


2. I still do that.


3. For what it's worth, if you do have halcyon memories of playing these games, this remastered version of The Day of the Tentacle really gets it right. They smooth out the pixelated graphics and bring in brighter, more vibrant colors. They updated the compressed, cruddy sounding audio w/ a clearer, modern sound. There's controller support. That's it. It is still the same game just presented w/ a bit more polish.


4. I can see how someone might find the humor in this game charming but I don't believe anyone who says they think it is actually funny. I smiled a few times but never laughed.


5. The setup here is a tentacle drinks a bunch of toxic waste and takes over the world. A mad scientists recruits a stoner, a nerd and a ditz to travel through time and fix things. This is could maybe be the plot of a straight-to-VHS movie full of post-rehab 80s brat packers. Like I said, this game is not actually funny.


6. The way this game works is you solve puzzles by clicking on things until it's time to stop clicking on things.


7. I'm not going to say there aren't some clever puzzles here but I'm also not gonna say you don't  have to sometimes just do some random-ass bullshit to figure stuff out. Or use a walkthrough. This game is a quarter century old, you won't be the first person who cheated.


8. The voice acting was done in 1993. God help us.


9. One actor who does a bad impression of Woody Allen and uses it to voice both some random nerdy guy and John Hancock. I will admit, that was one of the things I smiled at in the game. Of course, I did not laugh because this game is not actually funny.


10. Early on, your characters get split up between three time periods. You can easily send items to other time periods using a time traveling porta-john. You can also leave things some place in the past and have them be there in the future, normally changed to some degree. This turns the whole game into one giant puzzle made of sub-puzzles you need to puzzle through.


11. While number 10, sounds good on the surface, the execution of this idea is problematical. For starters, some items are available way out of context and way before you need them. Combine this w/ some of the goofy, not-actually-funny puzzle solutions and you wind up w/ a lot of Day of the Tentacle being needlessly obtuse and frustrating. This being said, this frustration is at least tempered by the fact that you can not put yourself in a situation where you cannot finish the game. Believe it or not, in some of these old adventure games, you could get yourself in a failure state where you couldn't win and the game didn't even have the courtesy to tell you that.


12. This is the golden age of this type of game in some people's minds. I don't get it.


13. So yeah, at its heart, at this point in time, this is really a nostalgia trip or a history lesson depending how old you are or how much attention you were paying in the nineties. If you are after either of things, absolutely, you should play Day of the Tentacle. If you are looking for the most fun way to spend a few hours of your time, don't play a decades old adventure game.

35575964.review: A ce jour, le meilleur Point 'n' Click rétro auquel j'ai joué. Un humour bien ficelé, des énigmes super bien pensées et ce, sur trois time-lines différentes. Franchement... y'a rien à redire. Ce jeu mérite clairement son titre de classique !

35549139.review:
Day of the Tentacle, das ist Point-and-Click-Klamauk vom Feinsten. Aus den Tiefen der Neunziger hat Double Fine Productions eines der großartigsten Adventures dieser Zeit gekramt und dem ganzen einen aktuellen Anstrich verpasst. Dazu noch eine etwas komfortablere Steuerung und fertig ist die Remastered Edition. 

Das Spiel: 

Day of the Tentacle ist ein ganz klassisches P&C-Abenteuer. Man steuert per Maus die Charaktere Bernhard, Hoagie und Laverne. Knifflig dabei vor allem, dass man die drei simultan steuern kann und muss. Dabei müssen teilweise auch Gegenstände untereinander ausgetauscht werden, was am Anfang nicht gleich gänzlich offensichtlich ist.
Aber zurück zum eigentlichen Thema... 
Worum geht es eigentlich?
Schnell erzählt ist folgendes passiert:
Purpur Tentakel hat von Doktor Freds (verrückter Wissenschaftler) Matschmaschine kontaminiertes Wasser getrunken, hat dadurch zwei Arme bekommen sowie Allmachts-/Weltherrschaftsfantasien. Um ihn aufzuhalten, wollen der Nerd Bernhard, der übergewichtige Hardrocker Hoagie und die selbstzerstörerische Lavern mit Doktor Freds Hilfe und dem Chrono-Jon in die Vergangenheit reisen, um das zu verhindern. Weil Doktor Fred allerdings einen billigen Industriediamanten für seine Maschine verwendet hat, geht der Plan gehörig schief. Bernhard bleibt in der Gegenwart, Hoagie reist versehentlich 200 Jahre in der Zeit zurück zu den amerikanischen Gründungsvätern und Ben Franklin, während Lavern 200 Jahre in die Zukunft verfrachtet wird, in der die Tentakel die Welt beherrschen und Menschen als Haustiere halten. Und diesen Schlamassel muss man als Spieler nun wieder gerade rücken.

Klingt ganz schön verrückt? 
Genau das ist es. Neben derben Witzen und lustigen Lösungswegen ist das Spiel ein abgedreht verrücktes Abenteuer, das riesigen Spaß macht. Durch die erneuerte Steuerung geht vieles außerdem schneller von der Hand als im Original. Für Leute, die das Originial gespielt haben, sind als kleiner Zusatz zahlreiche versteckte Steamerrungenschaften integriert, die es freizuschalten gilt. Um die 100% zu erreichen ist schon einiges Ausprobieren notwendig.
Die Rätsel sind durchaus knifflig und aufgrund der drei verschiedenen Erzählstränge, die aber paralell gespielt werden können, nicht immer gleich zu durchschauen. Frust kommt dennoch selten auf, denn für annähernd jeden "bescheuerten" Lösungsversuch, wird man mit einem kruden Kommentar oder Aktion der Charaktere "belohnt". So macht selbst das planlose Klicken und herumkombinieren irgendwie Spaß. 

Sound und Videoqualität sind deutlich aufgehübscht und angepasst, wobei das eigentlich auch reine Kosmetik ist, die das Spiel eigentlich nicht brauchte. Es ist  einfach ein Point and Click Adventure, das durch seinen verrückten Ansatz und die durchgeknallte Story lebt und genau dort seine Stärken hat. 

Insgesamt?

Ich bin dennoch froh gewesen, dass es noch einmal aus den Tiefen der Vergangenheit gebuddelt und entstaubt wurde. Denn auf diese Weise bin ich nach etlichen Jahren ein zweites Mal in den Genuss eines absolut lustigen, abwechslungsreichen Klassikers gekommen. Die Spielzeit war zwar aufgrund der Vorerfahrung wesentlich kürzer, aber es hat einfach Spaß gemacht und darauf kommt es doch am Ende hauptsächlich an.
Darum gebe ich auch guten Gewissens eine Empfehlung für diesen aufgehübschten Genre-Klassiker.

If you look at the positive reviews for this game, you'll see a LOT of them reference the fact that they played this game when it first came out.  I'm not saying that nobody trying this out in the modern day will like it, but I am saying that most will probably not.  I think there is a serious case of nostalgia-goggles here.

I went into this game not knowing much about it.  I just knew that it's considered one of the great classic point-and-clicks, and I've enjoyed quite a few P&C so thought I should try it.

What I found was a heap of terrible voice acting, writing that didn't come together into anything coherent, and humor that would probably fall flat for anyone over the age of eight.  Things like "haha, that nerd's pants are pulled up too high" and "haha, that guy tripped and fell!"

If this game were new today, it would be ripped to shreds by any critics, and then promptly forgotten.

35412663.review:
7.9/10

Double Fine has a good reputation for creating fun games with lots of laughs and good dialogue. Day of the Tentacle is no exception.

Losely following Maniac Mansion, this game let's you explore the vast mansion of Dr. Fred again, but this time in multiple time-periods to prevent an evil tentacle from enslaving the entire world. You do this by controlling 3 teenagers with their own personalities and quirks, spending most of your time solving puzzles or interacting with the goody characters. If you have played the Monkey Island games or Grim Fandango you shold feel right at home especially with this remaster.

What's so good about this game is that most of the time the only thing controling the pacing is you, the player. If you get stuck it's often solved by talking or interacting with most of your environment and you should be able to figure out the way to progress forward. And exploring is fun, often rewarding with great dialogue and a couple of jokes.

Also worth mentioning that the entire first game, Maniac Mansion, is fully playable within this game! Two great games for the price of one!

If you like fun point and click-adventures, give this game a buy!

35367836.review: A must play for any video game fan. I would recommend looking up a walkthrough however as it would take a frustrating amount of time to complete it otherwise.

35190727.review:
This is one of the classic point and click adventures from back in the day. For anyone who has some nostalgia for the game, then this game is a no brainer. It has been lovingly remastered. They have updated the user interface as well as the graphics. It is intuitive and easy to play, unlike the original Maniac Mansion game which is included and can be played inside this game. It certainly made me appreciate the new user interface.  And made me wonder how I ever played the original Maniac Mansion game without going mad! 

The game is wacky and fun and has some great writing in it. If you don't cheat and look up the solutions, then it will take you some time. It is always best to sleep on some of the puzzles. And the writing is so good that you want to try every dialogue option anyway, just to hear all the jokes. There was only a couple of places where I was really stumped more by the user interface than by the puzzle itself. One time I didn't get the dialogue I needed and another time Bernard would not use an item. But quitting the game and trying again later I solved the puzzle straight away even though in my head I was trying the exact same thing. The game only bugged out once, which is good for a double fine game. The game would let me move my character but I could not interact with any objects or other characters. I could not even get to the menu to quit the game. 

If you have never played the game, and want to try a point a click adventure, then this is a good fun choice. It looks and sounds good, the user interface is intuitive. The remastering makes it feel pretty modern, I only hit those 2 puzzles that felt clunky and frustrating, and unlike most of the original point and click games, there are no totally impossible, totally stupid puzzles/solutions. You are NOT forced to click every object on every other object in every location like some games.

35150967.review:
¿Como podria describirse este juego?

Yo siempre lo he calificado como una obra maestra, en el momento cumbre de las aventuras gráficas, es cierto que no es excesivamente largo, pero si lo suficientemente complejo para tenerte entretenido númerosas horas. La aventura tiene un gran arte el cual se ha mejorado sustancialmente con esta remasterización.

A diferencia de las remasterizaciones de monkey island 1 y 2, las cuales tenian un control pesimo, un arte no acorde y encima el modo "antiguo" no estaba ni traducido, está es todo lo contrario. Lo primero la remasterización es el mismo juego pero con los gráficos acordes a día de hoy (el pixelado de las animaciones ya no se ve, si no que es dibujo del bueno), Lo segundo, el control no ha empeorado y es totalmente digno de una aventura gráfica y lo tercero si pones el modo antiguo sigues teniendo el juego en Español.

¿Hay alguna cosa mala?

Bien aparte de que el juego solo esta traducido y no doblado, el juego incluye una aventura de maniac mansión (el primer juego de la saga) el cual se activa ejecutando el pc. Esta aventura gráfica extra la cual es muy buena (aunque muy dificil, pero tiene varios caminos para realizarla), tiene el problema de que no se ha traducido, (es decir esta en ingles) y tampoco ha recibido remasterización. Hubiese estado bien que al menos hubiese estado traducida.

Recomendablep ara todos aquellos que amen este tipo de juegos. No defraudará.

This is a great point and click adventure game. It's got all thats needed:

+ Good voice acting and dialogue

I remember playing the original Maniac Mansion on a friend's Commodore64... entire afternoons trying to figure out how or where to go next, how to unravel the puzzles the game presented, the sense of awe when we bumped into the Mansion's inhabitants... Really endearing memories from my gaming life.  Then came DOTT, which was an entire new experience in itself because of the improvements over graphical design and the music we could enjoy by then because of the sound cards availability.  Much later it became possible to revisit the game using the ScummVM emulator.
Soon as I saw this game for sale I knew It was a perfect opportunity to replay this classic masterpiece.  The version comes with improved graphics while respecting the original art style. There is the possibility to switch to the original version on-the-fly.  The soundtrack has also been remastered and can be chosen over the originals as well.  The SCUMM style verbal controls have been replaced with a wheel icon controller type, much in the style of tha later LucasArts titles.
There are even a number of steam achievement to add value to that replay, and even pushes you to experience situiations you might have missed while playing the game back in the days.
This is a must even if you didn't play the originals.

34496872.review:
Day of the Tentacle is the sequel to the acclaimed Maniac Mansion. At first you might be saying "Why play the sequel, if I haven't played the original?", well the game Maniac Mansion is playable within the gameplay of the sequel. Once you are able to control Bernard freely in the mansion to go to the third floor, and enter the room on the right and access the computer where you will immediately be able to play and save Maniac Mansion in its' entirety. If you want to know the whole back story to the prior events of Day of the Tentacle then this is a nessacary side quest to focus on. So let's first talk about Maniac Mansion before talking about the sequel. Maniac Mansion was an adventure game from LucasArts, the plot consists of a meteor crash landing next to the mansion owned by the macabre Edison family(no relation to Thomas Edison). The head of the household Dr. Fred Edison came into contact with the meteor and tried to examine it for scientific purposes. The meteor was not your average shooting star as it has hypnotic powers that put Dr. Fred into a trance and now has the urge to take over the world. 20 years later, Dr. Fred kidnapped a college girl named Sandy as a means to conduct his experiment in taking over the world. Sandy's boyfriend Dave Miller tracks down his girlfriend's whereabouts at the Edison Mansion with two friends of his for back-up knowing his girlfriend was abducted by a mad man and that the rescue attempt will be dangerous. The mansion itself is a big place to cover ground there are many locked rooms and the presence of the Edison family members and their pets which are two large disembodied tentacles. With various items to obtain and many secret passage ways and rooms to discover, Dave will most likely succeed in saving Sandy and try to put an end to the master plan of hypnotised Dr. Fred. 
Maniac Mansion was an innovating adventure game for its time as it was the first game to utilize in the SCUMM game engine. A type of game engine that would be used in the much of the later LucasArts games, where the command options consist of give, use, talk, push, etc. Directed by Ron Gilbert who would go on to creating the Monkey Island games and additional staff work done by Tim Schaffer who was just starting in the computer game business at the time this game went into production. The game took two years to make and drew heavy inspiration from B movies and horror genre films for the basis of the story. This was a game that requires trial and error, as anyone playing it for the first time might mess up at first but will get better as you play it. There are multiple endings to the game, and with a selection of a few different characters to help out Dave, its a mix and match option that offers plenty of possibilities. Since the sequel features Bernard, it's recommended to have Bernard in the party to create continuity. The game was cool for offering more than other adventure games had at the time of its release. 
Now to finally talk about the sequel, Day of the Tentacle. The game is set five years after the events of the original game. The game starts off with one of the pet tentacles own by the Edisons(In this case the Purple Tentacle) drinks sludge that's been polluting the river by the Edison Mansion. Purple Tentacle began to grow small flapper arms, intelligence, and the urge to dominate the world. Dr. Fred tries to rid of this problem by killing both of the tentacles so that way the world will be sparred from deranged tentacles. Green Tentacle sends a plea for help via mail to his friend Bernard, knowing he will save him and his purple brother. Bernard receives the letter from his green friend and agrees with himself that he must comply to the plea of help. But that also means he must return to the mansion, a place he'd hope he would never have to revisit again. So after recruiting his roommates Laverne the crazed medical student and Hoagie the roadie travel to the mansion to set the tentacles free. They made things worse as Purple Tentacle escapes to continue his conquest. Because Purple Tentacle is smarter and quicker than an average human it would be impossible to foil his world domination plans. Which is why Dr. Fred cooks up a plan by sending Laverne, Bernard, & Hoagie back in time via three time traveling porta-potties to the day before Purple Tentacle drank the sludge to prevent the incident from ever happening in the first place. The plan goes abust when the fake diamond instead of a real one used for the power source breaks down the time machines. Bernard ends up where he last lifted off while Hoagie is stuck in the colonial times 200 years in the past and Laverne is stuck in the 22nd Century where tentacles have already taken over most of the planet. Bernard much help his friends by sending items through time to help his friends power up their own individual porta-potties in order to travel back to the past and stop Purple Tentacle once and for all. They must hurry as Purple Tentacle quickly rises in power as the game progresses. 
This sequel was better than the original game in contrast with the plot and gameplay. This time around you only play as three default characters with Bernard being the only protagnogist from Maniac Mansion to return. The gameplay is more linear meaning no matter what you do the out come remains the same. The art style was improved as it looked like an interactive cartoon on par with the earlier Humongous Games and the first Sam & Max game. It was one of the earliest LucasArts games to feature voice acting, something that wasn't too common for computers games to offer at the time. The game was Tim Schafer's first time directing along with Dave Grossman who later directed the second Bone game from Telltale and wrote for the the first two Monkey Island games. The characters were all great and the humor is right up there with the Monkey Island games. Anyone who loves the Monkey Island games will love the Maniac Mansion Duology games. These games played an important role for both adventure genre games and future LucasArts games a like.

34448879.review:
[h1]Summary[/h1]

The Day of the Tentacle is a point and click adventure game.

+ Interesting plot
+ Odd sense of humor
- Hard to figure out

[h1]Review[/h1]

The Day of the Tentacle is a point and click adventure game. In this game you control Bernard, Hoagie and Laverne to stop the Purple tentacle who is trying to take over the world.

In order to stop plans of world domination you will have to go back one day to the past but things don't go so well and each of your controllable characters get to different points in time: past, present and future. You can switch characters and you will have send items through time in order to beat the game.

The game has a odd but creative sense of humor that takes advantage of the different time lines. Interestingly the characters you find in the past have descendants of the future that somewhat preserve their personalities. Some characters are historical figures. The graphical style is wacky cartoon styled and fits the game plot.

The main issue with this game is that it is very hard to figure out what to do. The puzzles often don't really have much logic and sometimes lacks tips entirely so you may end up brute forcing by attempting every possible action or reading a walk-through. This is somewhat typical of these kinds of games but you will see what I mean if you try to beat the game.

The game also includes Maniac Mansion so it's actually two games in one. In fact Day of the Tentacle is considered to be Maniac Mansion 2.

I did enjoy the game for what it is even though the puzzles are very hard to figure out so I recommend it.

[b] Clásico atemporal  [/b]

Un trabajo de remasterización sobresaliente que si pudiera resumir en sus aspectos [u]positivos[/u] sería : 
 [list]

This game brings back so many great childhood memories. It may be basic compared with todays games but you can't beat a good point click puzzle classic.

Upon starting the game your immediately drawn into the story, it doesnt take long to understand what the plot is and what your goal is. The dialogue is smart and witty with various references....(mainly to star wars).
For those new to the game the puzzles can be a little tricky to solve and you may be left with very little guidance on which items are needed and where. However, a bit of common sense and sometimes a dark sense of humour is all thats needed to solve certain situations.

The remastered version is fantastic, with the ability to alternate from the classic/remastered appearance with the click of a button during gameplay. Interesting commentary adds to the history of how the game was developed for those interested. The artwork is what pulled me into the game originally and with the smoother graphics i've fallen in love with it all over again.

This game is great for old fans and new ones. This is definately a biased review with nostagic influence although I don't care, I'd recommend this to anyone who want's to kill some time.

33979391.review:
This game is a brilliant classic point and click game. Its also another great remaster from Double Fine who I thought also did a brilliant job with their Grim Fandango remaster.

Day of the Tentacle gives you control of 3 characters. One in the past, one in the present and one in the future. You can pass items between characters via the toilet in a portaloo time machine (dont ask). Other than that its pretty standard point and click gameplay but this game offers a lot of challenging puzzles to solve. I loved the humour and zany characters and ths is what makes it stand out.

The remaster has been masterfully done. The game has had all its animation redone and modernised as well as the sound and music. I hadn't played the original but you can switch to the original style with the press of a button and this really highlights the improvements. It's also possible to play the entirety of Maniac Mansion, the prequel of DotT, wihin the game.

There are a couple downsides. Some of the solutions are really out there and can be very difficult to figure out. Also very occasionaly I had problems with the sound where the music would randomly cut out though this would be fixed on moving to another room.

Overall this is a brilliant game and if your a fan of the point and click genre then this is worth picking up.

33945931.review:
Questo titolo, uscito negli anni 90, l'ho giocato da adolescente. Nel 2016 lo portano in una versione remastered e non potevo non prenderlo. Un divertentissimo gioco punta e clicca, come ci ha sempre abituati la LucasArts. Nei panni di un nerd, un metallaro ed una studentessa di medicina con la testa per aria, dovremo fermare i piani diabolici di tentacolo Viola, diventato cattivo a causa di certe scorie. La particolarità di questo titolo sta nel fatto che i nostri protagonisti saranno sbalzati in epoche diverse e dovranno, tra loro, interagire cambiando la storia e cercando di passarsi le cose utili attraverso le rispettive macchine del tempo (dei gabinetti). Un gioco adatto a tutte le età. La grafica è bella, in stile cartoon. Le musiche godibili. Gli enigmi non sempre facili, ma sicuramente divertenti. Forse, conoscendo la storia americana, si apprezzerebbe addirittura meglio questo titolo in quanto i riferimenti a personaggi storici è continua. Inoltre, fanno capolino diversi camei di altri personaggi di Lucas apparsi nelle varie avventure. Se vi piacciono le avventure grafiche in vecchio stile, vi consiglio questo gioco. E vi consiglio, ovviamente, tutti gli altri giochi della LucasArts.  
P. S. All'interno del gioco stesso, c'è un modo per giocare al titolo precedente della serie (completamente indipendente e slegato da questo, sia chiaro), Maniac Mansion. 

Voto personale: 8

33868641.review:
Very mixed feelings on whether or not to recommend that one. It's not really about what's in the game but more about whether or not you want updated graphics or not.

There are new features, like skipping dialogue and button press = highlighting of objects you can interact with, but other than that and the updated graphics it's still the same game as the classic.

You can toggle the in-game graphics between the new and the old design flawlessly at all times but then also lack some of the features tied to the new graphics and their engine. Art-wise the design is a flawless improvement of the classic.

Mentionable issues others had are crashes and freezes which I can't verify as I didn't have a single issue like that up to the point of completing the game. What issue I encountered was merely noticing that if you enable not just audio but also the display of the text spoken that there are most often mismatches or delay issues with the text.

So... if you just disable the text and leave the audio on that won't be an issue.
Size-wise this remake is rather large, compared to the slim, old classic, playable with ScummVM: 2.65 GB of the remake compared to ~140 MB of the classic.

Your choice whether or not and what you want to pay for better graphics and a few new features.

33753398.review:
Man what a blast from the past. We kids got it in ~1997 on a second-hand PC and spent weeks discovering every single clickable thing in the present-day mansion. I managed to recall quite a few tricks during this playthrough 20 years later. We used to always get stuck at a point where the game asked us to insert something from 'the manual'. I've always thought it was some kind of old school DRM. Was it actually? I found out online now that the feature was only in the 'non-talking' version and it was basically a combination lock with 4 * 4 * 2 * 2 * 2 * 2 = 256 possibilities (you had to mess around with croutons and stuff). I managed to accidentally crack it once during my childhood, but then lost the savegame : ( So you could say I had this game on hold for 2 decades.

DOTT is a classic not unlike the Monkey Island games. Great plot, writing and lots and lots of warm humour. The puzzles are quite tough and if I hadn't had my memories and I admit, 3 little peeks in the walkthrough, it would have probably taken me something like a day instead of 4 hours to complete.

The remastered version also features developers' commentary and Maniac Mansion as a game-within-a-game, but I didn't bother with those since the original game was largely unexplored territory for me and I didn't need any extra nostalgia to spice things up. But those may be really interesting for people who have DOTT memorized backwards.

They don't often make complex games any more. As I said, without cheating DOTT is a bit difficult to figure out and millennials will probably have trouble attention span wise. But if you're on a mission to play through, say, 100 essential video games, DOTT definitely has to be on that list.

33579736.review:
When I look at a remake of an old classic game, I always wonder 2 things. 1) How many of the positive reviews are pure nostalgia? And 2) How buggy is this remake?
Well, I had tons of fun playing this remake, and I had never played the old version, so it's not all nostalgia. And I experienced no bugs at all. 

The game's not perfect. Some of the puzzle solutions don't make much sense, so that can be frustrating. The setting is a little dated, and the characters are shallow dated stereotypes. But... 

It's a ton of fun. A very funny, quirky game. A lot of the puzzles are straightforward and fun to figure out. It's fun to figure out how to change the past to affect the future. The game in one word: Fun.

This game is a must have for people who like quirky humorous games, and classic 90s style point and click adventures.

33575922.review:
A remake must make the good aspects of the game better and eliminate problems with the game.  At the same time, it needs the authenticity of being the original game (in contrast to a reboot).

Dott remastered does improve on graphics.  It also improves on the adventure game "menu" (talk, look, take) by elimating its living place at the bottom of the screen to make the game full screen. 

What would have been nice is an improvement on some of the other things.  There were some awkward pauses in transitioning in and out of cut scenes that were kept.  It would have been nice to see mouths match the speech too, which makes itself more obvious than before with the sharper graphics.  It also would have been nice for some improvement on the backgrounds now that everything is not pixelated (at least beyond the Jar-Jar Binks photo (love it by-the-way!) hidden in the past.)  After playing Ducktales Remastered, Dott Remastered feels more like Dott "Updated."  And that is a good thing if you want to play a classic Lucas Arts game on your new machine.  

In conclusion, the title "remastered" is a bit of a misnomer, but breathing life into a classic adventure game is nice to see.

33391210.review:
Une version remasterisé d'assez bonne facture. Les musiques n'ont pas été "dénaturé". La nouvelle interface (au revoir la liste de verbes) peu surprendre et laisse sa place pour quelques chose de plus intiutif.. (pensé pour une manette PS4! -lol-).

Jeune c'était un de mes click and play préférés, résultat je l'ai fini extrémement vite, y compris avec l'ensemble des succés (qui ne demandent pas de faire des "choses absolument improbables" il faut le dire).. Comme quoi j'ai du y jouer bien plus que je m'en souvenais.
Moralité, il est clair que mon avis ne sera pas objéctif.
Je vais tout de même essayer de le diviser en deux temps.

Coté nostalgie, évidément le service est là.. On a une version remasterisé correcte, des nouveaux thèmes presque identique (qui crachent moins), le "swap" des tentacules qui saute à changé malheureusement...Mais on peu de toute manière jouer avec l'anciennes bande son, indépendament de anciens décors etc. C'est extrémement appréciable. Le fait de pouvoir changer la version d'une simple touche en temps réel, aussi.
De même, chose EXTREMEMENT appréciable pour tout Fans du jeu: les commentaires audios !

Cotés jeu du genre, d'une part on est là face à un des classique parmis les classiques, sans doute le plus réussi sous le moteur SCUMM (pour le jeu de mot: "ordure/pourriture").
L'humour très présent est une marque de fabrique de Lucasart. On peu dire que c'est tout de même assez réussis, et reste intemporel... (En fait il n'y qu'une seul blague qui devrait être "incompréhensible", une faisant référence à Helms qui est "vexxé" par la candidature de Pourpre*).
Les énigmens restent extrémement logique, les solutions des manoeuvres "complexe" toujours soufflé et induite par les discusions. Il n'y a pas d'actions absurde à effectuer sans raisons, comme on peu parfois en voire dans certains Point and click de cette époque.

Un immanquable pour ceux qui ne s'y serrait jamais testé et apprécie les jeux du genre.

Un gros bémol tout de fois... Le Prix... Hors solde steam 15€ pour un jeux qui à pratiquement 25 ans est un prix abusif, que le lifting ne justifient absolument pas (ce soins fait bondir le jeu à 2.5Giga pour un jeu pesant à l'origine 15 méga -version disquette-, autant dire qu'on parle d'une optimisation "à l'arrache") et s'insèrre dans le banditisme assumé de Lucasart qui n'hésite d'ailleurs pas à nous revendre à 7€ des jeux de la même époque non remasterisé avec en "bonus"... la perte de la version française !(on pensera aux Indiana Jones par exemple).

Si le jeu reste excélent le rapport qualité/prix n'y est pas. 
Bien que Lucasart est toujours refusé de déclarer ses logiciels "abandonwear", exigeant de tirer profit de jeux qui n'étaient plus commercialisé, on parle d'un jeu qui était gratuit jusqu'à présent (pas "légament" certes, mais il aurat fallu attendre 20 ans pour une réédition, ceci est une autre question), comme la plupart des jeux qui ont un bon quart de siècle, le "remasteur" ne vos clairement pas vos 15€. Nous sommes toujours ici dans des logiques déplorable visant à maximiser des profits à moindre coût.

Pour résumer, je donne un avis positif général. L'ayant acheté en solde, je suis très largement satisfait de mon achat, le jeu en lui-même est excpétionnel.
Mais 15€ pour un patch graphique, c'est du vol.

*Jesse Helms était un sénateur ultra-réactionnaire. Farouche défenseurs de la ségrégation raciale (il avait voté contre le civil right acts), sa nostalgie raciste l'avait poussé à s'opposer à l'établissement du Martin Luther King Day -jour férié- en cumulant plus de deux semaines d'obstructions acharnés. Il s'était opposé début 90 au fait qu'on soigne les malades du sida. Le titre en anglais est plus claire, Pourpre candidate à être Vice-Président des Usa investi par le partis républicains, Helms est donc "vexxé".

33382927.review:
Day of the Tentacle, both the original and the remake, looks really nice and sounds pretty good (if quite a bit outdated by today's standards). But most importantly, it tries to keep things fresh and creative from start to finish. There are no repeated puzzles, no tedium (don't forget you can transfer items between characters from the inventory itself), 3 characters actually interacting with each other and helping each other solve puzzles and a simple but fun story.

There are also infamously poorly conveyed puzzles, a bit too much focus on purely american history and in-jokes and the game does have a very, and I mean VERY strong focus specifically on puzzle solving, not on story and adventuring. Which is pretty much the main reason why I never cared much about Day of the Tentacle. But even with that, revisiting it now I cannot ignore just how well made and creative that game is. It's full of puzzles to solve, most of them actually make perfect sense and at the same time they're actually funny. So I'm not surprised people still hold it as a good example of what a puzzle focused comedic adventure game should be about. It's truly timeless (no pun intended).

Además, si no te convence el nuevo estilo o quieres volver a sentir el original tienes la opción de configurarlo a tu gusto.

10/10

La remasterización hace que el juego sea más atractivo y fluido, algo casi imprescindible para que sea jugable en la actualidad. De hecho, la mejor parte de la remasterización no es el apartado gráfico o las voces (que, sin duda, son una mejora más que notable en la experiencia) sino los cambios en el inventario, la interfaz y los menús.

En cuanto al contenido, he de decir que me esperaba algo más: habiendo jugado otras aventuras gráficas, creo que algunos puzzles son demasiado difíciles por lo absurdos que resultan y las pocas pistas que el juego ofrece (no la mayoría pero sí hay alguno en concreto, quizá en función del orden de resolución de los enigmas). Sin embargo, la idea y el diseño de personajes me resulta muy divertida si nos paramos a pensar en que el juego original fue lanzado en 1993.

Es un juego recomendable, sobre todo para aquellos que disfrutamos de rememorar tiempos pasados del mundo de los videojuegos (tanto por cuestiones de edad como por motivos de interés en la historia del videojuego). En la actualidad, sin embargo, se puede disfrutar de otras aventuras gráficas más interesantes para mi gusto (aunque quizá menos absurdas, todo sea dicho). Para mí un 7/10, porque la remasterización es buena.
