33023877.review:
A very unique graphic adventure game, the story and plot are just as ridiculous as the name and you'll have no problem wondering what the hell is going on most of the time, but believe me; 99% of the time you'll be wondering what is going to happen next. This game involves the three main characters; Bernard, Hoagie, and Laverne, as well as the supporting cast of Doctor Fred and his family members and associates. Honestly the storyline is just crazy enough to make you want to find out what happens next, despite the fact that you may have no idea what might happen, the solutions in this game are almost always a bit out of the box.

I got this on the Steam Summer Sale of 2017 because I've been feeling a certain craving for adventure games, and I ended up completing it as soon as it finished downloading. I stayed up until eight in the morning just to see what all the fuss was about. It's an amazing game and at the moment it seems silly to pass up on buying it for less than four dollars, this Remastered version of a game is one of the best I've ever seen, it even allows you to switch seamlessly between the old version and the new version (This includes the sound files and the graphics). Even though I didn't play this in its original form, just being able to play it as it was meant to be was incredible and despite today's standards for graphics and sounds I found a very real sense of charm in both the original design and the new one, the latter being very faithful to the former to a precision I didn't think would be possible.

Give it a go, the story is as ridiculous as it sounds and that is a good thing, this is a very good example of a graphic adventure game. It even includes the full version of Maniac Mansion within the game, I've yet to try it but since I've beat the main game I'll definitely be trying that since this Steam version includes many achievements.

33015537.review: Oh DOTT! How I've missed you! Nostalgia at its finest..

33013019.review:
Being born in the 80's, and having a computer in the house in the 90's, I had the privilege of enjoying this game, and also Maniac Mansion (1). I remember the multiple floppy disks (I think the first and possibly even the second one came on 5-1/4!),  and I remember asking my father for instruction on how to get the game running on DOS. The fact that over 20 years later this game got remastered, is a testament to how fantastic of a game it is. It also biases my review...but really, do take my word for it...

Maniac Mansion is the game to which this game, remastered, is the sequel of. Of note, said game is available as a game within a game here, and is actually accessible quite early on in the plot. So you get 2 games really. 

As for the remastering, basically the video and audio have been reworked into much much higher quality. The difference is extremely noticeable...a 1993 game redone over 20 years later....and as a player you can tell that it was painstakingly redone, piece by piece, and very much an in depth process. The puzzles and plot from what I understand has been untouched, (but to be fair its been a really long time and i dont remember. Also, I didn't finish this game when I originally played, and only got about 15% through). 

Using "F1" the player is able to choose the "rendering output" to toggle, at any time, between the remastered version, and the original, very pixelated version. This pixelated version also has lower quality audio, which may be the users preference. And the user can toggle these elements individually in options so that he/she can have old-style audio with new-style video for example. There are options to have a (imo superior) "dial-style" right-click interactivity widget, or, the original "bar-style", which is statically placed at the bottom of the screen, is not contextually activated, and takes up space. This menu is for all your actions for items and iteractive object, such as using, pushing, pulling, looking at, etc, I don't think the dial was in the original; I think this was part of the remastering. Point is, the remastering is very much useful as much as it is aesthetic, because the static menu is a thousand times more clunky than the dial. 

The puzzles are very...odd. I read somewhere in the reviews that you have to apply "comedy logic" to solve a lot of them. I'd say this is accurate. There are quite a few scenarios where the "solution" seems to be something nobody would have ever put together. However, there are a great deal of puzzle parts that do make sense. In general, you will probably find the puzzles (which are what the game completely is about), are humorous, and solved with humour. In general this game is all humour. In my playthrough, I found I'd get stuck for a bit, and then solve one piece of the puzzle, which led to various, waterfalling unlocks of other puzzle parts, and I'd get "on a roll" until getting stumped again.

It's worth pointing out that this, and MM1, were both made by Lucas Arts. There's a few cameo's I guess you could say. Not too exciting, but you'll get a kick out of a few parts if you know what George Lucas means (and if you dont...well...wtf?)

This game uses time travel mechanics in its puzzles. You play as 3 protagonists, one 200 years in the past, one in the now, and one 200 years in the future. You share items through time, and you use time as a part of the puzzle solving.

My favorite part of this game was the dialogue and the cutscenes. The humour. Its a true gem!

In this game you cannot die. And as far as I know, it does not allow you to perform a "wrong action". There are zero repercussions, and this lends to an extremely relaxed play experience, where you don't have to worry about anything at all, and can freely perform any action knowing you won't have to load an old save or something if you mess up.

I recommend this game to all. It's classic. I lol'ed...a lot.

32998701.review:
Ok, so I know that negative reviews on popular games don’t fare well with the communities, but I’ve got to type how I felt about a game.

Day of the Tentacle is the sequel Manic Mansion (that can be found and played in game) in which you play as three characters, who have to use a time machine to stop a tentacle from taking over the world. After using the machine two of the characters have found themselves trap 200 years in the past and future while the third must get the machine working again. This version is a graphically updated version that can be reverted back to the original with the press of a button.

I like point and click games, I don’t love them, but I like them. Some are hit or miss depending on how well they were made and with a Lucas Arts game I’ve found to expect a good game. However, this game just didn’t feel that great to me. There wasn’t much in the way of interactions, there were only a few characters to talk to, must of which were just annoying, and the humor that is usually found in a game like this wasn’t very funny. 

As for the puzzles, I always get frustrated when playing a point and click puzzle games, but with this I was actually getting angry with a few puzzles in this game. I did like the concept of the puzzles, having three maps which you must solve puzzles and find objects to send to other character, but there was some poor execution to some of these puzzles. To explain, there are some background objects that you can view, but just a few, only enough to disguise a couple items as useless background objects early in the game only for them to be a critical item later. While this may seem like a normal thing for the style of game, it doesn’t fit well with how solvable most of the other puzzles are. There is even one puzzle that is unsolvable unless you just happen to stand around long enough or get lucky enough to see an idle-animation of one of the NPCs.

With the amount of frustration, flat Humor, and in my opinion, a not to good story. I can’t really give this game a good recommendation. I can recommend others remastered Lucas Arts games like The Secret of Monkey Island, Monkey Island 2, The Dig, and (Also by Double Fine and personal favorite) Grim Fandango.

32736011.review:
Another LucasArts classic, remastered by Double Fine Productions, Day of the Tentacle is still probably the greatest point-and-click adventure game ever made. In this sequel to Maniac Mansion (which is also included within this game itself), three moronic college students travel through time to save the world from an army of evil tentacles taking over, and somehow fluke their way into doing just that, despite their overwhelming levels of ineptitude.

The humour still holds up for a game made in the mid-90's, the voice acting is still on the nose, the music is excellent, the puzzles while weird do for the most part make some quirky sense (except that damn making it rain puzzle), the art is good. It's still the original Day of the Tentacle, which was an amazingly good game, and one that actually still holds up, unlike the Monkey Island series.

The remastered edition doesn't actually add a great deal to the excellent original game; the updated graphics actually seem to lose something versus the original pixel art, but graphics modes can be switched between the two on the fly, meaning the player can pick which they prefer. The developer commentary is also rather basic; despite bringing together several LucasArts alumni, they don't have a great deal to say about the game

But it has achievements, and we all know that's what really matters, right? Right?

Day of the Tentacle Remastered can be found for sale by itself, or also in the very low priced Double Fine Bundle, which also includes Psychonauts (Amazing), Costume Quest 1 (pretty fun), Stacking (fairly good), Iron Brigade (uninvolving), Brutal Legend (weird), Broken Age (underwhelming), Grim Fandango Remastered (amazing), Hack 'n' Slash (decent), Spacebase DF-9 (very under featured and dull) and Full Throttle Remasted (really good), which I think works out to be a pretty good deal!

32685760.review:
Best adventure game of all time IMO. Perfectly integrates clever puzzles, humor and plot. Not much else to add -- it's a classic.

Regarding this remaster, it's generally very good. The voice quality is superb relative to the original, and the graphics are much sharper. DOTT was a game that really bumped up against the old 320x200 VGA resolution. VGA didn't work very well for cartoony graphics, and the move to modern high-res has done wonders for the graphics.

At the same time, it's not perfect. Had DOTT been made today, the graphics would have been sharper and involved more detail. Instead, the detail that's in the game is just what was barely possible in the VGA version -- they didn't want to taint it by adding more. This results in a game that looks very good to people who remember the original and is clearly the best version of that game, but isn't particularly impressive to newcomers. There's no easy answer here though, since had they added more detail to the graphics, purists would be complaining.

All in all, it's a terrific game. If you've never played it, you should, and if you have played it, this is the best version there is.

32456851.review:
Maniac Mansion : Day of the Tentacle
1993년에 LucasArts에서 발매한 어드벤쳐 게임.
 
처음 이 게임을 접했을 땐 당연히 영어 버전이라 상당히 난이도가 느껴졌는데,
지금은 한글판(비공식)도 나와 있....어도 그래도 쉽지만은 않았다.
 
사실 발매 당시 영어사전 뒤져가며, 어찌어찌해서 엔딩을 한번 봤는데다가
이제 어드벤쳐류 게임으로는 잔뼈가 굵다고 생각하는 편인데도 메뉴얼 두세번은 참고해서 클리어 했다.

과거,현재,미래에 3캐릭터가 나뉘어져서 동시에 문제를해결해야 하는데 미래에서 필요한 아이템을 얻기위해
과거의 캐릭터가 어떤 행동을 취해야하는 그런 식, 게다가 코미디 요소가 강해 넌센스와 아이디어가 필요하다.
 
리마스터링이 아닌 음성과 한글패치된 버전까지 포함해서 3번을 클리어했지만
클리어할 때마다 '재미있는 만화 영화' 한편 본 것 같은 생각이 든다.

게다가 리마스터링 버전은 그래픽, 인터페이스, 음악 등 모든 요소를 리마스터링 버전과
기존 올드 버전을 동시에, 실시간으로 스위치해가며 즐길 수 있다. (F1키 하나만 누르면 OK)
게다가 제작자의 코멘터리도 즐길 수 있으니 참고.

그래픽은 말할 것도 없지만, 어레인지된 조작법이나 음악도 아주 만족스럽다.
쓰다보니 칭찬만 늘어놨는데, 워낙 오리지날 게임이 완성도가 훌륭해서
딱히 단점이라고 할만한 게 없다.

루카스아츠식 어드벤쳐 올드팬이든, 그냥 어드벤쳐류 좋아하는 게이머든
누구에게나 꼭 한번 해보라고 추천해주고 싶은 작품.

** 교훈 : '촉수물'은 동서고금을 막론하고 좋은 테마인 것이다.

The whole game feels like you're trapped in an episode of Pinky and the Brain (1993 all over again!) It's alot sillier than it's predecessor was (Maniac Mansion). The very cartoonish take on viewing perspective heightens the atmosphere. I got this game mainly for the easter egg (a complete version of Maniac Mansion hidden on a computer in the game). If you've played the recent Thimbleweed Park, you can see its origins in the two games.

The puzzles are supposedly the best part of DotTR, although I can't say I'm a huge fan. The remastered artwork is quite nice, even if I'm not too keen on the cartoonish style. It's tough to feel empathy for the main characters, as the plot and such are just so crazy from the outset. But I got this at 50% off, and felt I got my money's worth.

32076655.review:
Some remakes and remasters lack the character and quality of the original game, but this is absolutely not the case with the Day of the Tentacle (DoTT) remaster. It feels fresh 24 years after the original release, and is every bit as fun to play. The original art concept scans are a nice addition and help prove that this version of the game is true to the original design.

If you have never played DoTT, you'll want to buy it and finish it at least once. In addition to DoTT, it includes a non-remastered version of Maniac Mansion within the game.

If you're like me, and had not played DoTT in 20+ years, you can buy it again and it will seem brand new, yet familiar; Even though I can't remember how to solve most of the puzzles, solving them is enjoyable, because, unlike most adventure games, they make sense and don't require the player to resort to hint books or guides. The Steam achievements add even more value. 10/10.

Great, classic adventure game, funny story, charming characters. I never played the original so one concern I had going into the game was if the puzzle solutions would be obtuse and frustrating. I'm happy to say I got through most of the game only consulting a walkthrough once or twice for one of the more weird sections of the game (the cat puzzle was not very well relayed to the player unfortunately). So if that's your concern as well you can lay that to rest. But walking around aimlessly for awhile and occasionally wacky solutions are part of the experience and if you hate that then this game won't change your mind. 

In this game you play as three different characters trapped in 3 different eras of the same mansion. You can give each other items and sometimes things you do in the past will affect the future. The point is to power up the time machines and get a diamond to go back to the present. Some of the changes you can make include to the American flag and even the Constitution. Overall a great game and great way to introduce yourself to point and click games.

31865059.review:
Day of The Tentacle is the sequel to Maniac Mansion, the adventure game that kicked off Lucasarts' legendary SCUMM series of games, as well as the game that introduced Tim Shafer of Double Fine.  

The plot is very silly, moreso than its predecessor, and far less dark.  It really feels like a cartoon.  And once you think of things in cartoon logic, the game's puzzles start to make a weird kind of sense.  There's something very Looney Tunes inspired about the game.  

Bernard, one of the optional characters in the original game, has returned to the Edison mansion with some new friends as Purple Tentacle is mutated by toxic waste into a super villain bent on conquering the world.  In this, the Tentacle is successful, enslaving humanity for centuries to come.  Dr. Fred, the villain in the previous game, is now free from his mind control and is just a crazy, senile mad scientist.  In order to stop the reign of the Tentacle, Fred reveals he has been working on a time machine.  Made out of port-a-potties, of course.  

The time jump malfunctions, stranding the three characters in different time periods.  

Bernard, the stereotypical nerd, is stuck in the present.

Hoagie, a roadie, is stuck in colonial America during the drafting of the Constitution. 

Laverne, a crazy, manic medical student, is caught in a future where humans are pets and Tentacles rule.

The gameplay is based around solving puzzles by using items and commands in unusual ways, and sending items back and forth in time.  Sometimes the item you need to solve a puzzle is in another time period, so you have to try stuff out.  For anyone familiar with these kinds of games, this is expected, if this is your first point-and-click adventure, I am sure it could feel tedious.  They can be straightforward, such as "put the videotape in the VCR" or outright insane (chattery teeth to make a fire!).  Again, the game uses weird cartoon logic.  If it would fit in a Bugs Bunny cartoon, it's possible in this game.  

For the most part, it is not an overly difficult game of its kind, but some of the puzzles are unintuitive enough to be frustrating.  I ended up having to look a few of them up.  

As for the Remaster, it's wonderfully done and with the ability to switch between the original and remastered version at will.  Pressing F1 will switch the artstyle between the original pixel art and the new hand-drawn HD version.  The commands and audio can also be changed at will between classic and remastered, as well as optional subtitles.  

The remastered graphics are very well done, though they really bring out the cartoonishness of the game.  There are a few places where the graphics update helps with some frustrating stuff as some objects are indistinct in the original pixel art.  The overhaul matches the original concept art (which is included as a bonus), and so it doesn't seem like a big departure.  

The sounds have all been remastered from the original recordings, as well.  The commands in the original release were underneath the screen, in a list of actions and inventory.  In the Remaster, a dial system like those in later SCUMM games is used (right click on an object and choose a command from a dial).  Like everything else, this can be switched - but using the dial, the game will expand to fullscreen, making it nicer to look at and less cluttered.  It is perfectly playable either way - but the dial looks better.

And as a bonus, the original Maniac Mansion is included as an easter egg - if you can find a PC in the house, you can access the first game.  

Overall, it's another great game in a line of great adventure games from Lucasarts.

31798912.review:
Honestly, DoTT was a fantastic game, and one that got me into adventure gaming, something I had trouble with before. It just did a lot of things right... It went to town on the art, to the point where it was one of the closest things to playing an interactive cartoon at the time, and it also weeded out a lot of the frustrating aspects previous adventure games had... Being one of the first (if not THE first) adventure games to remove game overs completely, cutting out a lot of obnoxious trial and error while also not making the game too easy. The puzzles can still be daunting, though thankfully not as abstruse and nonsensical as the ones in Monkey Island 2. It was essentially the next evolution in adventure gaming, setting the model for many games in the genre that followed.

However, this was all a review of the original game from 1993. How does the remake fare? Wellll honestly, it's pretty average. The upscaled graphics vary in quality, often looking like they simply ran a filter over the original. The voice acting now uses much less compressed versions of the recordings, but it's still the same stilted, awkward acting as before, and many of the animations just haven't aged well.

The thing is, all these faults seem primarily due to the feature to switch between the remastered game and the original game on the fly, which, quite frankly, was a really cool feature when it was introduced in the Monkey Island remaster, but has since become a bit of a worn-out gimmick. Needing to sync the new version of the game completely with the old one just holds back the ability of the developers to give the game the updates it really needs, and I'd have preferred they ditched the remaster/original switching entirely for some reworked animation in the new version, as well as actual timing in the dialogue.

Aside from that, the additions I ended up appeciating the most were the added commentary mode, as well as the new achievements, which (for the most part) encourage players to find little extra touches and bits of dialogue in the game, and that's something the lucasarts developers have always been good at.

I believe this remaster is very worth it for those who haven't played the game before and would like to witness an incredible piece of adventure game history. Those as old as I, who've played the original and enjoyed it back in the day, way want to wait for a sale. That is my verdict!

31407559.review: This is a must-buy title for any fan of the genre. It's one of the few games that is in league with the likes of Indiana Jones & the Fate of Atlantis, Broken Sword: Shadow of the Templars and the first two editions of the Monkey Island series. In terms of game design, I'd say it's the most ingenious of the genre with a puzzle system that revolves around solving tasks in a past, present and future state of the Maniac Mansion, with each feeding into solutions of the other. This novel take on time travel, in the form of transporting inventory through the toilets of the Chron-O-Johns (time machines), is what sets this adventure apart from so many others.

31264569.review:
Masterful remaster!

I played this game when it first came out in an earlier millennia and loved it so much that I played it over and over again. The nostalgic value of this remaster is pretty damn high for me personally, which means this review will be highly subjective. One thing I think I easily can say in an objective way though is that this remaster is done right. This is how you make a masterful remaster.

Often when you play a remaster of a game that you remember as a vital contribution to your gaming history it does not live up to the way you remember it. This has happened to me on several occasions. This is because your selective memory gives you a vision of how it would look by todays standards, and most games can not live up to that vision. This game though, to my shock, did that to the fullest. They managed to update this game to my visions of the classic based on my selective memory, and that to the fullest. That is simply amazing. I don't think I've ever experienced that with any remastered game before. Bravo to Double Fine!

To this day I could remember most of the gameplay and puzzles from when I played it many years ago, and because of that I kind of breezed through the game this time. But even with the lack of challenge, reliving the experience with this game was a blast. Reciting lines just before they are said and giggling in anticipation of what you know is going to happen when you do certain things. Even the retro game (Maniac Mansion) within the retro game had me excited (Yes, I am so old I can even remember playing that some time before this "sequel"). I had so much fun that I might play this remastered version over and over again like I did with the original way back when.

If you are an old school gamer like me and used to play adventure games you have probably played this before and know what to expect. In fact if you at all played this game at one point or never got to play it the first time around you can not let it pass this time. Play or replay it. It is a must. However, today there is several younger generations that never got to play this, but I bet most of them too have heard about the greats that was LucasArts and the times of point 'n' click adventure games. If you want to experience what every father, uncle or any other older gamer was bragging about, now's your chance to try for yourself. But there is a few things you need to know in advance:

Going through this game for the first time is not going to be as easy as it looks. There are some brain twisting moments in this game and few things are straight forward. Yes, you might also consider several puzzles to be a bit far fetched or illogical, or like us older gamers call it, creative :o). It is not a game with a lot of action and high pulse, though you might experience moments of heavy frustration over not figuring out how to advance the story and welts on your forehead because of facepalms after you figure it out. Though it might seem impossible or unfair at times, the game always hints you in the right direction. You need to pay attention though or you might miss them. The game is cleverly designed that way. Do yourself a favor by trying to use guides or walkthroughs as little as possible. The fulfilment you sit with after getting through this game without help is worth it.

The graphics and artstyle is suitable corny and comedic, well fitting the premise of the game. You'll love the characters, both main and secondary. They are even wonderfully voiced. I even dare you to not laugh out loud playing through this game. There is so much great stuff in here it is impossible not to. Another good thing is that I did not experience a single glitch or bug at all playing through this, something that seems rare lately.

I have to recommend this game to everybody and their mother, father, brother etc. It is that damn good. You owe it to yourself to play this so you know what all the fuzz is about. Even if you should end up not liking it, it would still be worth it. Just for that.

To me it is one of the pinnacles of gaming history and the fact that I enjoyed it as much now after all these years and after all these playthroughs attest that to me it simply is and always will be a masterpiece. That is why I simply have to rate this 10/10.

In fact, I enjoy it so much I feel like I could... TAKE ON THE WORLD!

What are you waiting for.... go get ;o)

Other people migh not share my opinion of this game so it could always be worth reading other reviews....and tell them they are WRONG, and then run to buy it yourself ;o)

Happy gaming :o)

TJ

I have never played a Tim Schafer game that I did not like, and DofT is no exception! The humor is on point (..and not something you will see in newer games), I laughed so many times and really enjoyed the easy going story.

Day of the Tentacle Remastered is Maniac Mansion 2.  This is your old-school point and click adventure game, where you play as 3 kids trying to find the things they need to defeat the evil Purple Tentacle (who just was mutated with arms!)

There are some hilarious lines in this game, that could only have been allowed because it was made in the 90s.  Gameplay is very similar to that of the typical 90s adventure games as well.

If you have the patience, this is a classic title for this genre, and highly recommend it.  If not, you can read a review and a walkthrough and have the puzzles told for you, and still enjoyable.

Achivement Quest:  This is an easy 100%, but there are missable achivements which make it scary.  Look up a guide, find the missable achivements, and make sure to look for those along the way.  All achivements can be earned in 1 playthrough.

31083060.review:
Кто может защитить землю от щупальца и его подопечных? - Ботан, Рокер и Дурнушка! 
Может показаться, что игрока ждет глуповатый квест с соответствующими шуточками... Но! Есть несколько "плюшек", которые в корне меняют игровой процесс и отношение к сценарию.
Действие происходит в трех временных измерениях: прошлом, настоящем и будущем. Влияя на прошлое вы меняете будущее, начиная от замороженного кота в холодильнике, и заканчивая политическими деталями в свершении истории. Подобрав предмет одним из героев вы не просто можете применить его, а передать в другое время. От обилия возможностей теряешься в догадках, да и загадки тут не из простых, но более-менее логичные.
Попадая в прошлое вы общаетесь с прошлыми президентами США, влияете на их мысли и поступки. (Просто невероятно, при завязке-то со злым щупальцем.) Так что юмор здесь разный - и глуповатый, и комедия места, и историческо-сумбурный.
Римейк содержит обновленную графику, звук, комментарии разработчиков. Графика изменена довольно бюджетно, в неестественном стиле, - видимо это очень затратно, в современном мире, но глаза не режет и привыкаешь быстро. Переключится в старую версию с графикой, звуком можно на лету.
Веселый, глуповатый, сложный и неожиданно интересный квест проверенный временем.
7/10

31076269.review:
La migliore avventura grafica di sempre (insieme alla serie di Deponia). Questa versione rimasterizzata è straordinaria: l'interfaccia è stata svecchiata e alleggerita in maniera impeccabile (ora l'inventario è a comparsa). Le immagini sono a tutto schermo e in alta risoluzione. Il gioco mi ha fatto tornare indietro di vent'anni, facendomi assaporare lo stile delle vecchie avventure grafiche. Ringrazio i ragazzi della Double Fine Productions per aver svecchiato questo splendido gioco. Davvero un ottimo lavoro. Consiglio l'acquisto di questo gioco nel periodo degli sconti.

Consiglio: I personaggi possono passarsi gli oggetti direttamente dall'inventario (clikkate sull'oggetto nell'inventario e poi sull'immagine del personaggio destinatario) senza andare necessariamente ogni volta al crono-gabinetto.

Voto: 9

I last played the game when I was 17 or so. I'm 40 now; this remaster is how I remembered it in my mind's eye. This is a brilliant achievement; the repainted art, the remastered audio from the original voice recordings.. it gives completely new life to this classic. I bought this remaster at first to prepare my adventure muscles for the release of Thimbleweed Park, to get back in the mindset, but I ended up enjoying it immensely on its own. I was pretty happy that I completed it without any hints in 7 hours  - I recalled some puzzle chains from my last playthrough as a teen, but had to rediscover most and got stuck on a few silly things.

Highly, highly recommend if you're a point and click adventure fan; DOTT was the unbeaten high point of this genre and it still is.

30727995.review:
[h1]*** VERSIONE SINTETICA ***[/h1]
[b]pro[/b]:
[list]
[*] un [i]grande classico[/i] consigliato a chi non ha avuto la fortuna di scoprirlo a suo tempo
[*] il fascino dell'originale è rimasto intatto negli anni, in una veste rispettosa della tradizione ma con un occhio agli standard attuali
[*] mantenuta la possibilità di giocare per intero anche [i]Maniac Mansion[/i]
[/list]

[b]contro[/b]:
[list]
[*] la grafica remastered non sembra andare aldilà di una ripulita dei pixel
[*] commento degli autori a tratti deludente
[/list]


[h1] *** VERSIONE ESTESA ***
[i]Il giorno quando tentai di colare un tentacolo[/i] [/h1]
Spesso e volentieri quando si recensisce un'avventura grafica (o punta & clicca, a dir si voglia) si cade nel tranello di sbrodolarsi nella sindrome del "Ai miei tempi...", degni del miglior osservatore di cantiere italico. A maggior ragione se si sta parlando di un classico [b]LucasArts[/b] come [i]Day of the Tentacle[/i]...
   Si è scritto così tanto sul mondo delle avventure grafiche che non penso abbiate bisogno della mia opinione in merito. Va da sè che una remastered ha due ragioni d'esistere:
[list]
[*] dare la possibilità a giocatori giovincelli di avvicinarsi a pietre miliari della storia videoludica
[*] far riscoprire ai nostalgici un po' più "datati" una parte della propria gioventù ludica
[/list]
C'è da aggiungere che una qualsiasi remastered (soprattutto se si parla di avventure grafiche) ha in sè una componente fortemente "documentaristica", grazie alla possibilità di integrare al gioco ulteriori contenuti bonus, primo fra tutti il commento degli autori.
   L'uscita della remastered di DotT era una delle più attese, quantomento da parte mia: la prospettiva di vedere la grafica cartoonesca in alta definizione era un richiamo irresistibile, e [b]dopo aver goduto del commento degli autori della remastered di Monkey Island 2[/b]... beh diciamo che l'aspettativa aveva completamente stravolto la mia regolare salivazione. Devo ammettere, però, che una volta calatomi nei panni di [i]Bernard, Hoagie e Laverne[/i], la sensazione è che quell'aspettativa non sia stata del tutto soddisfatta.
   Non del tutto, certo: Effettivamente è una goduria vedere in una veste del tutto nuova uno dei giochi che ha profondamente segnato la mia giovinezza, sia dal punto di vista meramente ludico che da quello più ampiamente culturale. e Day of the Tentacle si conferma come un'opera invecchiata in maniera ineccepibile. [b] Ma c'è un ma [/b]. Probabilmente anche due.
   Complice la benevolenza della memoria umana, [i]la veste grafica remastered non mi ha dato la sensazione di meraviglia che un'operazione del genere vorrebbe suscitare[/i] - soprattutto messa a confronto con quella di Monkey Island 2. Nel mio immaginario Day of the Tentacle era come se fosse [b]già[/b] in alta risoluzione. Ovviamente se ci si mette con occhio clinico a paragonare le due versioni, le differenze vengono a galla e sono ben evidenti... eppure non c'è stata una trasfigurazione sbalorditiva. Il che - si badi bene - non è data dalla scarsa qualità del lavoro svolto dai ragazzi della [b]Double Fine[/b] (basta dare un occhio alla remastered di [i]Grim Fandango[/i]) quanto dal fatto che Day of the Tentacle di per sè è invecchiato in maniera splendida.
   Una delusione vera e propria, invece, la ho avuta per quanto riguarda [b]contenuti bonus[/b]. Aldilà dell'efficace e ben fatta impostazione delle interfacce e soprassedendo sul gradevole art book, dal commento degli autori mi aspettavo molto di più. Troppo pochi gli interventi, e spesso poco incisivi. Ogni tanto ho avuto la percezione non siano riusciti a trovare particolari argomenti da trattare o aneddoti da raccontare - dando un'atmosfera di riempitivo che dispiace. Peccato.

[h1]In sintesi...[/h1]
La mancata sensazione di sorpresa e di riscoperta che manca in questa remastered, da una parte sembra puntare il dito sulla (a volte) legittima critica di [b]"speculazione nostalgica"[/b] che le edizioni [i]remastered/special/enhanced[/i] si portano inevitabilmente dietro; dall'altra non si può notare che a volte - e fortunatamente questo è il caso - [i]non è l'HR che fa il gioco[/i].

30605748.review:
今は無きルーカスアーツより1993年に発売されたPCゲーム。日本ではなじみが薄いが、スチームのレビューを読むと若き頃の黄金の思い出として印象深いそうだ。本作はそのリマスター版であり、絵や音楽、操作方法が現代向けに作り直されているだけでなく、当時の画面と音楽でプレイできるモード（F1で切り替え）がある。更にはアートワークやオーディオ・コメンタリーも付いており、どれだけの人に愛されてきたゲームかを窺い知ることができる。

ゲームの内容を簡単に述べると、世界征服を企む触手「紫」を止める為、バーナードとその友人ホギーとラバーンが現代・過去・未来の三つの時代に分かれて暗躍するアドベンチャーゲーム。操作は左クリックで移動、対象を右クリックで動きを指定するポイント＆クリック方式。難易度はかなり高く、良くある理不尽な解決法（いや、悔しいけど伏線は貼ってある）もあり、ノーヒントでクリアするのは相当苦労すると思う。ヌルゲーマーの私は後述の煩雑さもあり、数回ほど答えを見たことをここに白状する。当時の人は良くクリアできたなぁ。

評価は思い出補正増し増しかと思っていたが、そんなことはなかった。絵、演出、物語、音楽、どれを取っても文句なしの作品だと思う。ただ一つ言わせて欲しいのは、持ち物をキャラ別にする必要は無かったのではないかと思う。正確には時代を跨いで移動できる小物に関しては共通でも良かったのではないか。わざわざアイテム授受の為にキャラを（マップ端にある交換場所へ）移動させなければないのが非常に面倒だった。この点を除けば、時系列を利用したギミックやコミカルなアニメーションはプレイしていて楽しいので、是非ノーヒントクリアを目指して挑戦してみて欲しい。

なお日本語はない。基本は適当に動かしていれば解決できるが、会話パートもあるので多少は理解できないとやり辛いかもしれない。

30523850.review: Incredible game now comes with awesome ingame flip-feature from classic to remastered version by the push of one button. Fantastic!! Ye good ol' memories.

30522247.review:
Ein Haus voller Verrückter, Zeitreisen und ein machthungriger Purpur-Tentakel. Unter Zockern meiner Generation klingelt‘s bei Erwähnung genannter Stichpunkte sofort, und wem schon bei der Titel-Abkürzung DOTT augenblicklich der Groschen fällt, der bekommt 100 Gummipunkte extra. *g* Natürlich ist von „Day of the Tentacle“ die Rede, einem DER großen Adventure-Meilensteine überhaupt – und zugleich eines der populärsten Genre-Meisterwerke der ehemaligen Kultschmiede Lucas Arts. Ein Must-Have-Titel den man als PCler in den 1990er Jahren einfach haben musste. Jaahaaaa, lang ist’s her…
Und nun, 23 Jahre später, darf auch die neue Generation in den Genuss dieses Klassikers kommen. Tim Schafer, dem geistigen Vater von DOTT, sei Dank. Nach „Grim Fandango“ hat das unter seiner Leitung geführte Entwickler-Studio Double Fine Adventures auch hier Hand angelegt und den ergrauten VGA-Hit fürs Full-HD-Zeitalter wieder fit gemacht. Das Resultat, welches sich nunmehr „DOTT – Remastered“ nennt, kann sich ohne Frage sehen lassen.

Für all jene die die DOTT-Story noch nicht kennen sollten – falls das überhaupt möglich ist-, hier eine kurze Zusammenfassung:
Das geknackte Dreier-Gespann Bernard, Laverne und Hoagie eilt zum Edison-Haus um den durch Dr. Freds eigene Giftbrühe mutierten Purpur-Tentakel aufzuhalten, der mit seinen nachgewachsenen Stummelärmchen Welteroberungsambitionen an den Tag legt. Doch weil das Kind längst in den Brunnen gefallen ist muss die Katastrophe verhindert werden bevor sie passiert. Also gestern. Klar, kriegen wir hin. Denn wie es der Zufall will hat Dr. Fred drei zu Zeitmaschinen umfunktionierte Dixie-Klos im Keller stehen – für nen DeLorian fehlte wohl das Geld *lach* -, ergo schickt er bebrillten Tollpatsch, wirre Medizin-Studentin und korpulenten Rocker auf Zeitreise um die Menschheit vor Purpur zu bewahren. Doch leider geht alles (wie zu erwarten) schief. Hoagie landet 200 Jahre in der Vergangenheit, Laverne selbe Zeit in der Zukunft, während Bernard weiterhin in der Gegenwart festsitzt. Obgleich zeitlich voneinander getrennt müssen alle Drei alles daran setzen den verursachten Schlamassel wieder zu korrigieren…

Zur Beruhigung aller Alt-Fans:
„DOTT- Remastered“ ist kein (!) Komplett-Remake geworden. Die Handlungsabfolge, die Rätsel(ketten), die Dialoge, nahezu alles was das Ur-Spiel eben so kultig macht ist unangetastet geblieben, das Einzige was Schafer und sein Team an Verbesserungen durchgeführt haben ist rein kosmetischer Natur zuzuordnen. Der unvergleichliche, comicartige, aber aus heutiger Sicht auch arg grobpixelige Zeichenstil erstrahlt nun messerscharf 1:1 nachgezeichnet und im bildschirmfüllenden 16:9-Format, während das alte SCUMM-Interface mitsamt Verb-Leiste einem modernen Popup-Menü weicht. Wer sich zu den Puristen zählt und nicht auf SCUMM verzichten möchte darf dies glücklicherweise weiterhin nutzen, muss aber dann auch mit einem klassischen 4:3-Bild leben. Gleiches gilt für die Original-Grafik zu der man – wie bei den „Monkey Island“-Neuauflagen – per Tastendruck schnell hin und her switchen kann. Ansonsten gibt es keine nennenswerten Neuerungen. Die Animationsstufen der Charaktere sind weiterhin beschränkt, weshalb die Bewegungen von Bernard und Co. altmodisch, sprich leicht abgehakt aussehen, während die knallbunten Hintergründe in der Regel recht starr bleiben. Dafür erfolgt das horizontale Scrolling - anders als früher - nunmehr butterweich. 
Richtige Anpassungen lassen sich eher auf der tonalen Ebene herausfiltern. Die neu abgemischte Musik klingt etwas frischer bzw. minimal satter und einzelne Geräuscheffekte wurden ausgetauscht, was aber letztendlich nix an der eher spärlichen Soundkulisse großartig ändert. Neben der alten, leicht dumpfen Deutsch-Sprachausgabe steht nun auch die englische Tonspur zur Verfügung, welche klar vorzuziehen ist. Zwar nicht ganz auf dem Niveau der Original-Fassung von „Sam & Max“ und Co., aber insgesamt doch passender als die deutschen Sprecher. Multilinguale Texte und eine Entwickler-Kommentar-Funktion gibt’s noch dazu, und das „Spiel im Spiel“ – gemeint ist natürlich der DOTT-Vorgänger „Maniac Mansion“ – ist ebenfalls noch enthalten.

Fazit:
Obwohl es nicht zu meinen persönlichen Lucas Arts-Favoriten zählt möchte ich „DOTT – Remastered“ nicht missen. Auch nach über 20 Jahren mag ich den schrulligen Humor und die besondere Rätselgüte des Originals, die mit äußerst schrägen, aber doch streng logischen Einfällen daherkommt. Dank an Schafer und Co. dafür dass sie diese nicht wegzudenkende Genre-Perle für die nächsten (mindestens) 20 Jahre liebevoll restauriert und für nachfolgende Generationen gerettet haben. Nun kann ich das nächste Remastered-Projekt ("Full Throttle - Vollgas") kaum abwarten. :)

30504818.review:
Los grandes clásicos nunca se olvidan, tarde o temprano vuelven, llegan mejorados pero como no, manteniéndose tan vivos y con tanta carisma como los conociamos.

Estamos antes la segunda parte del juego Maniac Mansion, un gran clásico dentro de las aventuras gráficas que allá por los noventa ya causó furor, y seguramente, con esta reedición siga ganando jugadores en los siguientes 20 años.

El argumento gira en torno a tres amigos que tienen que unirse y viajar al pasado para evitar que un tentáculo púrpura mutado controle el mundo en un mundo que se nos muestra al más puro “dibujo animado”. Todo esto plagado de un humor por doquier, y grandes momentos para recodar.

El sistema de juego utiliza el clásico point and click, en el que pincharemos sobre la pantalla para que nuestros personajes se muevan por el escenario. Como en toda aventura gráfica, las ideas más descabelladas y alocadas serán las que marquen el avance la historia. El sentido común no te será útil, tendrán que darle al coco para pensar una idea loca, y que harían nuestros personajes para resolver cada puzle que nos encontremos. 

Una parte que hace interesante el título es como juego con el tiempo. No hago ningún spoiler si os digo que muy pronto cada uno de los tres personajes viajarán en el tiempo, bueno… todos no, Bernard se quedará en el presente, pero los otros dos amigos si se irán, uno 200 años al pasado desde la actual fecha, y la chica 200 años al futuro. Lo interesante de esto es que estarán en contacto todo el tiempo gracias a las maquinas del Dr. Fred Edison, y cada acciones que hagamos en el tiempo afectarán a los momentos sucesores. 

Si te decides por comprar la versión de consola estas de suerte, porque Day of the Tentacle cuenta con cross-buy y cross-save, para disfrutar de nuestra partida en Playstation 4 a la vez en PS Vita.

Gráficamente el juego ha sido mejorado muchísimo, con unas ilustraciones en alta resolución, pero con la ventaja de seguir teniendo el mismo juego de siempre.
 ¿No te llega a gustar el nuevo diseño? No importa, si eres de los que no quieren cambios del diseño, y simplemente han buscado una excusa para volver a jugarlo, siempre tendrás a un toque de botón (pinchando en PS4 en la pantalla táctil) y así de sencillo pasaremos de vista moderna a vista clásica.

Un nuevo añadido, aunque ya estamos acostumbrado a ello con las remasterizaciones de otros juegos, es la inclusión de logros. Un aliciente más para los amantes de los trofeos, y para los coleccionistas de juegos completados.

El apartado sonoro también ha sido mejorado, brindándonos la oportunidad de escoger la música de esta nueva edición o de su antigua. Y no solo eso, contamos con el juego con todos los textos en castellano, que será más que esplendido para disfrutar plenamente de las graciosas conversaciones entre personajes. Respecto al audio no hemos tenido tanta suerte pero bueno, no se puede pedir todo. Si no te queda suficiente con todo esto, encima el juego cuenta con la posibilidad de habilitar al comienzo los comentarios de los creadores originales.

Si has leído este análisis es porque te gustan las aventuras gráficas, y en tal caso tanto si lo jugaste hace más de veinte años como si no, este juego se convierte en un indispensable al tenemos todo. Disfrutable en versión clásica o remasterizada, logros, diversión, entretenimiento y sobre todo mucho humor.

Más en: creativefuturegames(doc)com

30428431.review:
Zeitreise in der Videospielgeschichte!
Wenn man einen Spieleklassiker wie Day of the Tentacle überarbeitet und neuveröffentlicht, kann man damit zwei Gruppen ansprechen: Jene, die damals bereits das Spiel liebten und ihre Sentimentalität mit einer den modernen Standards weitmöglichst angepassten Version ausleben wollen, und jene, die das Spiel bei der ersten Veröffentlichung aus verschiedensten Gründen nicht gespielt haben und sich womöglich nicht auf den damaligen Standard einlassen können oder wollen. Das Design des Spiels wirkt auf mich wie die Blaupause für weite Teile der kommerziellen „Nerdkultur“, wie ich sie kenne: bunt, überstilisierte Proportionen, charmant überzeichnete Charaktere. Der Humor schwankt zwischen wirklich clever und grenzenlos stumpf. Die Idee, dass Purpur-Tentakel nun, da ihm dank giftmüllverschmutztem Wasser Arme gewachsen sind, die Weltherrschaft an sich reißen möchte und drei Hauptprotagonisten, die zwar alle nur denkbaren Klischees erfüllen, aber dennoch irgendwie sympathisch sind, ihn nun völlig plan- und ahnungslos stoppen sollen.

30376539.review: Day of the tentacle, le père fondateur des point and click modernes, revient dans une version (légèrement) retravaillée ! Je viens juste de le finir à nouveau et quel bonheur ! Le jeu est toujours aussi fun et retords après toutes ces années ! Pour ceux qui ne connaissent pas et qui ne sont pas allergiques aux point & click, sachez que ce jeu est absolument indispensable ! Tout y est formidable : l'humour potache, la direction unique très inspirée où tout est dessiné de travers, les animations à la Tex Avery, l'aventure qui fait penser aux meilleurs moments de Retour vers le futur, les situations et les personnages, plus loufoques les uns que les autres. Bref, un gigantesque moment de bonheur à passer en compagnie du docteur Fred - savant complètement fou, de Bernard l'intello, de Hoagie le rockeur gras du bide et de Laverne l'apprentie chirurgienne à tendances sadiques. Quant à la version 'Remastered' proposée, celle-ci n'apporte que de menus ajouts, mais sympathiques : possibilité de passer de la version d'origine en gros pixels avec l'interface et la musique de l'époque vers la version remasterisée en appuyant sur la touche F1, sauvegarde automatique, succès et bonus débloqués quand on avance dans le jeu. La version Remasterisée consiste en un passage à la HD respectant parfaitement le style d'origine avec support des écrans larges, et sans le menu en bas de l'écran, remplacé par un menu contextuel en cercle apparaissant quand on clique sur bouton droit de la souris. Je trouve que le lissage graphique est sympathique, même s'il fait disparaître complètement le pixel-art d'origine. Cela dit, on peut switcher quand on veut entre la version d'origine et la nouvelle donc rien de grave à ce niveau-là. La musique remasterisée, quant à elle, est de l'ordre du sympathique également, mais n'est pas fofolle non plus. Un synthétiseur plus récent a été utilisé pour faire le rendu des musiques. Il n'y a pas eu de vraie réorchestration à proprement parler. Sinon, tout est là, y compris l'intégralité du jeu 'Maniac Mansion', jouable directement dans un des ordinateurs du jeu (ce qui était incroyable pour l'époque). Bon, je me suis un peu étalé, mais vous l'aurez compris : ce jeu est légendaire de par son génie et je pense sincèrement que tout gamer normalement constitué devrait l'avoir fini au moins un fois dans sa vie. Ah oui, une dernière chose : évitez d'utiliser une soluce si possible : les accomplissements n'en seront que plus jouissifs !

30160003.review:
Remaster przygodówki z początku lat 90. Wtedy by wyciągnąć sweter spod grubasa leżącego na łóżku należało wyjść na dwór gdzie rabuś próbuje się z łomem dostać do auta, dać rabusiowi kluczyki do samochodu, od odda ci wtedy łom, ty użyjesz łomu na gumie do żucia która przylgnęła do podłogi. Odlepioną gumę żujesz i znajdujesz w niej monetę. Monetę używasz na łóżku na którym przebywa grubas (pamiętacie o nim jeszcze?), moneta uruchamia wibracje pod materacem które wyrzucają grubasa na podłogę, a ty możesz wziąć sweter. A teraz... po co mi ten sweter?

Ale zawsze są bardzo pomocne poradniki na Steam. Dzięki temu można ukończyć produkcję i nadal pozostać przy zdrowych zmysłach. Sama przygoda jest bardzo przyjemna, bo rozgrywa się jednocześnie w trzech płaszczyznach czasowych. I na przykład by uwolnić koleżankę która utknęła na drzewie w przyszłości należy ściąć to drzewo w przeszłości.

"Day of the Tentacle" lśni w temacie kwestii wizualnych i dialogowych. Przyjemnie jest obcować w tym świecie i gadać z kolejnymi bohaterami. A do tego dochodzi jeszcze podróż w czasie, więc możemy opierniczyć Ojców Założycieli Stanów Zjednoczonych.


6+/10.

Day of Tentacle Remastered est un difficile Point & Click. Difficile par le fait que ses énigmes sont très tricky : à la différence d'un autre P&C, ici vous êtes plongé(e) dans une histoire loufoque à base de voyage dans le temps et de tentacules prenant vie. Par conséquent, la logique du jeu se veut à l'image de son univers : déjantée.

J'avoue avoir eu recours plusieurs fois à des guides tant certaines actions à réaliser étant tirées par les cheveux. Cela dit, l'humour est bien présent, et des références feront sans nul doute sourire.

Un bon jeu dans l'ensemble, dans lequel il convient de prendre son temps et surtout, de réfléchir plus ou moins logiquement. Durée de vie variant selon les joueurs, avec une rejouabilité éventuelle pour les chasseurs de succès.

29843476.review:
During the 90's, I seriously missed out. The only reason I knew about LucasArts was because when I was in the 4th grade, there was one computer. On that computer was The Secret of Monkey Island. We each had a turn and as a class we helped each other. How I wish we had had this game.

Pure and simple, this is a classic. I know I would have loved this game in my youth, if I had been able to play it. Seriously, what hasn't been said about this game? This is a must buy for those who are fans of LucasArts and of zany fun and wacky 90's point and click adventures. The characters are wacky and memorable. The game colors just pop. There is a seemless transition between the old and the remaster. I enjoyed taking a look at the original. Maniac Mansion is also here, another LucasArts game I have been unable to play until now! The puzzles will make you think, since this is LucasArts and from the 90's. Speaking of the 90's, I enjoyed all the cultural references and how the game dated itself. I felt like a kid again and I enjoyed the feeling of a game that even though it is old felt very new and reminded me how excited we were during that time of gaming. I know more great times are ahead.

Je préfères les remaster de Monkey Island, qui, même s'il y a eu quelques changements, s'adaptaient vraiment aux techniques d'aujourd'hui. Il aurait été tout à fait possible de le faire ici sans garder les saccades.
Et si c'est juste pour la fonction ultra gadget de pouvoir switcher entre l'original et le remaster... bof bof, surtout que MI permettait de le faire sans ce problème.

Autrement le jeu reste un excellent Point & Click mythique et ravira les amateurs du genre, je le recommande donc ne serait-ce que pour ça, mais attendez des soldes tout de même : Moi j'ai eu la chance de me le faire offrir, et heureusement parce que j'aurais été un peu dégoûté d'avoir payé pour un remaster pas aussi poussé que je ne le pensais.

29586902.review:
---------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Spiel: 

Ein Point & Klick Adventure mit Zeitreise Story wunderschön aufgearbeitet und immer noch sehr unterhaltsam.

---------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Einzelspieler:

Man spielt mit drei Charakteren abwechselnd in verschiedenen Zeiten. 
Die Geschichte ist das ein Mutierter Böser Tentakel die Welt erobern will, er Reist durch die Zeit um seinen Erfolg zu sichern und drei Helden Reisen ihm nach. Es geht etwas schief und die drei Helden landen in verschiedenen Zeiten, nun müssen sie Rätsel lösen um die Gegenwart zu retten.
Man spielt in Typischer Point & Klick Manier alle Charaktere wie man es von Lucas Arts gewohnt ist.

Im Spiel gibt es ausserdem noch einen Computer zu finden an dem man Maniac Mansion spielen kann, diese Version ist mit Savegame und alle was dazu gehört versehen.

---------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Grafik:

Die Grafik ist in der remasterten Fassung ist super überarbeitet, das Original sieht auch sehr gut aus.

---------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Musik:

Die Musik ist sehr gut gemacht, immer sehr passend.

---------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Steuerung:

Die Steuerung sehr gut mit der Maus im Remasterten Teil, es kann aber auch im Scumm Mode gespielt werden.

---------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Pro/Contra:

+ sehr gute Grafik
+ gute Steuerung
+ gute Musik
+ sehr gute Deutsche Synchro
+ gute Story
+ guter Deutscher Untertitel
+ Maniac Mansion


---------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Fazit:

Ein wirklich sehr gutes Point & Klick Adventure, aber LucasArts hat es nun mal wirklich drauf gehabt. Hier stimmt einfach alles, die Charaktere sind Super, die Geschichte ist einfach aber schön erzählt und es ist für alle Altersklassen unterhaltbar. Leider etwas kurz geraten mit circa 8 Stunden beim ersten Mal durchspielen.

Aber wenn es mal im Angebot ist für 75% oder in einem Bundle sollte wirklich mal einen Blick hineinwerfen.

---------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Zusammengefasst: 

Einzelspieler: 10/10
Grafik: 10/10
Musik: 10/10
Steuerung: 10/10
---------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Spiel: 10/10

29452650.review:
Supongo que para los que jugamos al Día del Tentáculo en su día es fácil caer en la nostalgia a la hora de ponernos a hablar de él. Lo bueno es que a veces hay títulos tan válidos que se puede (y debe) hablar de ellos por lo que son y no por cómo los recordamos.

Dejando a un lado aquellas tardes de nocilla delante de la pantalla, lo cierto es que el juego, remasterización gráfica aparte, aguanta el tipo de manera sorprendente. El diseño de puzzles, divididos en tres personajes e hilos temporales distintos, sigue dando muchísima cancha a la hora de experimentar y dar rienda suelta a nuestro pensamiento lateral, que es a fin de cuentas lo que venimos a hacer cuando jugamos a una aventura gráfica.

El resto, historia y personajes, son casi el MacGuffin sobre el que se desarrollan las situaciones y resoluciones más disparatadas, con permiso de Sam & Max, de la época dorada de LucasArts.

No hace falta llamar a los recuerdos de infancia para encumbrar juegos de este calibre. Ya lo hacen por sí mismos.

29451242.review: One of the best games ever made... re-made.

29294087.review:
[h1][b]Day Of The Tentacle Remastered			* 9/10[/b][/h1]

This has always been a MUST I've never been able to play at the times. I was lucky enough to play the first Monkey Island and Sam & Max, but I missed this one, and this remaster is a really great opportunity.

Day Of The Tentacle is a Point & Click adventure with the typical traits of any Lucas arts adventure: Funny story, Humour and silly non-sense situations and characters. On top of that This is a Remaster from Double Fine which can be considered a revived Lucas Arts and responsible for other Remasters and interesting titles (Grim Fandango is a Good Example)
The story begins straight and simple, and maybe it might be worth to know that DOTT is not a first or unique chapter (Even I wasn't aware of that before playing it in these days...), but it's a sequel of Maniac Mansion, one of the very first Lucas Arts games which shares most of the characters with DOTT, especially one of the protagonists: Bernard.

The original DOTT was supposed to have an interface resembling Monkey island, with a large bar below the screen with a list of selectable actions and the inventory. This remaster adopted a different (and in my opinion more modern and efficient) system which recalls the coin from Curse of Monkey island, where you hold the right mouse on an item/character in the environment and a set of available actions appears.

One of the unique aspects of DOTT (already used in Maniac Mansion) is the number of protagonists. You have to control either Bernard, Hoagie (my favorite character XD) and Laverne in different situations. This kind of enhances and complicates the experience by increasing the playtime as the inventory items found around can be shared between characters to solve their own puzzles, so you must keep in mind that you might need another character's item to solve your current riddle.

Graphically there's not much to say, DOTT is a Remaster so it is obviously a more polished hi-res version of the classic game. As usual you can constantly switch the game to the classic and original graphic/interface, just for fun or nostalgia (just like in Monkey island's remasters, always by double fine). Musics are as usual great and they clearly fit in the silly mood of the game.

Noteworthy: inside the game there's a "not-too-hidden" opportunity to play the original Maniac Mansion. Entirely. And it's weird to think this "easter egg" was available in the original DOTT as well... O.o

[h1]+++PROs+++[/h1][list]
[*][b] LUCAS ARTS ADVENTURE.[/b] Another great Lucas Arts adventure available and remastered for modern configurations. Humour, Story and puzzles. Everything in a great mix, now Remastered
[*][b] ORIGINAL CHARACTER SETUP.[/b] This was an interesting setup, you can move each of the three protagonists at any time and share their items in their inventory to solve riddles.
[/list]
[h1]---CONs---[/h1][list]
*[i]coff, coff...[/i]*
[/list]

29216481.review:
This is a competent remaster of a fantastic classic game - if you've never played it, or if you have and have the cash to burn -- BUY THIS GAME.

A couple of pointers to make your playing experience a LOT smoother:

- I was having massive graphical and sound problems when playing this game at first, to the point where it was almost unplayable and really dragging down my opinion of the game.  After some desperate Googling I tried something that I haven't had to manually do on any system in nearly ten years and updated my sound drivers.  After that, everything ran smooth as butter, and the sound was just as spectacular as it ever was in the original version.

- Unlike earlier remasters of other LucasArts games such as Grim Fandango or the Monkey Island series, the remastered graphics displayed here are not in fact disappointing garbage.  I played through the whole game twice without having to switch to the classic renderer.

- Huge time saver here that eliminates a possible source of frustration in the game: If you're managing a character's inventory, and want to give an item to a different character, you can just drag and drop the thing right onto that character's portrait to instantly give them that item.  Trading items in this fashion can cut a good half hour off of your final playtime.


So in closing: Great game, great remaster, well worth your time and moolah.  

* Extra special kudos to Double Fine for not f*cking this one up.  Great job, you guys.  We're all rooting for you, truly and sincerely.  Now, be careful delivering Psychonauts 2, we don't want you to accidentally drop it on its head and have it turn out like its brother Spacebase did.

29184226.review:
Tras la remasterización de Grim Fandango, el anuncio de la próxima aventura gráfica era algo que estaba casi cantado. El día del tentáculo ('Day of The Tentacle' o DOTT en la gloriosa era de MS-DOS), ha conseguido que me quite un par de años mientras recordaba lo bien que uno se lo pasaba jugando a las aventuras gráficas de LucasArts.

La remasterización ha sido muy fidedigna, sin estridencia alguna, y respetando el original en todo momento. A nivel gráfico se ha estilizado aún más el aspecto de dibujo animado (consiguiendo un resultado soberbio), y han adaptado los controles a nuevos jugadores que opten por el mando (siempre será mejor el sistema 'point & click').

Como es habitual en este tipo de ediciones que lleva realizando Double Fine, podemos jugar tal y como jugamos en los 90 (con el estilo gráfico, el sistema de verbos y música original), remasterizado (mejora gráfica, un sistema de verbos simplificado y adaptado, amén de música remasterizada para la ocasión)... y eso no es todo: podemos jugar con el nuevo lavado de cara y el sistema de verbos original, eligiendo incluso qué tipo de música queremos escuchar. Este es un punto que es de agradecer, pues da manga ancha (y varias 'configuraciones') para que se adapte a todo tipo de jugador, ya seas de la vieja escuela o un iniciado en este maravilloso mundo de las aventuras gráficas.

Quizás el único punto negativo sea que el Maniac Mansion que han incluído (recordemos la publicidad de la propia caja 'un juego dentro de un juego'), esté localizado sólamente al idioma de Shakespeare y no en castellano, no posibilitando disfrutar de ambas aventuras gráficas por completo, pues recordemos que 'El día del Tentáculo' es una secuela directa del Maniac Mansion creada por el genial Ron Gilbert (compañero durante la etapa dorada de LucasArts de Tim Schafer).

Una oportunidad de oro si te gustan las aventuras gráficas o eres seguidor de la edad dorada de LucasArts, y un ejemplo de cómo se ha de mimar y tratar un juego a la hora de pasar por el taller para ser remasterizado. 

Próxima parada: Full Throttle Remastered.

DOTT Remastered is a polished remake of the original CD version;
The humor is goofy and the puzzles aren't that hard if you can think outside of the box. One of the nice things is that you can customize your HUD and display to play it with the SCUMM interface with the old graphics or just in the remastered style or even a combination of the two.
The transition between the three characters is gradual and adds a nice pace to the game.
As an added bonus just like the original you can play the original Maniac Mansion, something that was a bit of a problem with the old verion on newer machines. The old game on cd played just fine on modern computers but I couldn't play the original.
Very fun game if you like the Lucas Arts adventure style games but not for everybody I guess...

29021693.review:
Although already a fan of the original game, I purchased this with an open mind. The plot of the game is story rich, imaginative, funny and challenging. The game is neither too easy or too difficult, and does provide clues here and there, but you need to pay attention so you don't miss them. If you have already played the game in the past, then you will know how much of a legend it is amongst old school gamers, but if this will be your first play through, you are in for a treat if you appreciate old school adventure games. 

The gameplay has changed slightly from the old version, but is not overly complicated - infact it is a time saving way of playing. 

The graphics have been highly polished but other than that, nothing has changed at all (which is brilliant!) 

The game is now compatible with newer PC's without having to mess about with compatability settings or downloading other softare to make it compatible. 

All in all, I am so pleased I purchased the remastered version of this classic game. It absorbs you into the story and you feel you have to complete it in one sitting!

28990323.review:
Это превосходный, олдскульный квест, в который играли с самого детства мы, дети 80-х :) С этим переизданием в игру вдохнули новый виток жизни, и получилось очень хорошо. Для любителей по ностальгировать с чашкой кофе в руках (или с чем покрепче) это игра прекрасно подходит. Кому нужно ставте Руссификатор, ибо довольно сложная Английская речь в игре. 

Про саму игру рассказывать смысла нет, все и так уже рассказали. Единственное, что могу отметить, это самый сложный квест что я знаю, а знаю их не мало, проходить без подглядывания в прохождение может быть очень не просто, лично я так и не осилил ее в то время (где-то на пол пути так и бросил), но прошел сейчас и естественно прохождение подглядел. В других квестах как правило 3-4 действия можно совершить с предметом, здесь же до 8-и, такие как толкнуть от себя, потянуть на себя,.. кроме тоже практически каждую вещь можно передать 3-м героям игры, которые находятся в будущем, прошлом и настоящем. 
Но все равно, игра прекрасна! У ценителей должна быть в коллекции, наряду с такими шедеврами как. Full Throttle, Grim Fandango (кстати тоже весьма не простой квест), Deus Ex 1, Psychonauts, Shadowman 1, Fahrenheit: Indigo Prophecy и других, которые не вспомнил на скорую руку.

28912516.review:
Fazit für eilige Leser: Ein alter Adventure Klassiker mit hübsch-aufgebohrter Grafik, viel Slapstick Humor aber ohne zusätzliche Hilfen.

Ich habe das Original damals zwar gespielt, aber nie komplett fertig (ich glaub sogar nur ca. 50%). Dadurch kamen anfangs Nostalgie Gefühle auf, die mich auch über ein paar Sackgassen im Spiel hinwegtrösten konnten. Denn wenn man nicht weiterkommt, gibt es leider keine Hilfe oder Tips (wie es z.b. bei Baphomets Fluch der Fall ist). Man kann interagierende Objekte hervorheben mit Shift, das wars an Hilfe.

Die Optik ist in meinen Augen sehr gut gelungen und hübsch umgesetzt. Die Möglichkeit mit F1 direkt zur alten Klassik-Optik zu switchen hat mir sehr gut gefallen und ist ein nettes Gimmick.
Es gibt im Verlauf des Spiels auch die Möglichkeit auf einem Computer das alte Maniac Manson zu spielen, tolle Idee :)

Die Spielzeit war bei meinem ersten Durchgang mit knapp 7 Stunden angemessen, wobei ich auch teilweise eine Weile gebraucht hab um auf die richtige Lösung zu kommen.

Wer die alten LucasArt Adventures gespielt hat, dem kann ich dieses Spiel nur empfehlen. Wer aber schnell die Geduld verliert oder sowieso nicht gern Adventures spielt, der braucht hier kein Geld ausgeben. Es gibt zwar eine detailierte Komplettlösung in den Community Guides, womit man zumidenst von der Story alles erfährt. Aber es ist eben doch ein anderes, viel erhabeneres Gefühl, wenn man nach ewigen rumprobieren selbst auf die Lösung kommt.

28837859.review:
Day of the Tentical Remastered falls into our love of retro games. Adventure games as a whole have sort of taken a back seat due to their lack of pace and more thoughtful direction of story telling. But where these games may not have fast paced adrenaline shoot 'em ups and car chases, they make up for in both humor, story and puzzels. Day of the Tentical is no exception.

Day of the Tentical Remastered is a reboot that is worth while. All of the graphics have been replaced with beautifully hand drawn sprites, updated music, and with all this, keeping the actual original game intact. On top of this, if you are a stickler for originality, it's as simple as pressing F1 and you can play the game in it's original pixeled glory.

If you're a fan of adventure games, and/or just want to play something that's legitemately funny, I can recommend this whole hartily. If not, and you're looking for some fast paced action, then avoid this, and any classic adventure games at all costs.

28785185.review:
Оригинальная игра была выпущена LucasArts в 1993 году. И эта игра была под [b]DOS[/b]!
На сегодняшний день, несмотря на солидный возраст оригинала, Day of the Tentacle Remastered ничего не потерял, но и приобрёл - обновлённая графика и интерфейс, возможность запуска на современных ОС, достижения Steam, коллекционные карточки, комментарии авторов. А для тех, кто ещё помнит оригинальную игру, есть возможность переключения к "старому" виду "на лету".

История самой игры рассказывает нам о трёх друзьях, которым необходимо помешать мутировавшему(!) щупальцу(!!) завоевать мир и поработить человечество. Действие происходит на территории старинного поместья, которое необходимо будет посетить в прошлом, настоящем и будущем.

Графика игры выполнена в мультяшном стиле.

Проходить игру будет весело как ребёнку, так и взрослому. Но необходимо иметь в виду то, что русский язык не поддерживается.

Итого, моя оценка 10 из 10.

PS Как и в оригинальной Day of the Tentacle, есть возможность поиграть в первую часть игры - Maniac Mansion, возпользовавшись компьютером в комнате Эда Эдиссона. Правда она уже, в свою очередь, идёт с оригинальными графикой и звуками из 90-х.

28716952.review:
[h1] DISCLAIMER: This is a full review, and NOT a first impressions review like all my other reviews, if you want a better full review, then please read better reviews then mine [/h1]

Along with the other LucasArts games I've played from just a wee child to now from Grim Fandango, to Full Throttle, to the Tales from Monkey Island series and this Day of the Tentacle, I will always love the adventure games LucasArts has produced in its hayday. Day of the Tentacle was the third game I played after finishing Grim Fandango and Full Throttle as a child and now thanks to Double Fine Productions, Walt Disney Interactive and Lucasfilm we can now finally have another LucasArts adventure game fully remastered to its former glory

Funnily enough I did not know that Day of the Tentacle is actually a sequel to a previous LucasArts game known as Maniac Mansion and I have personally never played Maniac Mansion

Day of the Tentacle's story is brilliant. From its quirky characters to its lovable cutscenes and funny comedy. and the music (especially in the remastered edition) is absolutely brilliant! The cutscenes are lovable and fun to watch and are brilliantly animated, overall the game is brilliant! 

The puzzles and game progression, although when I was young and I played Day of the Tentacle for the very first time I did not have any walkthroughs or guides, so the puzzles were a bit challenging and can be a bit too awkward for modern-day players or even newcomers to the genre. The game does not help you at all when progressing through and does not hold your hand when your stuck on a puzzle for too long, so be prepared to get stuck here and there, thankfully I remembered most of the stuff! Lucky guys with internet nowadays, you can simply type in walkthroughs for the game!

The remastered version, Double Fine have really done a job well done for remastering this classic. The music is spot-on and digitally remastered. The cutscenes, although not fully converted to HD are very watchable, and the new HUD system they implemented has made it easier for players to play the game. The addition of HD graphics, etc... made the game more stunning than it originally was (and if you want some nostalgia, you can play the game in its original graphics!)

Overall, Day of the Tentacle and its remastered version are simply brilliant and if you are a fan of LucasArts (like me!) or you like adventure games or you want to try something new, then I would highly recommend playing Day of the Tentacle and I hope that Double Fine will continue to remaster these old LucasArts classics!

Although no LucasArts classic adventure game will ever beat Grim Fandango, Day of the Tentacle is still a wonderful and one of my favourite adventure games to play even though nothing beats Grim Fandango, that's a legendary LucasArts classic game!

[h1] RECOMMENDED :) [/h1]

28698349.review: You can not do anything wrong by playing this game. Especially if you like classic adventure games.

28697644.review:
As a follow up to one of the greatest point and click adventure games of all time, Maniac Mansion, Day of the Tentacle Remastered had a lot to live up to.   Maniac Mansion allowed the player to choose 2 characters from 6 friends to accompany the main character which means it had 20 possible teams to play as.  Day of the Tentacle had a standard 3 character set. 

So does it measure up?  I think it does.  The story of the game is the team is trying to stop the Purple Tentacle that has gotten mutated and decided to take over the world.  The game starts with Bernard (a character from the original game, and a fan favorite) bringing two friends to help stop the Purple Tentacle.  He ends up traveling through time to yesterday and through a problem, the three friends are separated by hundreds of years.   The three friends need to find a way to fix their personal problems, and eventually work together to save the day. 

So how is the game play and puzzles?   Well honestly, that's what really shines.  The remastered version of the game has the ability to choose between hot spots on the screen, which really helps. 

At the same time there's a few puzzles that are hard, but honestly there's nothing that obtuse, and a few that are really clever.  There was a room or two I had to revisit with out realizing it, but overall a lot of the game is quite straight forward.  The puzzles work well and some of them are quite clever.

The story does shine as well, I love the updated characters and new characters for the original game.  It's not overly hilarious, but it's also not trying to be funny all the time.  The puzzles take precedence over the story, and that works.  So don't expect to piss yourself laughing, but you will get a couple really good laughs. 

But wait there's one last thing to mention.  Day of the Tentacle also included the classic Maniac Mansion.  While the remastered didn't improve the classic game, it's still included in this version, which is a fantastic deal. 

Overall I recommend this game as a great example of how an adventure game SHOULD be.  There's not a ton of frustration with it, and the story and areas the game explores are great.   The only thing I could imagine is this is a very American centric game.  There's a few puzzles that likely require a small understanding of American history, or colloquialisms.  It shouldn't ruin the game, but there was one point where I questioned if someone who didn't know a story would be able to solve it.    But still overall? Easy recommend, especially for anyone who is a fan of point and click adventure games.   And bonus points for having multiple different control schemes and the classic game included inside the game?  Hell yeah!

28686000.review:
I’ve played this game far more offline than steam wants to admit.

After playing “Grim Fandango” among others, I started to think point and click games weren’t for me. The characters and story is usually really nice but so many (a minority but many enough) puzzles where illogical or out of nowhere. (I need to point out that I’m a very logical person and have a easy time with problem solving in general. When I say they are illogical  it’s not because I just don’t get it.) Some people say that you “need to know the developers” for games like “Monkey Island” (haven’t played) and “Grim Fandango”. I call it bull-excrement. 

Either way. This game changed my mind. It’s not without it’s annoying parts/puzzles but most of it is logical. It might take you some time and sometimes you will just guess it right rather than figuring it out. When you do however it’s almost always a “Oh, right of course”-moment. If you’re being slow they also give you hints in the form “films” of npc:s talking.

So the puzzles are good, what else you ask. Well, the animation style is nice on the eye and the humor, if a bit dated, really funny. The story is wacky and completely out there. The characters are amusing and, in a good way, stereotypical. They make fun of the stereotype rather then the people.

If I would mention some negatives. Sometimes it’s hard to know that you may walk to certain places. I walked back and forth a lot at one occasion before I realized one of the characters could enter a whole new area. The jokes are very American and as earlier mentioned, a bit dated.

I might be a bit bias since I played this as a kid and I haven’t played that many point and click games but this is still a great game. I’m not sure I will recommend this in a decade or two since it is dated, I am now however. I pity the fool that doesn’t get it.  

PS: Works on LINUX!

Ayant joué à DotT à l'époque, j'en avais gardé un excellent souvenir, avec ses graphismes style dessin animé, ses énigmes à la fois loufoques et logiques (enfin, plutôt, logiques selon l'univers du jeu), avec ce petit grain de sel supplémentaire des interactions entre les différentes époques qui faisait tout le charme de ce point-&-click.

Ce remaster remet cet excellent jeu au goût du jour, et je ne peux que recommander à ceux qui ne le connaissent pas d'en profiter pour s'y plonger.
Les graphismes avaient plutôt bien veillis, ils sont maintenant entièrement refaits mais toujours dans le même esprit.
Différentes interfaces, plus modernes, sont disponibles. Et celle proposée par défaut simplifiera grandement les choses au nouveau venu, vu qu'en fonction de l'objet choisi, les possibilités d'interactions varient et sont fortement réduites - alors que dans le jeu de base, il était possible de combiner toutes les actions avec tous les objets... ce qui faisait un paquet de possibilités.
Et puis enfin, cerises sur le gâteau : Maniac Mansion est toujours là. Et il est possible de basculer à n'importe quel moment vers la version d'origine. De petits détails, mais qui font la différence entre un remaster paresseux, et un de qualité.

27904060.review:
LucasArts and Sierra games were a mainstay of my early years with computers.  A time where I only was able to fit one game at a time on my hard drive.  Day of The Tentacle (after playing Maniac Mansion on NES) was one of the first CD based talkie games I ever owned.  It quickly ascended the ranks of personal favorite computer games to settle in a top five position among greats like the Space Quest series, Sam and Max Hit The Road, and a few select others.

I am so glad I played it long enough ago that higher education and the real world erased many of the puzzle solutions and plot developments from my mind.  Playing the remaster of DotT immediatly transported me back to sitting in front of the computer in the den trying to figure out where to go next and learning the most innacurate American history possible.

The remastered graphics are amazing and the ability to switch on the fly to the old pixelated look is a great feature.  The music and voice acting made the move over flawlessly and the puzzles are just as head scratching.  Much easier to get a hint now as well with the advent of the modern internet.  Bonus points for Mac support as well.  I played most of the game on a Mac without issue and spent some time playing on PC as well.  Both perform exceptionally.

Day of the Tentacle Remastered is a must play for classic adventure game fans and anyone who wants puzzles that are as far from obvious as you can get.
