27888511.review:
One of the most iconing point&click adventure games from lucas arts. Like with previous remasters from Double fine, you are given a choice to seamlessly switch between original visuals and remastered ones. Similarly you can either switch between original midi sound score and remastered sampled one.  Personally i find of remastered sound with classic visuals and director comentary the most satisfying combination of the available options.  
A no brainer purchase for adventure newcomers and veterans  alike. 

PROS: 
Oldimers will appreciate updated sound and smooth gamplay without of hassle of messing around with either dosbox or scummvm. New players will appreciate timeless cartoonish style, hillarious dialogue and insane puzzles in style of early LA production 

CONS: 
Remastered visuals are somewhat lacking in detail as if original graphics had been just retraced in vector painting app, giving the the visuals feel of a browser flash game. 
Some puzzles may be a bit more challenging than what players are used to in current games. 
A large part of the puzzle design revolves around indirect interaction beween the 3 main protagonists via something akin to message in the bottle mechanic. While ingenious in concept, it can sometimes lead to being stuck for extended periods of time as the necessary interaction is not easy to guess. eaxmple: bernard(present) needs to stick hamster in into icebox so it freezes, so laverne(future) can thaw it and use hamster in solving the puzzle in future

27888475.review: So gut wie damals. Sowohl der Charme als auch der Witz des ersten Durchspielens vor vielen Jahren stellt sich ab der ersten Minute wieder ein.

27885118.review: One of the best LucasArts game remastered :).

27884871.review: One of the greatest point and click adventures Lucasfilm Games ever created. I played this game probably 10 times, maybe even more, so there's a replay potential. I really like the overhaul of the remastered edition and that you can always switch back to the original game. The only advice apart from buying this game is not reading any walkthroughs because eventually it's more fun to explore and to find the solution to every riddle on your own (just remember to close every door you see).

27883735.review:
One of the best point-and-click adventure games of all times gets the remaster it deserves. A remaster that doesn't dumb it down and doesn't "make the gameplay more fluid", but just makes the game playable on newer systems and updates the beautiful graphics. Even better, if you are the sort of purist who thinks only the original is worthy, you can always change the graphics back to the pixelated glory of the early '90s and it will seem like you never skipped a beat. 

The use of time travel as game mechanics is one of the coolest ways in which the story and the mechanics of a game come together to create something greater than the sum of its parts. Some of the best puzzles in video
game history can be found here and only a handful of them will seem frustrating or illogical. 

The only bad thing I can say about it, really, is that there seems to be a small, yet irritating, bug where after playing for a while, a random audio effects will begin looping every few seconds. This makes the game extremely annoying to play, but can be solved by quitting and restarting the game. It happened to me 3 or 4 times during my playthrough, making it something more than just a freak occurrence. 

An absolute gem, for both old and new players!

27881861.review: Todo un clásico atemporal, un pedacito de historia previo lavado de cara para adaptarlo a las pantallas y controles de hoy en día (aunque permite cambiar a la versión antigua y pixelada para los más nostálgicos). Obra maestra. Ya estás tardando en jugarlo.

27780886.review: This was one of the earliest PaC PC games I ever played. Once I realized that Dr. Fred's secret plans were in the basement, I could finally enjoy the real absurdity and hilarity that was the rest of this game. If you find you aren't making progress, you probably aren't being maniacal enough (it's the Maniac Mansion sequel, after all). I definitely recommend this Remastered version, as it contains developer commentary that fans will love. If you're new to DoTT, I'd also recommend playing with the classic graphics (not remastered) if you want an authentic and original experience. 10/10!

27524321.review:
Nostalgia canaglia

Fiumi di ricordi nell’edizione rimasterizzata di Maniac Mansion I nostri lettori più giovani probabilmente non erano nemmeno nati quando, nel 1993, fu pubblicata una delle pietre angolari nell’industria videoludica, frutto della creatività di una coppia di autentici geni. Day Of The Tentacle, seguito di Maniac Mansion uscito nel 1987 (incluso in una easter egg, anche se non oggetto di revisione), si può considerare a giusta ragione come un’espressione della cultura popolare con la quale sono cresciuti tanti ragazzi (anche italiani) dei primi anni Novanta: un’opera con cui Tim Schafer e Dave Grossman, i due programmatori principali, sono inconsapevolmente diventati papà di una nutrita schiera di avventurieri. A volte ritornano Come ogni capolavoro che si rispetti Day Of The Tentacle non ha conosciuto un enorme successo commerciale: agli esordi ne furono vendute, secondo le stime dello stesso creatore, poco meno di 100.000 copie. La fama crebbe grazie alla critica dell’epoca e il titolo divenne un vero e proprio cult negli anni a venire, comparendo in cima in più o meno tutte le “hall of fame” che i siti di informazioni videoludica (e non solo) hanno stilato. Le logiche commerciali hanno quindi voluto che anche questo mostro sacro passasse sotto le forche caudine dell’ammodernamento: pratica dannatamente pericolosa che rischia di sacrificare il fascino che una produzione del genere si porta dietro, snaturandosi per incontrare i favori di una platea enormemente più numerose, eterogenea e, ci si passi il termine, meno “hardcore” di quella che oltre vent’anni fa si destreggiava con la configurazione dell’autoexec.bat per far partire il file dott.exe dal prompt del DOS. Il fronte della vecchia guardia, alla quale chi scrive appartiene, solitamente è molto restio a questo tipo di operazioni, ma bisogna ammettere che, nel caso di Day Of The Tentacle Remastered, il lavoro di update si è saggiamente limitato ad una ridefinizione grafica molto aderente alle idee originali della LucasArts e ad una leggera semplificazione dell’interfaccia SCUMM che però è rimasta concettualmente invariata. Il risultato è una copia 1 a 1 del titolo originale: fortunatamente non sono state fatte aggiunte di alcun tipo tanto che, volendo, è possibile portare a termine il titolo nella venerata e pixellosissima versione anni Novanta - basta premere il tasto F1 per fare un salto indietro nel tempo, proprio come quello di Hoogie, uno dei tre protagonisti del gioco. Preparate i fazzoletti Il futuro dell’umanità è minacciato dal tentacolo Viola che, dopo aver bevuto dell’acqua radioattiva, acquista dei superpoteri: viene catturato, assieme al più mite fratello di provetta, dal proprio artefice, lo scienziato pazzo Fred Edison che per evitare la catastrofe decide di eliminare le due creature. In soccorso dell’indifeso Verdone arriva il maldestro dottor Bern Bernoulli accompagnato da una coppia di assistenti: la psicotica studentessa Lavigne e il summenzionato Hoogie, degno esponente della categoria roadie. Il tentativo di salvataggio non va a buon fine perché Viola riesce a fuggire: per fermarlo dai suoi diabolici piani servirà tornare indietro di un giorno, grazie al prototipo della macchina del tempo appena messo a punto dal buon Edison. Come facilmente prevedibile anche questa mossa non funziona a dovere: mentre Bern rimane ancorato ai giorni nostri, i due ragazzi vengono catapultati 200 anni nel passato (Hoogie) e 200 nel futuro (Lavigne). Il fil rouge che li collega passa attraverso il gabinetto della cabina del tempo. Il giocatore si troverà quindi a zompare tra un’epoca e l’altra nel tentativo di mettere a posto le cose e di salvare la razza umana. Uno degli aspetti più riusciti di Day Of The Tentacle è la spiritosissima trama, alla cui stesura ha contribuito anche Ron Gilbert, padre del motore SCUMM e di Monkey Island. I nostri eroi si troveranno spesso in situazioni paradossali così come altrettanto assurdi, ma non per questo privi di logica, sono i numerosi enigmi la cui risoluzione fa proseguire nella trama. I tre protagonisti dovranno aiutarsi a vicenda gettando oggetti apparentemente insignificanti nello sciacquone: così capiterà che la pubblicità di un’aspirapolvere finirà con l’influenzare la costituzione americana, rendendo in futuro un diritto di tutti il possesso dell’elettrodomestico, il che tornerà particolarmente utile nello scenario di Lavigne. Il livello di sfida è piuttosto interessante per chi si avvicina al titolo per la prima volta: naturalmente un po’ meno per chi ricorda a menadito ogni passaggio del gioco, considerando che, come detto, si tratta di una fedele replica dell’originale. Nonostante il peso degli anni tutto funziona ancora a meraviglia: usando la nuova interfaccia utente, cliccando sugli oggetti compare un menù radiale in cui si può scegliere solo tra le azioni effettivamente disponibili per quel tipo di oggetto (ad esempio non si può parlare con una lavatrice, azione che nella vecchia release era invece contemplata). Questa impostazione rende la navigazione al passo coi tempi e permette allo stesso tempo di utilizzare anche l’ereticissimo joypad (il titolo è infatti previsto anche per PlayStation 4 e PlayStation Vita). Old but gold Per fornire nuova linfa vitale al suo capolavoro Double Fine si è affidata a Yujin Keim che ha avuto la benedizione di Peter Chan e Larry Ahern, i due disegnatori originali: il risultato è davvero encomiabile, perché l’artista ha rispettato fedelmente i bozzetti del 1993, riproducendo in alta definizione quello che un tempo si poteva solamente immaginare. Merita ancora un plauso la possibilità di saltare, in tempo reale, da una versione all’altra mediante la pressione di un tasto, giusto per ricordarsi come si giocava una volta e a che punto sono arrivate le moderne tecnologie. Anche la colonna sonora è stata rimasterizzata e si integra perfettamente con la veste grafica proprio come lo faceva all’epoca. La possibilità di attivare i commenti dei programmatori, inoltre, è una graditissima opzione che aggiunge un tocco di rigiocabilità ad un titolo che richiederà circa una decina di ore per essere portato ai titoli di coda. Kommento Il grande Vincenzo Beretta, caporedattore della storica rivista PCZeta, sosteneva che nessun gioco può meritare il massimo alla sua uscita: è necessario che trascorrano gli anni e che il tempo ne certifichi un’eccellenza che all’atto della pubblicazione non può essere pienamente compresa. Mai come in questo caso è quindi giusto tributare con una votazione ad honorem uno dei titoli più importanti della storia dei videogame, degnamente riportato al passo con i tempi da un’ottima rivisitazione tecnica che rimane fedele alle idee dei geniali ideatori di Day of the Tentacle, esempio, per certi versi più raggiunto, di creatività, originalità, umorismo e divertimento.

27512722.review:
Day of the Tentacle ist ein klassisches Adventure-Spiel aus den frühen 90ern: es glänzt mit einer phantasievollen Story, einmaligen Charakteren und jede Menge Witz und Charm -- aber wer das Spiel genießen will muss sich auch auf eine gute Portion Pixel-Jagen und Adventure-Spiel-Logik einlassen.

Nichtsdestotrotz, Day of the Tentacle ein echter Klassiker aus der goldenen Zeit der Adventure Spiele, und diesen Status hat es sich redlich verdient. Mit der Maus und den klassischen Aktions-Verben und Inventar-Quadraten navigiert man drei steuerbare Charaktere durch drei unterschiedliche Epochen - die Gründerzeit der Vereinigten Staaten, die Gegenwart, und die nahe Zukunft -, um dem tyrannischen Violett-Tentakel die Weltherrschaft zu entreißen. Dabei spielt es keine Rolle, ob man gerade den Gründervätern einen Streich spielt oder eine alte Frau die Treppe herunterstößt, das Spiel wirkt immer wie aus einem Guss; selbstverständlich gibt es überall Rätsel zu lösen, aber diese werden als Teil der Welt und Geschichte präsentiert.

Meine Meinung zu Day of the Tentacle ist dabei sicher stark durch Nostalgie und Jugenderinnerungen beeinflusst, aber wer nicht Point&Click-Adventures allgemein ablehnt oder beim Spielen grundsätzlich auf Spannung und Nervenkitzel aus ist, der wird an Day of the Tentacle seine wahre Freunde haben.

Fazit: bedenkenlose Empfehlung!

Besonders wenn man das geniale Rätseldesign, die herrlich abstruse Story und die abgedrehten Charaktere einmal selbst erleben möchte und auch sollte. DOTT gehört einfach in jede Spielesammlung! 27414284.review:
Endlich wieder da!

Damals in jungen Jahren  noch als Escom Bundle geholt und seit her mein liebstes Spiel im Bereich Point to Click.

Es ist kein Day of Tentacle 2, aber man merkt deutlich, wo hier noch gearbeitet wurde. Viele ehemals nicht vertonte Textpassagen wurden nach-vertont und als kleiner Bonus wird sogar noch der Wechsel von HD in die Retro Grafik angeboten, obgleich diese mir noch zu optimiert vorkommt. Sogar die alte Retro Steuerung ist in dieser Ansicht verfügbar.
Die Stimmen selbst sind nah am Original, aber doch merklich anders -  jedoch nicht schlechter... oder lag es doch nur an den damals schlechteren Boxen?? 

Alles im allen einfach wieder schön sich in das Chaos zu stürzen. Wer es noch nicht kennen sollte, es ist eindeutig eine Kaufempfehlung.

Performance ist technisch sauber umgesetzt. Habe es auf einem alten Laptop mit einem AMD E 250 und Linux spielen können :)

Ich bin noch nicht bis zum Automaten im Spiel, aber ich bin gespannt auf die Umsetzung von Maniac Mansion. Bisher eine gelungene, solide Überarbeitung. Einzig zu kritisieren ist die Voreinstellung der Entwicklerdokumentation, die im ersten Moment das Intro ruiniert, wenn man sehnsüchtig darauf wartet ins Spiel einzutauchen. Ein kleines Symbol im Spiel zum de- und aktivieren wäre mir lieber gewesen als dafür immer ins Menü zu müssen.


Bleibt nur zu hoffen, dass es vielleicht doch irgendwann den 2ten Teil geben wird....

27351595.review:
¿Qué hace que un juego sea rejugable?
La mayoría de las veces lo importante es que tengas diferentes opciones dentro del juego, que te lleven por diferentes caminos... en algunos casos con diferente final. Están también aquellos donde la adicción que produce la jugabilidad hace que lo juegues una y otra vez. No es el caso de "Day of the tentacle". Entonces... qué es lo que lo hace rejugable? Muy simple, en mi caso particular es la nostalgia, que va más alla del juego, es eso que viene por añadidura y qué esta fuera de lo que pensaron los desarrolladores: El recuerdo de lo que te generó cuando lo jugaste por primera vez.
 Y es que Day of the tentacle tiene eso y mucho más. Es uno de los mejores juego que he jugado, la historia es muy divertida y es un clásico de los juegos point & click, incluso en los 90, donde era la época dorada de este tipo de juegos.

 Así que si sos un veterano como yo, no podes dejar de comprártelo y jugarlo nuevamente, y si nunca lo jugaste no podes perdértelo.
 Incluso para los más nostálgicos, dentro del juego podés jugar al Maniac Mansion original (no al Maniac Mansion 2 que es este, sino al primer juego de la saga)

27297839.review:
Like many other reviewers, I'd like to say that I remember Day of the Tentacle (DOTT) from my childhood. Unfortunately (fortunately?), I'm too old to say that without lying. However, I can say that I remember the game from my (earlier) adulthood, which means I'm not too old to recall playing it.

It was nice to hear that they were doing a re-master of this game since I had been thinking of trying to get my CD copies to work on a modern computer. This made that task a lot easier. Now I could finally introduce my daughter to this fun and funny game. Unfortunately, after a short period of time she declared that the game was boring and had bad graphics. Then she went back to playing Undertale.

If you enjoy adventure games with a sense of humour and you're not a 13 year old girl prone to ironic statements regarding graphic quality, I definitely recommend Day of the Tentacle. Plus you're actually getting two games in one since, like the original, it also includes Maniac Mansion, the game that came before DOTT. You just have to find it...

27289898.review: This game is an utter classic. I play the original at least once a year on average. Everything is on point. You can also still play Maniac Mansion inside the game, just like the original, if you know where to look! Perhaps Ed knows?

Sigue siendo Day of the Tentacle, una de las aventuras gráficas más divertidas que, al igual que la mayoría de LucasArts, tiene la virtud de que aunque no consigas avanzar, los chascarrillos que mete en sus diálogo hace que no se haga frustrante dar vueltas para seguir buscando la clave para continuar.

Como versión remasterizada deja un poco que desear el hecho de que los gráficos mejorados sean simplemente pasar los originales por un "filtro de emulador" y que todo parezcan manchurrones de color, pero lo compensa el hecho de poder cambiar a los gráficos originales en cualquier momento y la pista de comentarios de los desarrolladores.

Attribute: Saukomisch, nicht leicht, sehr gute Charakterzeichnung, tolle Geschichtsstunde zur Gründung der USvonA, außergewöhnliches Schema der Spielgestaltung (drei Figuren erleben drei Zeitebenen, zwischen denen man agieren und rätseln muss) dies erschwert abstraktes denken ein klein wenig und natürlich das Spiel im Spiel (ManiacMansion, ein noch älteres und fast noch besseres Adventure als DoTT)! It's a great product of a past, sadly, era during which point and click adventure games ruled supreme.
And while the game isn't the best of the best, it's definitely up there with all the other great games of its time.
Plus, it aged extremely well and still holds up to scrutiny.
Though, while the graphics in this updated version are nice looking, they weren't what I'd call mind blowing.
That is not an issue however, as this is still one of those rare must-play games for everyone.
If you're a fan of the genre itself, do yourself a solid and pick this one up even if you weren't part of the pc gaming scene during the glorious golden age of adventure games.

Back in the day, during the golden age of point and click, I had two lucas arts games that I loved, the first was sam & max hit the road, and the second was Day of the Tentacle.  Both games have completly bonkers puzzles that need solving, which is something that is seriously lacking in todays point and click games (with the exception of Deponia) that give it that extra challenge and Laugh out Loud moments.

the remaster has smoother edges on its textures, but I actually prefer some of the classic audio more than the remaster audio.  and there's plenty of acheviments to keep you playing, and many of the achievments are not story related and easy to miss (something for your next playthrough me thinks)

it's also worth mentioning that this game has its prequel game 'Manic Manision' as a playable mini game within the game (just like the original DOTT did)

27002740.review:
In 1994 when I was seven years old I went over to the house of a girl I was desperately in love with. On her family computer was a game. I didn't recognize it, but I love the art style. She moved the mouse and clicked on, "Look at" in the bottom menu, then clicked on a door. The character walked over to the door and said, "Bitchin'." We laughed. 

I moved away a few months later and thought about her and that game for years. When I went to computer stores I would search through the game ailse for a game that looked like what she was playing. A few years later I finally found the game in a Lucas Arts adventure pack. It was called, "Day of the Tentacle." I bought it, played it, loved it, and thought of the girl I once loved. 

Today point and click adventure games are still my favorite genre and Day of the Tentacle is the best of them all.

26970740.review:
Si hablamos de aventuras clásicas, sin duda una de ellas es Day of the Tentacle. Esta versión remasterizada nos vuelve a traer, para deleite de nuestros ojos, al trio de héroes en su afán por derrotar al villano tentáculo morado. Hay que jugarlo para apreciarlo en toda su dimensión.

La remasterización creo que es un gran acierto. Mantiene el estilo de dibujo original, tan sólo le han dado un lavado de cara. Y no añadiendo polígonos o simple potencia gráfica, al ser una aventura antigua con imágenes artísticas 2D han rehecho de cero todas las imágenes. El resultado es muy bueno, aunque también es verdad que la aventura original ocupaba unos pocos disquetes de 1.44 MB y ¡¡¡ahora son casi 3.00 GB!!!  :D
(1.00 GB = 1024 MB)

Una nota importante es que, al igual que en la versión original, dentro del juego hay otro juego completo: ¡Maniac Mansion! Este Day of the Tentacle es como la segunda parte. Así que para quienes no probaron la primera bien puedes hacerlo como parte de esta aventura.

Disfrutad de esta joya atemporal.

Nota: Imprescindible  9/10

One of the best point & click adventure games, now in both the original form and a new remastered look with sharp HD visuals, remastered audio, music and sound effects and much more! Everything looks great and it's really refreshing playing it again with the new graphics and all the additions, the game is still a blast to play, I love the story, the amazing art, all the funny scenes and great characters, it's really a recommended game for everyone (unless you really don't like to read much, then point & click games are probably not your cup of tea).

26762697.review:
A faithful recreation of the original classic game. If you're a Lucas Arts/DOTT/point-n-click fan, this is for you - improved audio quality, reworked score and better interfacing bring the game neatly to the 21st century without sacrificing any of the original game's feel and genius.

The high-definition graphics mode will be hit or miss depending on who's asked: Others will definitely prefer the original VGA graphics over the squeaky-clean remastered backgrounds, and I personally felt the character sprites conversion was sloppy and rushed and didn't do the originals justice. It didn't affect the experience otherwise and it was a good call from Double Fine to include the choice - I'm sure there's plenty of people out there who will think the new sprites fit the wonky overall art style of the game. Still more than happy to give this a big fat thumbs up!

26704796.review:
:-/

I'm in the minority, it seems, but this game is ... terrible.  It's a classic case of "figure out what the designer wants you to do" -- down to the fiddly details of exactly what order you click on the relevant objects.

(puzzle spoiler in next paragraph)

For example, at one point I needed to wake someone up by giving them coffee.  I had coffee, but they were asleep, so I needed to use a funnel to make sure I didn't spill it.  (Already absurd.)  So I "use" the coffee "with" the funnel and I'm told "I can't do that, I might spill it."  ... Okay, I guess I'm not doing this right?  Nope!  Needed to use the funnel on the guy first, then use the coffee on the funnel.

(end spoiler)

If you're yearning for a classic, give this a go, I guess.  Otherwise skip it.

Qui siamo all'apoteosi delle avventure grafiche, gli enigmi mettono seriamente alla prova la proria intelligenza e la propria fantasia .Day of the tentacle è il seguito di un'altra avventura grafica storica "Maniac Mansion" che sarà possibile giocare interamente come ester egg nel pc di pazzo ed edison , non vi preoccupate i richiami a Maniac Mansion sono veramente pochi e poco significativi
PRO:
-Rimasterizzazione fatta come si deve al contrario di altre ....
-Enigmi molto divertinte 
-Comicità e carisma dei personaggi 
-Achievement molto belli da scoprire e divertenti da fare
-Possibilità di giocare Maniac Mansion
CONTRO:
-Di negativo non c'è quasi nulla tranne un paio di volte che si è leggermente buggata la grafica
-Avrei gradito un sistema di suggerimenti per i neofiti, anche senza ci si arriva alle soluzioni ma posso immaginare che qualcuno si precluda dal giocare questo capolavoro per la complessità degli enigmi

VOTO: 9/10

26695884.review: I was two years old when this classic point 'n' click adventure released and after more than 20 years I got the chance to enjoy the adventure of Bernard, Laverne, and Hoagie. It's no wonder that so many people have fond memories of this game,  in gameplay and humour Day of the Tentacle hasn't aged a day. It's quite an experience to control three protagonists through three different timelines including interconnected puzzles. I felt great triumph every time I reached the solution to a complex task, not to mention the joy thanks to the great characters and writing. I recommend this game without hesitation to anyone who is interested in good old adventure games!

10 / 10 - A perfect remaster of the perfect point and click adventure.

Comes with Developers commentary - a real time toggle choice between the original version and remastered - and the crem de la creme - It includes the authentic CD version of Maniac Mansion as an ingame extra, fully playable with its own save slots .

In my view this is the very best of Lucas Arts, and its a cleverer , more streamlined experience than the revered Monkey Island.

The mechanics are great, all the puzzles are fair and the jokes and dialogue are just as strong as they were in the 90's - very little is dated.

Well worth the asking price, I feel a little guilty I got as part of a bundle, I hope Double Fine are getting the revenue they deserver for this!!!

I'll keep wishing for more remasters of all the SCUMM games - Especially that bike one I , ah "Full Throttle" - that'd be great!.

Oh and by the way America - Jefferson brings up a great argument for the turkey instead of the Eagle as the US national symbol! And it's spot on!

Ok. time to mosey on to Grim Fandango remastered!

Non conseillé, sauf si vous y avez joué à l'époque et avez apprécié, dans ce cas foncez :).

---

Screens : Triplescreen, dont un vertical, un seul screen X.

26505208.review:
Schon als Kind war ich ein großer Fan dieses Spiels! Zig Male habe ich mir den PC meines Vaters geklaut und meine Freude mit dem Point-and-Click-Adventure gehabt!
Umso mehr habe ich mich gefreut, als von einer Remastered Edition des Spiels die Rede war! So lässt sich das Spiel deutlich einfacher und bequemer auf neueren Rechnern spielen.

Der Hilferuf eines guten Freundes lässt den nerdigen Bernard, die Medizinstudentin Laverne und den 
Heavy-Metal-Freak Hoagie sofort zur Hilfe eilen. Wie sich herausstellt, ist einer der beiden von dem verrückten Wissenschaftler Dr. Fred Edison erschaffenen Tentakel böse geworden und versucht nun die Welt zu erobern und die Menschheit zu versklaven.
Die einzige Möglichkeit den bösen Purpur-Tentakel aufzuhalten ist die Maschine abzuschalten, durch deren Abwasser der Tentakel böse geworden ist.
Doch leider geht die Zeitreisemission ein wenig schief: Hoagie landet mal eben 200 Jahre in der Vergangenheit, während Laverne 200 Jahre in die Zukunft befördert wird. Nur Bernard kommt wieder genau dort hinaus, wo er gestartet ist.
Daraufhin entbrennt eine Schnitzeljagt in drei verschiedenen Zeiten, um die Menschheit vor dem Untergang zu bewahren und um Bernards Freunde wieder zurück in ihre eigene Zeit zu holen.

Day of the Tentacle ist einfach ein Klassiker, den man gespielt haben muss. Der Humor ist genial und die Rätsel, die sogar die Zeitepochen überschreiten, sind einfallsreich und gut gemacht!
Auch die Remastered Edition kann sich sehen lassen (selbst nach kurzer Zeit schon! :D)! Auch, wenn die Bedienung des Spiels ein wenig anders ist, als im Original, fühlt es sich immer noch genauso wie der Klassiker an! Und das in seeehr schickem HD. :D
Ich finde, das Spiel ist ein absolutes Muss für jeden, der Computerspiele mag!

26377119.review:
Day of the Tentacle não é a primeira tentativa de uma remasterização de clássicos da LucasArts. Há não muito tempo, os dois Monkey Island originais receberam um tratamento semelhante, e além da melhoria gráfica, o grande atrativo foi a adição de vozes para os dois jogos, algo que os originais não tinham. Contudo, muitos acharam que a remasterização foi um pouco longe demais, ao deturpar ligeiramente o grafismo, que abraçou por completo um aspeto de desenho-animado.

Não foi isso que aconteceu com Day of the Tentacle. Todos os detalhes gráficos foram redesenhados, frame a frame, mas debaixo de rigorosas limitações. As animações, as cores e a iluminação das cenas mantém-se idênticas, apenas mudou o número de píxeis, o que naturalmente aumentou o nível de qualidade visual. Isto significa que a remasterização é 100% fiel ao original, e tudo está exatamente igual - apenas melhor. Até existe a opção para alternarem entre o aspeto original e o novo, mas parece-nos que ninguém vai usar essa opção, porque a remasterização é perfeita.

Quanto ao departamento sonoro, passou por um processo semelhante. Pegaram nas cassetes de áudio originais e trabalharam-nas para aumentarem a qualidade e retirarem qualquer indício de falhas. Acreditem quando dizemos que a diferença entre o som original e o da remasterização é da noite para o dia. De resto, muito se mantém parecido ou idêntico ao original. A interface foi trabalhada, para se tornar mais prática e acessível, mas mantém todas as funcionalidades originais. E agora até existe a opção para ouvir comentários dos produtores. Quando à jogábilidade, é virtualmente idêntica.

O grande golpe de génio de Day of the Tentacle, e o que realmente distinguiu esta aventura, foi o elemento de viagens no tempo, enquanto resolvem puzzles ao longo de 400 anos. Por exemplo, a personagem que está no futuro não consegue prosseguir porque está bloqueado numa árvore? Basta cortá-la no passado para deixar de existir no futuro. Muitos dos puzzles do jogo atravessam esta lógica temporal, que também vos irá motivar a utilizar os itens de formas pouco convencionais.

Outra das forças de Day of the Tentacle é o facto do jogo ser relativamente compacto. Tudo envolve a mesma mansão, mas em três períodos diferentes. Vão visitar os mesmos quartos, a mesma cave, o mesmo telhado, e assim sucessivamente. Isto significa que nunca têm de percorrer grandes distâncias para chegarem onde pretendem ir. O jogo também consegue manter-se atual em termos de puzzles e história, embora uma situação que envolve uma cassete de vídeo possa apresentar algumas dificuldades para os jogadores mais novos, pouco habituados a essa tecnologia "datada".

[h1]Conclusão[/h1]

Day of the Tentacle Remastered é um ótimo exemplo do trabalho de restauração e preservação histórica no mundo dos videogames. Independente dos 20 anos nas costas, a nova versão tira as amarras do tempo com uma mecânica retrabalhada para os consoles e que se adapta decentemente aos sistemas mais modernos de gameplay, podendo ser aproveitado em sua plenitude pelas novas gerações. Mesmo com alguns puzzles e pequenos problemas técnicos, é nostálgico sem ser ultrapassado, com personagens e uma história carismática. É definitivamente uma ótima viagem no tempo na história dos games.

[h1]+ Prós[/h1]

+ Excelente atualização gráfica. História fantástica de viagens no tempo. Puzzles loucos, mas lógicos.

[h1]Contras[/h1]

-  É um jogo de aventura à antiga, com tudo o que isso tem de bom e mau.

26371149.review:
藉由時光機穿梭時空拯救世界的題材，可以說是屢見不鮮了。但時光機可以是書桌的抽屜 (哆啦A夢梗)，可以是電話亭 (Dr.Who 梗) ，用流動公共廁所就很罕見了吧？
http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=685619527
主角是三個看起來很兩光的遜咖，加上極度偏執工作狂的愛迪生家族，以及不知怎麼搞的就統治世界的可愛反派角色～紫色觸角，巧妙的融合歷史人物軼事，在這棟旅館穿梭時空三百年的不停沖馬桶來拯救世界... 喔喔喔，可見得炒飯人人會做，讓人回味無窮的炒飯卻不是那麼容易做出來的，更何況復刻用的是米倉內的老米 XD
「瘋狂時代」(Day of the Tentacle)這款遊戲是1993年Lucas Arts工作室的作品，細緻流暢的過場動畫(320x200 256色)、動聽的配樂、逗趣的人物和腦洞大開又詼諧的劇情，在當年可是獲得各大遊戲媒體的一致好評喔！
http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=685619399
多年來，不管是DOS版的或是透過ScummVM來回味，難免都會因為化學配方調製圖卡了好久(當年的防拷機制，要翻說明書才有正確答案)。
而這次的重製版蠻阿莎力的拿掉老舊的防拷 (那老方法早就防不了啦 XD )，保留了以前就有的完整版APPLE II的「瘋狂大樓」(Maniac Mansion) ，且人物場景全部配合這個時代用HD重繪，為了增加挑戰性也增加了58個成就，另外還加上原開發小組的語音講評，可以說是誠意十足的復刻了這款遊戲。不管老玩家回味、新玩家瞻仰經典或是成就控的全成就+1，都是相當適合，趁特價或同捆包入手更是不可錯過的好機會。
所以只要廠商有心，就算陳年舊米拿來翻炒還是有一番新滋味的，擁有大量陳年佳作的CAPCOM & SEGA，還不學著點？

25950415.review:
From the pages of the US Gold product catalogue 1994-1995:

Get to grips with Day of the Tentacle(TM)

Inspired by the cartoon styles of Chuck Jones and Maurice Noble, Day of the Tentacle (TM) is the sequel to Maniac Mansion - and it's like notheing else you've ever seen, heard, or played. In one zany adventure you've got bizarre interwoven plots, a liberal dose of outrageous humour, snazzy graphics and a hundred way-out sound effects. Plus that essential element in any big-time arcade adventure - brain busting puzzles. And when you're travelling through time, the paradoxical shenanigans are endless... Or is that beginning-less?

Down at Maniac Mansion, Dr. Fred is cooking up trouble. His beloved Purple Tentacle has gotten hold of some of the mutagenic pollutants oozing out of the doctor's lab. What's more, it's grown arms, not to mention thoughts of global domination.
Enter Bernard, Hoagie, and Laverne - mankind's last chance. In the space of a single night they relese the Tentacle by mistake and spend 400 years timetravelling on the Chron-O-John to save humanity. Day of the Tentacle. It's going to grip you the second you press 'play'.

25926421.review:
The early 90's were a great time for what we now consider as classic point and click games; the retro pixelated artwork, the high level of difficulty, the need for personal critical thinking and complex problem solving. Some didn't become quite as famous as others, leaving them to fall into the void of cult-classic status, remembered by their appreciative yet relatively small fanbase. Such can be said about Day of the Tentacle, a zany point and click adventure game from LucasArts from 1993, now Remastered with smooth high-definition art and sound thanks to Double Fine Productions.

For those who're already familiar with the game, I'll go ahead and start out with the Remastered stuff. The artwork is all hand-drawn; it looks fantastic, and it's very smooth. The color is extremely vibrant, and the gradients transition so much better thanks to how far technology has come within the last two-plus decades. Not to mention the wonderful use of lighting and angles that really make the artwork stand out above many other point and click games. The interface has also been updated to modern standards, and it's much more user-friendly than the old one. You have the option to transition from the original graphics, and sound, to the Remastered ones all throughout the game; one can even mix and match if they so desire, old graphics/new sounds or new graphics/old sounds. There's also a developer commentary available to those who're interested, and bonus content in the main menu. It's an incredibly solid Remaster, in functionality, performance, and design. I noticed that some people in the review section had problems with the audio, such as stuttering or other characters voices playing. I believe that the last patch, noted as June 1st, 2016, took care of these problems as I didn't experience any audio issues whatsoever. 

Day of the Tentacle is a sequel to another highly favorable point and click LucasArts game, Maniac Mansion. At the start of the game a scene occurs where two Tentacles, Green and Purple, are standing beside a radiated river. Purple Tentacle decides to take a sip of the toxic sludge coming out from the sewers, and he begins to mutate; a mutation so inconceivable and horrific at that... he grows... arms. In his new superior form, Purple Tentacle turns into an evil genius and begins scheming to have his army of Tentacles to take over the world. One of the main characters, Bernard, is friends with Green Tentacle, who lets Bernard know of Purple Tentacle's intents. Bernard gathers his two best friends, Hoagie and Laverne, in an effort to stop the evil plot.

What follows are events of wacky cartoon mayhem and eccentric wit. The dialogue and actions of the characters are absolutely hilarious, garnering more than a few laugh-out-loud moments from me personally; which I must say is hard to achieve, I'm more of a chuckler/internal laugher. Bernard is your typical know-it-all nerd, Hoagie is a heavy metal roadie, and Laverne is just out of her mind. You'll even get to interact with the founding fathers quite a bit, and the Tentacles are as memorable as they are priceless. Beyond question, it's an adventure that you really must seek for yourself.

Probably the only downfall that one could find about Day of the Tentacle are some of its nonsensical puzzle solutions. This again stems from the 90's era of point and click gameplay, though, and it's to be expected from a title that originally launched so long ago. A guide is highly recommended, as the game really is extremely cryptic with some of its puzzles. There are also dialogue conundrums that can sometimes only be solved by performing an event and then going to talk to the person again. However, some people still like their games mystifying and complex, so if you're one of those self-punishing loonies, you'll absolutely enjoy this game in its entirety.

Whether or not you played Day of the Tentacle back in 1993, you'll absolutely love this absurd, unpredictable, humorous experience. It's one of those classic games that are up there with Grim Fandago in the "you shouldn't miss this" category. Double Fine Productions have done a bang-up job on this Remaster, and they've presented in a way that lets the original design shine through, while also making it obvious that the remake was crafted by them; if only all recent remastered editions were this good. While $16.99 CAD is pretty steep for a 4 hour adventure, grabbing this game on sale for half off is a great idea.

25844587.review:
La entrada original podéis encontrarla en

https://thepastisnow.net/2016/09/20/maniac-mansion-el-dia-del-tentaculo-purpura-contra-todos/ 

Este juegazo de LucasArts de 1993 es la segunda parte del mítico Maniac Mansion (1987), gracias a Double Fine, 23 años después, podemos volver a jugarlo en una edición remasterizada, desde Marzo de 2016, que además nos permite ir cambiando al juego original simplemente pulsando un botón.

¡Estos locos Edison nos han vuelto a liar! Verde ha escrito a su amigo Bernard (ese friki que parece Steve Urkel versión blanco) porque Púrpura, ha bebido agua contaminada y esto ha provocado el crecimiento de un par de brazos y un plan para conquistar el mundo!

¡Púrpura se ha vuelto loco y ha escapado!

En  este ordenador puedes jugar a Maniac Mansion 1.

Este título salió durante una época conocida como “la época dorada de las aventuras gráficas” de la mano de Dave Grossman y Tim Schafer (quién además es el fundador de Double Fine) y utiliza un sistema de verbos a través de los cuales ejecutamos acciones para ir desarrollando el juego. Este sistema, se llama SCUMM que son las siglas de  Script Creation Utility for Maniac Mansion ya que se desarrolló para la primera parte de Manic Mansion.

Bernard era uno de los compañeros de Dave en la primera aventura en la mansión de los Edison.
Bernard, acompañado de sus amigos Hoagie y Lavergne, se dispondrá entonces a detener a Púrpura en su loco plan. El profesor Edison, creador de los tentáculos, les enviará al pasado para detener a Púrpura antes de que beba el agua contaminada.

Hasta aquí parece muy fácil, montar en la Cron-O-Letrina (con ese nombre, no hubiera accedido JAMÁS) volver un día en el tiempo y acabar con ese renacuajo, pero… algo sale mal y acaba cada uno en una época diferente de la mansión, pasado, presente y futuro.

Este detalle es lo que realmente me llamó la atención de El día del tentáculo, como las acciones que hacemos en las diferentes épocas tienen repercusión, detalles como talar un árbol para que desaparezca en el futuro o dar un mapa de anatomía tentacular a Betsy Ross (que tejió la bandera de Estados Unidos).

La Mansión Edison recogió grandes momentos históricos.
 
Con un humor muy ácido que te hará reír a carcajadas en tu silla comentario a comentario, situaciones increíbles y guiños con grandes sagas de LucasArts/LucasFilm que te seguirán por todo el juego (desde Star Wars a Sam & Max, pasando por Monkey Island) consigue hacer que te intereses por cada línea de texto de cada personaje.

Las animaciones son muy buenas, estética Cartoon, muy similar a Sam & Max, llenas de vida y color, con mucha sensación de movimiento, consiguiendo sumergirte en el juego. Al arrancar la edición Remastered, es curioso que te da la sensación de que el juego era así, y no ha envejecido, cuando cambié a la versión original, pude comprobar que el juego no había envejecido nada pero que nada mal.

Aquí os dejo algunas imágenes en comparativa sobre la versión original y la versión Remastered, algunos de vosotros me habéis pedido que indique donde se pueden obtener los juegos o como jugarlos hoy en día, pues bien, este juego esta disponible en Steam en su versión remastered, y en la misma se puede alternar con la versión original.

Da igual que versión juegues, un ejercito de tentáculos púrpura va a conquistar tu ordenador.
Hace poco, encontré unos Alemanes, que están desarrollando una secuela Return of the tentacle, que espero que aunque sea en inglés, podamos probarlo con nuestros propios tentáculos con nuestras propias manos.

En definitiva, es una aventura gráfica clásica point and click en la que hablaremos con muchísimos personajes y acumularemos muchos objetos que utilizaremos entre sí y con el entorno (algunos nunca sabremos que utilidad tienen).

Vale vale, salid ahí y jugadlo si aún no lo habéis hecho!
 
¿Y tu? ¿Conseguiste librar al mundo del malvado plan del tentáculo púrpura?

¡¡¡Nos vemos pronto!!!

25701653.review:
This is my first time playing through Day of Tentacle so I can’t truly compare it to the original entirely, but the remastering looks real good to me. Double Fine even added some modern conveniences such as a hotspot button.

Now I’m usually not a fan of old school adventure game puzzles, even in old school adventure games I adore such as Longest Journey and Gabriel Knight 1 I had to keep going back to guides because I hated some of the puzzles. Day of the Tentacle surprised me in that I only had to use a guide towards the very end, most of the puzzles make sense, and if even they don’t the game gives you some hints if you explore enough to help you along. The only really bad part is one piece of pixel hunting, but if you use the hotspot button you should be fine. (I didn’t, so that’s why I hit a brick wall) It’s almost like a modern adventure game in that the game’s puzzles don’t actively hate you and fit with what you’re doing. The time travel conceit makes the puzzle solving fun and the game is quite funny. It’s overall a real good game that still holds up more than twenty years later.

25517466.review:
[h1]A brief overview...[/h1]

[b]Goal:[/b] To stop an evil triangle from taking over the world.

[b]Method:[/b] Travel back in time to the day before so that you can stop the triangle from becoming evil in the first place. However, the majority of the story revolves around blowing a large sum of money on a shopping channel product, and finding sources of electricity that you can plug toilets into.

[b]Heroes:[/b] The true heroes of this game are a metalhead who has zero book smarts, a trainee doctor who cannot be trusted with her own scalpel, and that nerd from the first game who used to be a coward. This trio receives help along the way from an ex-villain mad scientist, the founding fathers, a hamster, and a dead guy.

[b]Events:[/b] This game lets you rob a vending machine, strike up conversations with historical figures, break out of jail, play numerous practical jokes on people, set off a fire alarm, throw a dead man down the stairs, throw a live woman down the stairs, cause it to rain at your own will, have way too much fun in a beauty pageant, and seek revenge on an inflatable clown.


[h1]... and now, let's get serious![/h1]

Day of the Tentacle is my favourite game of all time, so I guess ever since this remaster was announced I've had something of a positivity bias towards it. Why do I love the game so much? Wow... where do I start? The game is set in a cartoon world with fitting art and music, where slapstick humour is abundant. It is one of the few games that truly makes me feel like I am "playing" a cartoon. Mix that with everything you can expect from a LucasArts adventure game (y'know, stealing various items, getting creative with how you use items together, doing terrible things to NPCs just to get closer to your goal), and you are in for a treat.

Despite its Saturday Morning Cartoon setting, the puzzles are actually logical and very well thought out. What really makes the puzzles special in this game is its time travel element; most of the game deals with the three protagonists separated from each other in different time periods. Hoagie is stranded way back in colonial times, Laverne has ended up in a tentacle-ruled future, and Bernard is back in the present (well, the '90s). Naturally, your actions in one time period could have a direct effect on a later one. For example, Hoagie can change a significant part of American history in order to make Laverne's life (four hundred years later) much easier. See where I'm going with this?

Like I've already said, the graphics and music fit the game's cartoon atmosphere wonderfully. Even the original version of the game is fully voice acted (well, the CD-ROM version... those voiceover files wouldn't fit on the floppy disk version!) and that was a big deal back in 1993. The voice acting is done to a professional standard, and stars Richard Sanders (from WKRP in Cincinnati) as Bernard. Sound effects are typically cartoony, dialogue is well written, it's great fun exploring the mansion in three different moments in time (which is very well designed), and the characters are just amazing. I love them all.

Oh, and get this... the original Maniac Mansion (DOTT's prequel) is included and fully playable. So you're basically getting two awesome adventure games for the price of one.


[h1]What's new in the remaster?[/h1]

Those pixelly graphics from the '90s have all been redrawn - but not redesigned - so they look exactly as you remember them, except much cleaner! This has allowed artists to pay certain attention to detail that couldn't be done back when working with so few pixels; signs and other items have additional text on them now. One of my personal favourites is what the sign above the lobby door says. Also, smoother panning when the screen scrolls. Music has been digitally remastered too, for a more modern sound. Higher quality sound effects are in place, and the original, uncompressed voice over recordings have been used. The interface has been remastered too, and you can now play the game with a verb dial that has excluded the verbs considered "useless" on the item you are interacting with.

However, if you want to see the old graphics, hear the old music, or use the old interface, all of those options are there too! Unlike other remasters and special editions I've played, this one has a much more customizable experience. You don't have to use all the original settings at once or all the remastered settings; instead you can mix and match. You might want to see the new graphics, but hear the old music. Or perhaps you want pixel graphics while using the new verb dial. You can select each setting separately, letting you play exactly how you want.

When playing for your first time, you will unlock concept art as you progress further into the game and enter more and more scenes. Developer commentary is available; when starting a new game, you will be asked whether you want commentary on or off, but you can toggle it at any time in the main menu too. The Steam version also includes a great set of achievements, as well as trading cards and all the perks that come with those. Also, as can be expected in any modern computer game... [i]autosave[/i].

The first Maniac Mansion is playable like it's always been, but instead of the C64 version included with the original release of DOTT, the remaster includes the Amiga version, so the graphics and audio are notably better quality.

For newcomers, controls are displayed at the start of the game, and can also be found on the options screen (something the original didn't really have). Back when the game was first released, you were expected to read the manual. Or not. Whichever came first.


[h1]The final verdict...[/h1]

Am I recommending this game? Of [i]course[/i] I am! The biggest complaint I can come up with is that some of the remastered sound effects aren't as funny as the original ones (especially that new Hoagie belch sound... I'm sorry but that's nowhere [i]near[/i] as hilarious as the old one). So if that's the best I can come up with... I must be really impressed with this game overall! Remastered graphics that make the game more appealing to a contemporary audience without losing the original's charm, concept art and developer commentary for the hardcore fans, and perhaps most importantly, an accessible way for new customers to get their hands on the awesomeness that is Day of the Tentacle.

[b]An excellent remaster of a most excellent game![/b]

25428321.review:
[url=http://fabereview.blogspot.it/2016/09/maniac-mansion-deluxe.html]Recensione  Maniac Mansion Deluxe[/url]

Seguito di Maniac mansion, Day of the tentacle ci dovrà far visita di nuovo alla famiglia Edison e alla loro casa.
Prima di tutto si, potete giocarvelo tranquillamente anche senza aver giocato a Maniac mansion (ci saranno poche frasi dove ci riporteranno all'altro gioco.)

[b]A livello personale è il mio punta e clicca preferito.[/b]
Mi è sempre piaciuto l'argomento del viaggio nel tempo, e vedere che in questo gioco si può stare contemporaneamente nel passato, presente e futuro, l'ho trovato geniale.
A livello di gameplay è abbastanza complicato, sia per gli enigmi/rompicapo demenziali tipici di Ron Gilbert, sia per il fatto che dovremmo usare 3 personaggi diversi e farci passare gli oggetti di continuo.
Comunque una cosa è certa, non sarà difficile come Maniac mansion (essendo uscito pure anni dopo): qui non si potrà morire.

[b]Per quanto riguarda la trama del gioco[/b] è abbastanza simpatica: Il tentacolo viola (apparso precedentemente in Maniac Mansion),  beve dei rifiuti tossici di una macchina, facendoli cresce delle braccia e facendolo diventare intelligente così tanto da voler conquistare il mondo.
Il nostro compito sarà quello di tornare indietro nel tempo di un giorno spegnendo la macchina che produce i rifiuti tossici. Ovviamente la macchina del tempo del dottor fred avrà dei problemi, e invece che farli tornare indietro di un giorno i nostri protagonisti li faranno viaggiare nel passato e nel futuro (l'altro personaggio è rimasto nel presente).
Quindi il nostro scopo principale del gioco sarà quello di far funzionare le macchine del tempo.

C'è subito da precisare che la grafica è molto cartoonesca, i colori sono molto accessi, e momenti di comicità non macheranno. Esattamente l'opposto dell'atmosfera di Maniac mansion.
C'è anche da dire che qua  l'unico protagonista che compare è solo il secchione Bernard, gli altri due personaggi che lo accompagneranno non si sono mai visti nel gioco precedente.

Ora passiamo al piatto forte del gioco, ovvero [b]"La remastered".[/b]

Non mi garba molto l'idea delle remastered dei giochi, su alcune sono d'accordo ma sinceramente su day of tentacle... potevano evitare.
Non lo sto dicendo perchè hanno fatto un brutto lavoro, ma perchè con tutte le loro avventure grafiche che avevano potevano concentrarci su giochi un po' più vecchi.
Comunque il cambiamento principale è la grafica, l'hanno migliorata non mettendola a pixel, ed hanno fatto un buon lavoro.
Hanno rimasterizzato pure la soundtrack e pure li hanno fatto un lavoro più che buono.
Ma sopratutto per gli appassionati del gioco ci saranno i commenti degli sviluppatori, sono veramente tantissimi e anche molto interessanti.

[b]Conclusione:[/b] Il gioco in questione come ho scritto prima è la mia avventura grafica preferita, quindi vi consiglio di giocarla se siete appassionati del genere (anche se penso che ormai la conoscano quasi tutti).

[b]Voto 9/10[/b]

PS: [b]come nella vecchia versione sarà possibile giocare all'originale maniac mansion.[/b] Purtroppo la lingua è solo in inglese.
[b]Per giocarvelo in italiano provate a scaricarvi la versione classica o la deluxe su internet.[/b]

25401977.review:
Le monde (des amateurs de point'n'click) se divise en deux catégories : d'un côté, ceux qui ne jurent que par [i][b]Day of the Tentacle[/b][/i] ; de l'autre, ceux qui n'y ont jamais joué.

Je vais être honnête, je n'ai pas fait l'original ([i]pas lyncher, pitié...[/i]). En général, tout remastérisés qu'ils soient, ces anciens jeux accusent leur âge, surtout quand on les compare aux productions actuelles. Et pourtant... ce [i][b]Day of the Tentacle[/b][/i]-là - un papi de presque 25 ans, pardonnez du peu ! - n'a pas à rougir de sa performance. Loin s'en faut ! En l'état, il n'a rien à envier aux point'n'click récents. Autant dire que cette version est un franc succès.

Difficile de lui trouver des défauts : un gameplay certes basique pour le genre (qui a toutefois le mérite d'éviter les lourdeurs), des graphismes très propres, une bande son excellente, le tout dans un univers complètement déjanté. Qui plaira sans nul doute aux amateurs de [url=http://steamcommunity.com/profiles/76561198164382571/recommended/214340][i][b]Deponia[/b][/i][/url] et autres [url=http://steamcommunity.com/profiles/76561198164382571/recommended/255320][i][b]Edna & Harvey[/b][/i][/url]. Rien qu'un bémol : ici ou là, quelques problèmes infimes ([i]non, pas le pouce vers le bas, pitié...[/i]) de synchro textes/dialogues, avec des pauses dans l'un dues à la lenteur de l'autre. Anecdotique, en somme.

Bref, en ce qui me concerne, cette version remasterisée confirme le statut culte de [i][b]Day of the Tentacle[/b][/i]. Si vous non plus ne vous étiez pas encore penché sur son cas, sachez qu'il n'est jamais trop tard...

[h1]Verdict : ∞/5 - A sa place au panthéon des jeux vidéos ![/h1]

25267765.review:
I used to play this game all the time as a child, but it's a sad thing you're urged to buy a digital copy; because with every new Windows release, the amount of old games you can play decreases.

Nevertheless, I'm a loyal fan.

When I started playing the game, the first thing I noticed is that the "HD remake" was not worth it. The pixelated artwork has a charm that the, honestly, cheaply redrawn HD images do not. It looks like it was drawn with Adobe Flash, and I was disappointed to see they didn't even bother to make the mouth movements fit the dialogue or improved the animations to make the new style fit. 24475467.review:
Hach, das Spiel war Nostalgie pur! Lang, lang ist es her als ich irgendwann 1993 als junger kleiner Bub das Original spielte. Als großer Fan der Lucasfilm / LucasArts Adventures habe ich seinerzeit natürlich deren erstes Adventure Maniac Mansion und den genialen Nachfolger Day of the Tentacle gespielt. Das war damals ein echt großes Ding - sogar mit Sprachausgabe (ein Novum) ;)

Jetzt habe ich mich nochmals durch das Anwesen gekämpft und hatte viele schöne Momente, die mich an früher erinnerten. Allerdings musste ich auch ganz schön knobeln, da ich mich an die Rätsel im Detail eigentlich gar nicht mehr erinnern konnte. Und da ich aber den verdrehten Stil von LucasArts noch kannte, bin ich auch ganz gut weitergekommen. Wer nicht viel um die Ecke denkt, bleibt hier und da vielleicht ein wenig hängen. Die Rätsel sind zwar im Prinzip nachvollziehbar, aber eben auch recht abgedreht. 

Aber heutzutage ist das ja kein Problem mehr. Wer will kann ja im Internet nachschauen, solchen Luxus gab es damals noch nicht. Und ich habe mir wirklich öfters die Haare gerauft, weil ich einfach nicht weiterkam. :) Empfehlen würde ich habe nicht nachzuschauen, da sonst der Flair der Rätzel ein wenig verblast.

Technisch ist das Spiel nett gemacht, meiner Meinung nach ein zeitloser Comic Stil. Es sieht stimmig und atmosphärisch aus (typischer LucasArts-Stil), der Sound ist ok, die Sprachausgabe klingt allerdings doch ein wenig aufgesetzt und (unter heutiger Betrachtung) teilweise nicht gut. Insgesamt ist Day of the Tentacle wunderbar spielbar und sieht nicht aus wie ein Spiel aus der Mottenkiste. Als netten Gag kann man - wie auch schon bei den beiden neuen Versionen von Monkey Island - jederzeit mit F1 zur alten Originalgrafik (inkl. der ganzen typischen SCUMM-Verben) umschalten. Das gefällt - und alle jüngeren Spieler können mal sehen, welche Grafik wir damals gefeiert haben... :)

Jedem LucasArts-Fan kann man das Spiel wohl blind empfehlen. Meiner Meinung nach ist es aber auch komplett losgelöst davon wunderbar spielbar und einfach auch heute noch ein gutes Adventure.

Meine Wertung: 
Grafik: 8/10
Sound: 6/10
Umfang: 7/10
Atmosphäre: 10/10

24438081.review:
I have very fond memories about Day of the Tentacle (DotT), back in the DOS days, Lucasarts was my favourite games company, their adventures were the best and their Star Wars games are pretty legendary in their own right. DotT is one of those games that was released when PC gained its status as superiour gaming platform. All previous adventures games still got released on multiple platforms (think Amiga etc), but not this one. It was also released on CDROM and the whole game features voice acting, pretty big deal back in the day.

And so, with rose tinted glasses I started playing this game, would it still be as good as I remembered it? Or would it turn out to be one of those classics that didn't age well, like a fine wine turning into vinegar. Well I can assure you, that none of the magic is lost. The game is still very much fun today, everything still stands, it only lost some of its freshness, but that was to be expected as it's a remaster that stays 100% faithfull to the original.

I'm also very happy that they did not change any of the graphics. When I learned that the Monkey Island series were rereleased, I was excited. Until I saw it at a friend of mine, that is when disappointment set in. They changed the graphics and the new graphics just didn't do it for me, in fact they were a big turn-off. If you never played the game before, you probably would have no issue with it, but the problem for me was that they changed too much. You could still play the original graphics, but what is the point of that? You could just as easily use ScummVM then.
This is not the case with DotT, the graphics have been retained. To be honest, the graphics had been retained as how I remembered them. There is a big difference, how we remember things is not how they really were, it's just our minds that make the memory more beautiful than it really is. In this case the remastered graphics just look like the originals with 100x Anti-Aliasing applied on them.

I was able to quickly finish the game as I still remembered a lot and the things i forgot were quickly figured out. You should not read any guides, as this will increase the enjoyment of an adventure game, the whole point is to figure these things out after all.

This game had a big impact on me as a youngster, I forgot how many things in the game I picked up in my vocabulairy and still use, though i completely forgot where they came from - this game!

Take this as you will, some guy has fond memories of an old game, the remastered version of said game is also liked by him. Does this mean it's a great game or that the guy is senile? That's up for you to decide when you're GOING BACK TO THE MANSION!

The game works flawlessly on SteamOS/Linux, the default Steam Controller setup is a bit weird, but ofcourse you can change it to your liking. Streams to the Steam Link without problems (great way to play the game btw).

I played this game in the 90s when I was budding gamer, and I have fond memories. I grabbed this game for $8.99 the other day basically for nostalgia. I wasn't sure if I'd actually like the game again - would I find it too silly? too easy? plain boring? BUT, it is actually a fun little puzzle game. I was cruising along for a while, half playing the game and half strolling down memory lane, and then I actually got stuck. I'll admit I've had to use google a couple times. Some of the puzzles actually make you think. My advice: click on EVERYTHING. Pick up ALL objects. Listen to what the people are saying - they often drop hints. Go back and re-explore areas - it's easy to overlook something that you thought was meaningless. As for the remaster side of things - it's perfect. The new graphics are how I remember the game looking back when graphics weren't superduperHD. The new controls are simple and easy, and the new sound is good.

All in all, this is a good remaster of a classic game. If you played this game in the 90s, I *definitely* recommend getting this.

24282076.review:
Getting this remastered version of Day of the Tentacle is worth it. Not only have the backgrounds and sprites been redrawn to more closely resemble Peter Chan's original drawings and paintings, but the nutjobs working on this actually dug up all the audio tapes containing the voicework, re-digitalized them in higher quality, and then sliced and re-organized them and put them back into the game. Crazy. As in most of these Remastered game editions, you can switch to the old pixely graphics by pressing F1, which also switches you to more classical midi tunes instead of the slightly smoother music you get now.

My favorite addition, though, are the commentaries by the original team working on Day of the Tentacle. You'll get insight in how the game was made, and especially how they had to wrestle with the limitations forced on them by PC technology of the era.

It's a very lovingly done project, and while Day of the Tentacle isn't even my favorite Lucasarts adventure, I really enjoyed revisiting it like this. And if you're wondering, you can still play the entirety of Maniac Mansion inside this game!

24155710.review:
Was gibt es über DotT noch viel zu sagen?
Das Spiel selbst ist ein wohlbekannter Klassiker mit sehr witziger Handlung und liebevoll gezeichneten Grafiken. Die zu lösenden Aufgaben können dann und wann etwas knifflig sein, insbesondere für ältere Veteranen stellen sie aber kein großes Problem dar.
Die aufgehübschte Neufassung ist sehr gut gelungen. Trotz aufpolierter Grafik geht der Charme der Orginalgrafiken nicht verloren. Und wer dann und wann doch Sehnsucht nach dem Orginial-Feeling verspürt, kann ja im laufenden Spiel einfach umschalten. Das ist zwar nett, für mich aber ziemlich unnötig gewesen. :-D Ein nützliches neues Feature hingegen ist die Möglichkeit, anklickbare Bereiche sichtbar zu machen, indem man Shift gedrückt hält. Das erhöht die Spielbarkeit doch ungemein, da man nicht mehr den ganzen Schirm absuchen muss. Die überarbeitete Maussteuerung bei der man die möglichen Aktionen nach einem Rechtsklick auswählen kann, ist auch gut umgesetzt und entspricht gewohntem Standard.
Wie in der Originalfassung kann man auch wieder ManiacMansion spielen. Dort wurde allerdings außer dem Speicher-Menü nichts verändert, so dass der Unterschied zu DotT auf die Grafiken und den Spielkomfort bezogen noch größer ausfällt als früher. Ich denke, man muss schon alter Veteran sein, um sich diese nette Pixelschlacht noch einmal anzutun. :-D
Nettes neues Beiwerk sind die Achievements, die teilweise auf die ein oder andere Text-Perle hinweisen.

Alles in allem gibt es von mir für das kurzweilige (und auch leider viel zu kurze) Spiel eine klare Kaufempfehlung. Jeder, der witzige Click&Point-Adventures mag, sollte DotT haben!

24091085.review:
Ah la la, Day of the Tentacle, un classique incroyable de Lucasarts que je viens seulement de faire, en fait je n'ai pas beaucoup joué à ce genre de jeu étant un peu trop jeune à l'époque, ce genre de jeux n'était déjà plus à la mode dans les années 2000, et oui j'étais jeune dans les années 2000 et je n'ai pas connu le Club Dorothée ou certaines autres merveilleuses choses mais il y avait quand même Digimon, Pokémon et les jeux vidéos pour se rattraper ! Souvenez-vous de la trilogie du Samedi sur M6 ? Ou de la Nintendo 64 ou les jeux ne démarraient pas s'il y avait de la poussière dans la cartouche, d'Ocarina of Time et de son Open World (quoiqu'un peu vide du aux limitations cartouches mais passons), etc... 
Et je comprends très bien pourquoi ce jeu est devenu culte et a rendu Lucasarts ultra célèbre, tout a la classe, les graphismes sont incroyables et même si simplistes, ultra vivants, avec des couleurs ultra intenses, on a vraiment l'impression de participer à un cartoon interactif de la belle époque de la Warner, les Bugs Bunny, Bip Bip et Coyote, Sylvestre et Titi mènent l'enquête, etc... ou même les vieux Nickelodeon comme Hey! Arnold ou les Razmokets, etc...
La musique est elle aussi assez sympas quoique le MIDI ne m'excite plus trop en 2016 !
Des dialogues incroyables avec un niveau d'écriture dingue, des énigmes complétement barrées, j'en ai eu ras le bol assez rapidement, j'ai du utiliser une solution assez rapidement pour ne pas rester bloquer comme un con pendant 1000 ans. Un doublage incroyable et un humour devenu culte ! Petit défaut cependant, la fin qui selon moi aurait mérité bien plus d'attention, assez expéditive et un jeu trop court !
Pour ce qui est de ce Remaster, tous ne se valent pas, mon coups de coeur va pour ceux de Square Enix, les Kingdom Hearts ont d'excellent remasters pour ne citer qu'eux ! J'aime aussi les remasters de la série Sly de la PS2 ! 
La musique est toujours la même, mais les graphismes passent mieux en HD même si Double Fine a eu la main un peu forte sur les filtres graphiques, du beau travail ! 
Jouez-y ! C'est un ordre ! Un des meilleurs jeux de tous les temps ! Peut-être un peu trop overrated à mon goût ?

23611737.review:
[h1] Review Day of the Tentacle Remastered [/h1]

Hach, das Spiel war Nostalgie pur! Lang, lang ist es her als ich irgendwann 1993 als junger Erwachsener das Original spielte. Als großer Fan der Lucasfilm / LucasArts Adventures habe ich seinerzeit natürlich deren erstes Adventure Maniac Mansion und den genialen Nachfolger Day of the Tentacle gespielt. Das war damals ein echt großes Ding - sogar mit Sprachausgabe (ein Novum) ;)

Jetzt habe ich mich nochmals durch das Anwesen gekämpft und hatte viele schöne Momente, die mich an früher erinnerten. Allerdings musste ich auch ganz schön knobeln, da ich mich an die Rätsel im Detail eigentlich gar nicht mehr erinnern konnte. Und da ich aber den verdrehten Stil von LucasArts noch kannte, bin ich auch ganz gut weitergekommen. Wer nicht viel um die Ecke denkt, bleibt hier und da vielleicht ein wenig hängen. Die Rätsel sind zwar im Prinzip nachvollziehbar, aber eben auch recht abgedreht. 

Aber heutzutage ist das ja kein Problem mehr. Wer will kann ja im Internet nachschauen, solchen Luxus gab es damals noch nicht. Und ich habe mir wirklich öfters die Haare gerauft, weil ich einfach nicht weiter kam. :)

Technisch ist das Spiel nett gemacht, wenn auch keine Offenbarung. Es sieht stimmig und atmosphärisch aus (typischer LucasArts-Stil), der Sound ist ok, die Sprachausgabe klingt allerdings doch ein wenig aufgesetzt und (unter heutiger Betrachtung) teilweise nicht gut. Insgesamt ist Day of the Tentacle wunderbar spielbar und sieht nicht aus wie ein Spiel aus der Mottenkiste. Als netten Gag kann man - wie auch schon bei den beiden neuen Versionen von Monkey Island - jederzeit mit F1 zur alten Originalgrafik (inkl. der ganzen typischen SCUMM-Verben) umschalten. Das gefällt - und alle jüngeren Spieler können mal sehen, welche Grafik wir damals gefeiert haben... :)

Jedem LucasArts-Fan kann man das Spiel wohl blind empfehlen. Meiner Meinung nach ist es aber auch komplett losgelöst davon wunderbar spielbar und einfach auch heute noch ein gutes Adventure.

[b] Meine Wertung: [/b]
Grafik: 7/10
Sound: 5/10
Umfang: 8/10
Atmosphäre: 10/10

[b] Spielspaß: 87% [/b]

23603139.review:
A fantastic remastering of my all-time favorite point-and-click adventure game. A significant portion of my youthful gaming time was spent on LucasArts and Sierra adventure games, but DOTT was always my favorite and this version is stellar. The updated art is fantastic, the sound quality is solid, and everything ran well. I will absolutely continue to buy all of the remasters of old LucasArts adventure games if they maintain the quality that is present here and in the Monkey Island remasters.

So what if you don't have a nostalgic love of this game from 20 years ago or even a love of point-and-click adventure games? You should still play it. If for nothing else, the story and characters are entertaining enough to warrant a playthrough. Most of the jokes still made me laugh and it's just a fun world to be in.

23428238.review:
I went in to this game a little skeptical since I'd never player it at release and the design in some older adventure games has aged poorly. Turns out this is actually the masterpiece that everyone has always said it is, no nostalgia required!

After a short intro the game opens up a dozen rooms that can be explored in the past, present, and future. Most of the items in your inventory can be sent across time periods to solve puzzles, while others are done by taking actions in the past that change the future. It's easy to make forward progress and everything is rewarded with beautiful cartoony animations. The amount of detail in the visuals and audio must have been insanely expensive at the time and is a rare treat.

My biggest gripe is that eventually you'll hit the wall of not being able to make progress with no hint system or obvious direction. Why do you read a boring book to a horse to make it fall asleep? Maybe there's a joke or reference there I'm missing, but it doesn't seem to make any sense without looking it up. It's also annoying, and hopefully not intentional, that the game has 3 different sets of false teeth that could be interchangeable, but are all used for completely different solutions.

The UI overhaul works great and really streamlines problems with the old verb system. And of course you can flip between the old and new at any time to compare.

23363011.review:
[h1]A perfect remaster for a nearly perfect adventure game[/h1]

This game was formative for me. Not only was it the first adventure game I played, it also introduced me to a lot of American cultural staples. And its humour helped shape mine.

DOTT is a sort-of-sequel to Maniac Mansion, an older game (which is playable inside DOTT, by the way!). Friends Bernard, Laverne and Hoagie must travel back in time - courtesy of a shoddy time machine by Dr Fred - to prevent Purple Tentacle from gaining super intelligence (and arms!) and conquering the world. Instead, our three protagonists are accidentally scattered across time - far past, present and far future - and have to both rescue themselves and accomplish their original goal.
That's a summary of the silly premise, and the game is just as silly.

How that translates in terms of gameplay is that you have three playable characters occupying the same space - a motel where the events of the game take place - but at different periods in history. You control all three, solving puzzles, sometimes affecting the future, and sending items back and forth among them via the time machine.
This all makes your typical point-and-click puzzle solving a bit more interesting, as you need to think about what all three characters need and remember what items and NPCs and puzzles each version of the motel contains.

As for this modern remaster, I'm very happy to say they did an excellent job. It is basically how we imagine the original version in our minds. The music is also remastered, but I prefer the original. Lucky for everyone, the original art and music (and interface) are included and can be mixed and matched at will. I played modern art & interface with original music.

[b]What I enjoyed[/b]
[list]
[*]Triple the playable characters, triple the puzzles, triple the inventory, etc.
[*]Cartoony, funny, and not obnoxious (you hear that, Deponia?)
[*]The remastered art is excellent, making the whole game widescreen and crisp looking.
[*]The new radial action menu is a huge improvement on the old action bar, allowing for faster play while keeping the variety of options that give you all sorts of fun dialogue.
[/list]
[b]What I didn't like[/b]
[list]
[*]This being an early 90s adventure game, the puzzles can be nonsensical sometimes - you have to apply "comedy logic" to some of them, which can get frustrating.
[*]All the things you have to do across all the characters can get a bit overwhelming sometimes and you might forget what to do next. I'd suggest playing this game in as few sessions as possible, because you will forget stuff otherwise. Maybe take notes.
[/list]

I just relived a piece of my childhood, and it was just as good.

23337052.review:
I cannot believe my good fortune that this game popped up on my screen the moment I logged into Steam today. This (and LucasArts' Indiana Jones: The Fate of Atlantis) was my favorite DOS game of all time back in the 90's so I bought this immediately. I'm pretty sure I still have the original CD lying around somewhere. If I find it, i'll upload it in the Artwork section for the game.

Needless to say, nostalgia can be a cruel mistress, especially nostalgia from 3 decades ago. Not so in the case of LucasArts DOS games. His company's products were always ahead of their time. I personally feel that the cartoonish graphics of this game still hold up today (and they did a great job with the remastering!), and from what I remember, the puzzles in this game were not only challenging (not impossibly so) but there was a lot to do and figure out. And they were [i]interesting[/i] puzzles. I still remember how it took me forever to figure out how to get the fake rubber barf off the ceiling. Awesome! I now had fake barf in my possession! Now what do I do with that!? xD

The voice acting was also superb. Instead of always using the bland, "I can't do that." or "That won't work." kind of line when trying to figure out object combinations and placements, you are greeted with lines like, "My therapist told me I'm not allowed to play with sharp objects." followed by maniacal guffawing. These are the kinds of things that stick with you and add so much charm to this game.

So, the basics:

[quote]This game is the sequal to the 1987 game Maniac Mansion and takes place 5 years after the events of the first game. It is a single-player point-and-click adventure that originally came out in 1993. You do not need to have played the first game in order to enjoy or understand the events in this one.

Plot:

There are two living, breathing tentacles that are wandering around. Purple Tentacle ends up drinking some radioactive sludge that mutates him into having arms so he feels he can now take over the world. His brother, Green Tentacle, tries to stop him and ends up having to contact the mad scientist that lives in the mansion. Once the three main protagonists arive on the scene, the mad scientist asks for their help and convinces them to get into Port-O-Potty time machines to prevent Purple Tentacle from drinking the sludge in the first place.

Something goes terribly wrong and the three main protagonists get sent to three different points in time. The "Dude Brah", named Hoagie, gets sent about 200 years into the past to colonial America times, Bernard stays in the present and the deranged medical student, Laverne, gets sent about 200 years into the future where the world is now controlled by the evil Purple Tentacle's rule and humanity has been enslaved. All three have to work together, yet separately, in order to help each other out by sending objects back and forth to each other through the Port-O-Potty time machines. In doing so, they are not  only trying to get back to their own original timeline but also trying to prevent Purple Tentacle from taking over the world,[/quote]

The premise sounds silly but it's such a fun romp through an interactive Saturday Morning Cartoon where the humor from the 90's was at it's best (There's also a computer in the mad scientist's room where you can play the original 1987 Maniac Mansion on it, right inside this game. I do so hope they kept that in this remastered version).

This game is absolutely worth the full asking price. But if you see it on sale, snatch it up in a heartbeat.
